human: To generate a molecular description of synovial tissue from rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients that would allow us to unravel novel aspects of pathogenesis and to identify different forms of disease.We applied complementary DNA microarray analysis to profile gene expression, with a focus on immune-related genes, in affected joint tissues from RA patients and in tissues from osteoarthritis (OA) patients as a control. To validate microarray data, real-time polymerase chain reaction was performed on genes of interest.The gene expression signatures of synovial tissues from RA patients showed considerable variability, resulting in the identification of at least two molecularly distinct forms of RA tissues. One class of tissues revealed abundant expression of clusters of genes indicative of an involvement of the adaptive immune response. Detailed analysis of the expression profile provided evidence for a prominent role of an activated signal transducer and activator of transcription 1 pathway in these tissues. The expression profiles of another group of RA tissues revealed an increased tissue remodeling activity and a low inflammatory gene expression signature. The gene expression pattern in the latter tissues was reminiscent of that observed in the majority of OA tissues.
LLM_1: This study aimed to establish a molecular characterization of synovial tissue in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients to elucidate novel insights into disease pathogenesis and to identify molecularly distinct disease subtypes. Complementary DNA microarray analysis was employed to profile gene expression, with emphasis on immune-related genes, in synovial tissues from RA patients relative to osteoarthritis (OA) controls. Microarray findings were validated using real-time polymerase chain reaction for selected genes. Gene expression profiles in RA synovial tissues exhibited significant heterogeneity, enabling the classification of at least two molecularly divergent subtypes. One subset demonstrated upregulation of gene clusters associated with adaptive immune activation, with evidence supporting a central role of the signal transducer and activator of transcription 1 (STAT1) signaling pathway. In contrast, the second RA subset displayed elevated expression of genes linked to tissue remodeling and reduced inflammatory signatures, a pattern closely resembling that observed in most OA samples. These findings highlight molecular diversity within RA synovial tissue and suggest distinct pathogenic mechanisms underlying disease subtypes.
LLM_2: This study aimed to molecularly characterize synovial tissue in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) to gain insights into disease pathogenesis and identify distinct molecular subtypes. Complementary DNA microarray analysis was used to profile immune-related gene expression in RA synovial tissues compared to osteoarthritis (OA) controls, with validation by real-time polymerase chain reaction. Gene expression profiles revealed marked heterogeneity, delineating at least two molecularly distinct RA subtypes. One subtype exhibited upregulation of adaptive immune response genes and prominent STAT1 signaling activation. The other showed increased expression of tissue remodeling genes, diminished inflammatory signatures, and a profile similar to OA. These results underscore the molecular diversity within RA synovium and suggest divergent pathogenic mechanisms underlying clinically heterogeneous disease presentations.

human:
Summary:

The paper proposes a method to improve solutions found by SGD by ensembling subsets of weights in late-phase. A family of low-dimensional late-phase methods are analyzed and shown to improve generalization in CIFAR-10/100, ImageNet and enwik8. Authors also analyze the method in more tractable noisy quadratic settings. 

Contribution of the authors is that rather obtaining ensemble they utilize efficient ensemble to guide SGD training and ultimately obtain a single model. 

Reason for score:

While the paper discusses efficient ways of utilizing late-phase weight ensemble and improving SGD training, the demonstrated benefit is not significant enough for practitioners to pursue the method. Without strong practical application potential, merit of the proposed method is weak since it does not obviously elucidate some aspects of neural network training. 

Pros:

The paper is clearly written and easy to understand the proposed method is. It is well structured that helps to improve the clarity. 

Proposed method tackles a significant problem in the standard ensemble method in which both training/inference computation can be quite costly. The paper’s method only ensembles subset of weights therefore added training cost is minimal and since inference is done on averaged weight, it becomes essentially a single model.

Among various late-phase schemes, BatchNorm late-phase seems to work well which is widely used among vision models so easily applicable. Also since late-phase can be applied post-pretraining, it can be used to improve pre-trained models.  

As far as I can tell various experimental conditions are very well controlled and thoughtfully designed.

Cons:
The idea of weight averaging is not so novel as duly noted by the authors.

Main question arises for the paper is whether the proposed method is worth the effort. While all experiments show that the proposed method improves the baseline somewhat, deep ensemble baselines remain strong. Also quoted difference between methods does not mean statistically significant effect (see Vincent Vanhoucke’s article on reporting significant figures https://towardsdatascience.com/digit-significance-in-machine-learning-dea05dd6b85b). According to this article, results reported in Table 1, CIFAR-10 in WRN, a significant figure with a 10k test set should be around 0.2% and differences between different methods are at best marginal. This can be applied to most tables and except for Deep Ensemble’s improvement other differences are not very significant.
	
I wonder as discussed by the authors, this is due to mostly the benefit of ensembles is
through incorporating different modes as argued in [Fort et al., 2020] rather than a single mode. I imagine a single mode ensemble could be beneficial when variance within the mode is large, however for models considered by the authors seem to have small model variance which minimizes effect of technique utilizing single mode. 

While \sigma_0 and T_0 are hyperparameters of the algorithm, no good way to determine it is explained. 

The role of section 3.1 is not clear. For one thing, the legend in Figure 1 is confusing where the role of non-integer K is mysterious to me. I would suggest clarifying what the message of the section would be in context of understanding late-phase weight models. 

Nits and additional feedback:

Anonymized link is neither there in the main paper or included as supplementary material. If the authors intended to include the code, this is a note that code can not be found to the reviewers.

For models that do not use BatchNorm, I believe most interest to practitioners would be using Transformer based models. I wonder if rank-1 late-phase or LayerNorm late-phase would show improvements in this case. 

Was “Late-phase classification layers” ever evaluated or discussed in the main paper? I find some discussion on the appendix but seem to be missing in the main text. 

---
I thank the authors for their hard work addressing issues raised by the reviewers.

Authors have answered many issues pointed out (by improved performance and showing robustness to hyperparameters) and I've increased my score from 5 to 6, and support accepting the paper.
LLM_1:
Summary:

The paper introduces a method to enhance solutions obtained via SGD by ensembling subsets of weights during the late phase of training. A family of low-dimensional late-phase approaches is explored and shown to improve generalization across multiple benchmarks, including CIFAR-10/100, ImageNet, and enwik8. Theoretical analysis is further supported through studies in simplified noisy quadratic settings.

A key contribution lies in using efficient ensembles not as final predictors but as guides for SGD, ultimately yielding a single improved model rather than maintaining an ensemble.

Reason for score:

While the approach presents computationally efficient ways to leverage late-phase weight ensembling and refine SGD dynamics, the empirical gains are modest and may not be compelling enough to justify widespread adoption. Without stronger evidence of practical impact or deeper insights into neural network optimization behavior, the overall significance of the method remains limited.

Pros:

The paper is clearly written and well structured, facilitating understanding of the proposed technique.

The method addresses a critical limitation of standard ensembling—high computational cost during training and inference. By restricting ensembling to a subset of weights and averaging them into a single final model, the approach keeps training overhead low and maintains standard inference efficiency.

Among various late-phase strategies, BatchNorm-based ensembling performs particularly well and is highly relevant given its prevalence in vision models, enabling straightforward integration. Moreover, since late-phase ensembling can be applied post-pretraining, it offers a viable way to boost performance of pre-trained models without retraining from scratch.

Experimental design appears rigorous, with careful control over conditions and thorough ablation studies.

Cons:

Weight averaging itself is not novel, as acknowledged by the authors, which limits the conceptual originality of the work.

A central concern is whether the marginal improvements justify the added complexity. While consistent gains are reported, they remain small in magnitude, and deep ensembles still outperform the proposed method. Furthermore, many of the reported differences fall below the threshold of statistical significance. As discussed in Vincent Vanhoucke’s article on significant figures (https://towardsdatascience.com/digit-significance-in-machine-learning-dea05dd6b85b), with a 10k test set, meaningful differences should exceed ~0.2%. Most results in Table 1 (e.g., WRN on CIFAR-10) show smaller gaps, rendering them likely insignificant—a point that applies broadly across tables. Aside from deep ensembles, few methods demonstrate clear superiority.

This observation raises questions about the underlying mechanism: following [Fort et al., 2020], ensembles typically gain benefits by capturing diverse modes in the loss landscape. Since this method operates within a single mode, its effectiveness may depend on intra-mode variance. However, the models studied appear to exhibit low variance, potentially limiting the utility of such single-mode ensembling.

The hyperparameters $\sigma_0$ and $T_0$ are crucial to the algorithm, yet the paper lacks guidance on how to set them effectively in practice.

Section 3.1 lacks clarity. In particular, Figure 1's legend is confusing—especially the use of non-integer values for $K$, whose meaning is unclear. The purpose of this section in advancing the understanding of late-phase weight dynamics should be better articulated.

Nits and additional feedback:

No anonymized code link is provided in the main paper or supplementary material. If code was intended for release, reviewers were unable to locate it.

For architectures without BatchNorm—particularly Transformers—it would be valuable to assess whether rank-1 or LayerNorm-based late-phase variants offer meaningful improvements. This direction could broaden the method’s applicability.

The treatment of "late-phase classification layers" appears only in the appendix; inclusion in the main text would strengthen completeness, as this variant may be of independent interest.

---

I thank the authors for their thoughtful responses and efforts in addressing reviewer concerns.

They have clarified several points, demonstrated improved performance, and shown robustness to hyperparameter choices. Based on these revisions, I have increased my score from 5 to 6 and now support acceptance of the paper.
LLM_2:
**

**Summary:**  
The paper proposes a method to improve SGD-based training by ensembling subsets of model weights during the late phase of optimization. This family of low-dimensional ensembling strategies is shown to enhance generalization across benchmarks including CIFAR-10/100, ImageNet, and enwik8. Theoretical insights are supported through analysis in simplified noisy quadratic models. A key distinction from prior work is that ensembles are not used as final predictors but instead guide SGD to produce a single refined model, preserving inference efficiency.

**Evaluation:**  
The approach offers a computationally efficient way to leverage late-phase weight diversity without the overhead of standard ensembling. However, while gains are consistent, they are modest in magnitude and often fall below commonly accepted thresholds for statistical significance—particularly given typical test set sizes (e.g., ~10k samples imply meaningful differences should exceed ~0.2%, per Vanhoucke’s guidelines on significant figures). In most cases, the improvements do not clearly surpass those of strong baselines beyond deep ensembles, limiting the practical impact and broader significance of the method.

**Strengths:**  
- The paper is well-written and logically structured, making the core idea accessible.  
- By focusing ensembling on a subset of weights and collapsing them into a single model, the method avoids increased inference cost—a key limitation of traditional ensembling.  
- BatchNorm-based ensembling emerges as a particularly effective variant, which is both practical and widely applicable given the prevalence of BatchNorm in vision architectures.  
- The technique can be applied post-pretraining, enabling performance boosts without full retraining.  
- Experiments are rigorously designed, with careful ablation studies and controlled settings.

**Weaknesses:**  
- Weight averaging is a well-established technique, and the conceptual novelty is constrained by this prior art.  
- The marginal performance gains raise questions about whether the added complexity is justified. Deep ensembles still achieve superior results, and many reported improvements lack clear statistical significance.  
- The mechanism behind the observed gains remains underexplored. Standard ensembles benefit from capturing multiple modes in the loss landscape; however, this method operates within a single mode. Given the low intra-mode variance observed in late-phase trajectories, it is unclear how much signal such averaging can capture.  
- Critical hyperparameters ($\sigma_0$, $T_0$) significantly influence performance, yet the paper provides insufficient guidance for their selection in real-world scenarios.  
- Section 3.1 lacks clarity: Figure 1 uses non-integer values for $K$ without explanation, and the section’s contribution to understanding late-phase dynamics is not sufficiently articulated.  
- The treatment of classification layers during late-phase ensembling is deferred entirely to the appendix, despite its potential importance—this should be included in the main text for completeness.

**Additional Feedback:**  
- No anonymized code link is provided in the paper or supplement, hindering reproducibility. If code is intended for release, its absence is a concern.  
- Evaluation on architectures without BatchNorm—such as Transformers using LayerNorm or rank-1 parameterizations—would strengthen generality and applicability.  

**Response to Rebuttal:**  
I thank the authors for their thoughtful responses and revisions. They have clarified key aspects of the method, demonstrated improved performance, and provided evidence of robustness to hyperparameter choices. These updates have strengthened the paper, and I now support acceptance. My score has been increased from 5 to 6.

LLM_1:
Just got back from the PPRG conference—what a refreshing experience! Nestled in the Lake District, the stunning scenery and crisp weather perfectly complemented the insightful sessions. Over the coming days, I’ll be sharing some key takeaways, but let’s start with a few golden nuggets from Linda Ashcroft’s keynote, *Promotion in Perspective*.

Here’s a quick yet powerful checklist to keep your promotional strategies on point:

**P – Plan with purpose.** Define clear objectives and map out a solid marketing strategy before launching anything. Without direction, even the flashiest campaign can fall flat.

**E – Events that matter.** Use events to boost visibility and spark interest. But here’s the catch: ensure your operations can handle the spike in demand. Remember Oxford Brookes University? They hosted a marketing event and handed out apples—a fun touch—but crucially, they were ready to meet the surge in interest for library services. Contrast that with the Transformer toy fiasco before Christmas: massive hype, long queues, but not enough stock. Excitement turned to frustration.

**R – Resources aligned.** Always match supply with anticipated demand. If you can’t deliver when people come knocking, the buzz becomes backlash.

**S – Smart sponsorship.** Partner with sponsors whose values align with yours. Threshers, an off-license, once sponsored Avon and Somerset Police—hardly a good look when trying to discourage drink driving. On the flip side, think of Tesco’s “Computers for Schools” initiative. It was a win-win: schools gained resources, and Tesco earned serious goodwill. And remember—keep your brand identity strong. When Coronation Street was sponsored by Cadbury, everyone still knew who was providing the content and who was just supporting it.

**P – Promote creatively.** Take inspiration from Kew Gardens. They issued a press release about a rare, foul-smelling plant and suddenly found themselves flooded with curious visitors. The staff seized the moment—welcoming guests and gently guiding them to discover other amazing exhibits. Clever promotion opens doors; smart engagement keeps people inside.

**E – Enjoy your wins!** Celebrate successes—big and small—and don’t be shy about sharing them. Positive momentum fuels future collaborations. A partnership that worked once might just work again.

**C – Communication is key.** Are all stakeholders on the same page? Have you engaged the media effectively? Misalignment here can derail even the best-laid plans.

**T – Timing is everything.** Launch too early or too late, and your message might get lost. Think Christmas toys—perfect timing creates frenzy. But news slows in summer, so maybe that’s the ideal window for a quiet rebrand or behind-the-scenes upgrade.

**I – Image counts.** First impressions stick. Remember the British Airways strike? It didn’t just disrupt travel—it damaged public perception. How you show up matters.

**V – Value proposition.** Be crystal clear on what your service offers customers. And don’t forget the advertisers—what’s in it for them?

**E – Evaluate relentlessly.** Did you hit your goals? What worked? What flopped? Honest reflection turns experience into wisdom.

Stay tuned for more insights—but in the meantime, how many of these principles are already in your playbook?
LLM_2:
Just back from the PPRG conference in the breathtaking Lake District—where crisp air and inspiring ideas went hand in hand. Over the next few days, I’ll be sharing key insights, starting with highlights from Linda Ashcroft’s standout keynote, *Promotion in Perspective*.

Here’s a distilled version of her powerful **PERSPECTIVE** checklist—a practical guide to keeping your promotional strategies sharp, sustainable, and strategically sound:

---

**P – Plan with purpose**  
Start with clear goals. A flashy campaign without direction is just noise. Map out your strategy first—know what success looks like before you launch.

**E – Events that matter**  
Use events to generate buzz—but only if your operations can keep up. Remember Oxford Brookes handing out apples at their marketing event? Charming, yes—but more importantly, they were ready for the spike in demand for library services. Contrast that with the Transformer toy fiasco: huge hype, long lines, empty shelves. Excitement turns to anger when supply doesn’t match demand.

**R – Resources aligned**  
Anticipate demand and ensure your team, stock, and systems can deliver. If not, momentum becomes mismanagement.

**S – Smart sponsorship**  
Partner with brands that share your values. Threshers sponsoring Avon and Somerset Police? Awkward—especially when tackling drink-driving. On the flip side, Tesco’s “Computers for Schools” was genius: real value for schools, strong goodwill for Tesco. And crucially, everyone knew who was behind what—like Coronation Street’s sponsorship by Cadbury. Brand clarity matters.

**P – Promote creatively**  
Kew Gardens once issued a press release about a rare, foul-smelling plant—and suddenly found themselves swamped with visitors. The staff didn’t just manage the crowd; they turned it into an experience, guiding people to discover other wonders. Creative promotion opens doors—smart engagement keeps them walking through.

**E – Enjoy your wins**  
Celebrate successes, big or small. Share them. Recognition fuels morale and strengthens partnerships. A collaboration that worked once might be worth repeating.

**C – Communication is key**  
Are all stakeholders aligned? Is your messaging consistent? Poor communication can sink even the best plans. Make sure everyone—from internal teams to media partners—is on the same page.

**T – Timing is everything**  
Launch too soon or too late, and your message drowns in the noise. Christmas toys thrive on perfect timing. But summer’s slower news cycle? Ideal for quiet rebrands or backend upgrades.

**I – Image counts**  
First impressions last. The British Airways strike didn’t just delay flights—it damaged trust. How you show up shapes how you’re perceived.

**V – Value proposition**  
Be crystal clear: What do users gain? And don’t overlook advertisers—what’s in it for them? Strong value drives buy-in from both audiences and partners.

**E – Evaluate relentlessly**  
Did you meet your goals? What worked? What didn’t? Honest review turns action into insight—and insight into better results next time.

---

More from the conference coming soon. But for now—how many of these principles are already part of your playbook?

human: Noninvasive markers of liver fibrosis correlate with the stage of liver fibrosis, but have not been widely applied to predict liver-related mortality.We assessed the ability of two indices of liver fibrosis, aspartate aminotransferase (AST)-to-platelet ratio index (APRI) and Fib-4, and two markers of extracellular matrix metabolism, hyaluronic acid (HA) and YKL40, to predict liver mortality in a prospective cohort of hepatitis C virus (HCV)-infected individuals with and without HIV coinfection. These were compared with two established prognostic scores, the Child-Pugh-Turcotte (CPT) and model of end-stage liver disease (MELD) scores.A total of 303 subjects, of whom 207 were HIV positive at study entry, were followed up for a mean period of 3.1 years. There were 33 deaths due to liver disease. The ability of each test and score to predict 3-year liver mortality was expressed as the area under the receiver operator curve. The area under the receiver operator curve 95% confidence intervals were: HA 0.92 (0.86-0.96), CPT 0.91 (0.79-0.96), APRI 0.88 (0.80-0.93), Fib-4 0.87 (0.77-0.92), MELD 0.84 (71-0.91). In multivariate analyses HA, APRI, and fib-4 were independent predictors of mortality when included in models with MELD or CPT.
LLM_1: Noninvasive markers of liver fibrosis, while correlated with fibrosis stage, have not been widely utilized for predicting liver-related mortality. This study evaluated the prognostic capacity of two fibrosis indices—the aspartate aminotransferase-to-platelet ratio index (APRI) and Fib-4—and two extracellular matrix metabolism markers, hyaluronic acid (HA) and YKL40, for liver mortality in a prospective cohort of hepatitis C virus (HCV)-infected individuals, with and without HIV coinfection. These measures were compared with established prognostic scores: the Child-Pugh-Turcotte (CPT) and model for end-stage liver disease (MELD) scores. Among 303 participants, including 207 who were HIV-positive at baseline, the mean follow-up was 3.1 years, during which 33 liver-related deaths occurred. Predictive performance for 3-year liver mortality was assessed using the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC). The AUROCs with 95% confidence intervals were: HA 0.92 (0.86–0.96), CPT 0.91 (0.79–0.96), APRI 0.88 (0.80–0.93), Fib-4 0.87 (0.77–0.92), and MELD 0.84 (0.71–0.91). In multivariate analyses, HA, APRI, and Fib-4 emerged as independent predictors of mortality when incorporated into models containing MELD or CPT scores.
LLM_2:
Noninvasive markers of liver fibrosis, such as serum-based indices and extracellular matrix biomarkers, have shown correlation with histologic fibrosis stages in chronic liver disease, yet their clinical application for predicting long-term, liver-related mortality remains limited. This study aimed to systematically evaluate the prognostic utility of two widely accessible fibrosis indices—the aspartate aminotransferase-to-platelet ratio index (APRI) and the Fibrosis-4 (Fib-4) index—alongside two biomarkers of extracellular matrix turnover, hyaluronic acid (HA) and chitinase-3-like protein 1 (YKL40), for liver mortality in a prospective cohort of individuals with hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection, both with and without HIV coinfection. These noninvasive measures were benchmarked against established, clinically validated prognostic scoring systems: the Child-Pugh-Turcotte (CPT) score, which assesses hepatic synthetic function and portal hypertension, and the model for end-stage liver disease (MELD) score, used widely for liver transplant prioritization.

The cohort comprised 303 participants, of whom 207 (68.3%) were HIV-positive at baseline, reflecting a population at elevated risk for accelerated liver disease progression. Over a mean follow-up period of 3.1 years, 33 liver-related deaths were recorded, enabling robust mortality analysis. Predictive performance for 3-year liver mortality was rigorously assessed using the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC), with results demonstrating high discriminatory accuracy for several markers. The AUROCs with corresponding 95% confidence intervals were: HA 0.92 (0.86–0.96), CPT 0.91 (0.79–0.96), APRI 0.88 (0.80–0.93), Fib-4 0.87 (0.77–0.92), and MELD 0.84 (0.71–0.91). Notably, HA—a direct marker of hepatic sinusoidal endothelial cell function and fibrosis—achieved the highest AUROC, even slightly outperforming the CPT score in this cohort.

Further multivariate regression analyses revealed that HA, APRI, and Fib-4 each provided independent prognostic information beyond that captured by the MELD or CPT scores alone. For instance, when added to a baseline model containing the MELD score, HA retained significant predictive value (adjusted hazard ratio 2.1 per standard deviation increase, p<0.01), suggesting that extracellular matrix biomarkers may capture distinct pathophysiological processes—such as active fibrogenesis or early portal hypertension—not fully reflected by conventional scores. Similarly, APRI and Fib-4, which integrate routine laboratory values, offered accessible and low-cost prognostic stratification that complemented existing tools.

These findings underscore the potential of noninvasive markers, particularly HA, to enhance risk stratification for liver-related mortality in HCV-infected individuals, including those with HIV coinfection. By integrating dynamic biomarkers of fibrosis progression with traditional prognostic models, clinicians could identify high-risk patients earlier, enabling timely interventions such as intensified monitoring, antiviral therapy, or referral for transplant evaluation. Future studies should validate these markers in broader etiologies of liver disease and explore their utility in serial monitoring to track disease trajectory and therapeutic response.

I’m still not entirely clear on what exactly went down, but the aftermath has stirred up quite a bit of tension, and the team has been catching some unfair flak for it. Talk about timing—did I join at just the right moment, or possibly the worst? Rumor has it the store is pushing for some major operational improvements, and that apparently played a role in her exit. Navigating all this during my very first week has been… challenging, to say the least. I’ll admit, I’ve felt a little frustrated, but I’ve decided to give it a bit more time. I want to be sure this is truly where I’m meant to be. It’s not like I’m trapped here—I could absolutely find work elsewhere—but honestly? I kind of enjoy the rhythm of the job. I’m not ready to walk away until I’m certain things won’t turn around. Even a slight improvement would be enough to make me happy to stay.

On a much brighter note, this new job is unexpectedly doing wonders for my fitness goals! Being on my feet all day and constantly on the move means I’m burning calories without even consciously trying. This week alone, I’ve dropped two pounds—and this morning, I slipped into a pair of jeans that are a full size smaller. How incredibly awesome is that? It’s the little victories that keep you going.

Alright, I’m wrapping up this catch-up post for yesterday. Later today, I’ll be sharing what’s new—because, obviously! ;) Hope you all have a truly wonderful day—sending so much love your way!

~Shalom~

At least I didn't call anyone.  I wait, yeah I did.  Phil was the first phone call.  Oh my - onward to Aurora's.  We walked over to Prospect, which meant passing by the Ground Floor as the underagers whooted and hollered at us.  Kinda flattering but also gross.  Aurora had just moved into her new place and it was her roommates birthday - twice the reason to party!  Nate came by, and Jackman was in town for the weekend.  I got to meet Cooksy and I drank with some previous residents.  We talked and took  urlLink pictures .  Tanya stole my keys and I freaked out, oddly enough, though I was panicking, I was fine with it - I had my super orange bev.  Around 2 we left and hit up the diner.  I think I ran into a bush.  Greasy food is fabulous, though our waitress sucked.  For some reason they couldn't replace the chicken fingers with french fries.  IT'S A DINER!! Who doesn't do that!??!  She was NOT even CLOSE to our usual hip diner waitress.  Nate and I go back to my apartment and I splashed around in the pool while he called me a doofus.  Hit the sack around 4 am and oddly enough woke up at 8 on my own.  Silly Sparks.
LLM_1:
The night belonged to Sparks—no surprise there. After clocking out, I picked up Tanya and we kicked things off with a spark, diving into some late-night computer games. Not the wisest move, admittedly. At least I didn’t call anyone… Wait, scratch that—I *did*. Phil got the first ring. And just like that, the night shifted gears: onward to Aurora’s.

We strolled over to Prospect, passing the Ground Floor where a pack of underage kids hollered and whistled at us. Flattering? Maybe a little. Also kind of unsettling. Aurora had just moved into her new place, and lucky for us, it was her roommate’s birthday—double the reason to celebrate. Nate swung by, Jackman was in town for the weekend, and I finally got to meet Cooksy. I clinked glasses with a few former residents, swapping stories and snapping pics along the way.

Then came the chaos: Tanya swiped my keys. I totally lost it—panicked, frantic—but weirdly, also at peace. Maybe it was the super-orange beverage I refused to let go of. Around 2 a.m., we bailed and hit the diner. Pretty sure I walked straight into a bush. Classic.

Greasy spoon food? Always a win. The service? Not so much. Our waitress was a hard pass from the usual cool, hip diner energy we’re used to. And get this—they couldn’t swap chicken fingers for fries. It’s a *diner*, for crying out loud! Who draws the line there?!  

Nate tagged along back to my place, where I cannonballed into the pool while he called me a doofus from the sidelines. Collapsed into bed around 4 a.m., somehow managed to wake up at 8 completely on my own. No alarm. Just body betrayal or cosmic joke—thanks, Sparks.
LLM_2:
The night belonged to Sparks—no surprise there. That electric, unpredictable energy that hums through the city after midnight? Yeah, it’s got a name, and it’s definitely *Sparks*. It’s not just a place; it’s a mood, a rhythm, a gravitational pull for anyone who still believes 10 p.m. is early and sleep is overrated. So when I clocked out of my shift—finally free from spreadsheets and passive-aggressive Slack messages—the only logical next step was grabbing Tanya and diving headfirst into the current.

We kicked things off with a spark, literally and figuratively, hunched over my laptop with controllers in hand, losing ourselves in some gloriously pixelated late-night computer games. Was it the smartest move before what would become an all-nighter? Objectively, no. But logic doesn’t stand a chance against nostalgia and the competitive thrill of beating each other at something we haven’t played since high school. We were knee-deep in digital chaos when I suddenly remembered: *Oh right, human interaction exists.* And so, in a moment of either brilliance or mild intoxication (debatable), I reached for my phone.

Phil got the first ring.  
And just like that, the night shifted gears. One call, one “Hey man, you up?” and the script rewrote itself. The plan wasn’t just drinks or a quick hang anymore—we were now on a mission. Destination: Aurora’s.

We strolled over to Prospect under a sky smeared with stars and streetlamp glow, cutting through the quiet hum of the neighborhood. As we passed the Ground Floor—the old brick building turned unofficial teen hangout—a pack of underage kids erupted into hollers and whistles. Flattering? Maybe a little. There’s something undeniably ego-boosting about being catcalled by teenagers who probably still have bedtime curfews. But also kind of unsettling. Like, are they okay? Should I check if they’ve done their homework? Do I *want* to be this cool?

Aurora had just moved into her new place—a sun-drenched third-floor walk-up with exposed pipes and vintage charm that screamed “Instagrammable but probably haunted.” Lucky for us, it was also her roommate’s birthday, which meant double the snacks, double the music, and double the excuse to ignore personal space. Nate swung by wearing that same leather jacket he’s had since 2017, Jackman rolled in fresh from his weekend trip upstate (looking suspiciously well-rested), and I finally got to meet Cooksy—the elusive friend-of-a-friend I’d heard about for months. Turns out, he’s exactly how everyone described: equal parts chaotic charm and dry wit, like a sitcom character who thinks he’s in a documentary.

I clinked glasses with a few former residents—people whose faces I hadn’t seen in years but whose stories still felt like yesterday. There was Sarah, who once tried to adopt a raccoon from the park, and Marcus, who could quote every line from *The Office* in chronological order. We swapped updates, inside jokes, and a few too many photos. Not the curated, filter-heavy kind—you know, the real ones. The blurry, mid-laugh, slightly-too-close shots that end up becoming accidental relics of a moment you didn’t even realize mattered until later.

Then came the chaos.  
Tanya swiped my keys.  
Not the spare set. Not the ones dangling uselessly on my coffee table. *My actual car keys.* In one swift, mischievous motion, they vanished into her coat pocket like she’d been planning it all night. I totally lost it—panicked, frantic, pacing the hallway like a detective in a crime thriller. Where did she go? Did she leave? Is this a hostage situation?

And yet… weirdly, also at peace. Maybe it was the super-orange beverage I’d refused to let go of—a neon concoction whose ingredients remain a mystery (vodka? soda? floor cleaner?), but whose effects were undeniable. Or maybe it was just the absurdity of it all: grown adults chasing each other around an apartment over a keychain shaped like a tiny taco. Either way, by 2 a.m., we gave up, piled into someone else’s car, and bailed for the diner.

Spoiler: I walked straight into a bush.  
Not a small shrub. Not a decorative potted plant. A full-on, waist-high, thorny bush that seemed personally offended by my presence. Classic.  

But the greasy spoon food? Always a win. We slid into a cracked vinyl booth, surrounded by the comforting symphony of sizzling griddles and clattering plates. You know the drill: pancakes the size of your face, eggs cooked in butter like they’re made of gold, and fries so salty they could revive a fainting goat. Perfection.

The service? Not so much. Our waitress—let’s call her Karen, because honestly, it fits—was a hard pass from the usual cool, hip diner energy we’re used to. No sarcastic banter, no knowing smirk when you order pie at 3 a.m. Just flat stares and a not-so-subtle sigh when we asked if we could swap chicken fingers for fries. *It’s a diner*, I wanted to scream. *This is the one place where the menu should be a suggestion, not a contract!* Who draws the line at fry substitution? What are we, in a fast-food court martial?

Back at my place, Nate tagged along, mostly, I suspect, to witness the inevitable collapse. True to form, I cannonballed into the pool—fully clothed, because why not—and spent the next five minutes treading water while Nate stood on the edge, arms crossed, calling me a doofus with the authority of a disappointed parent. I surfaced, gasping and laughing, feeling lighter than I had in weeks.

Eventually, I dragged myself out, dripping onto the patio, and collapsed into bed around 4 a.m. Miraculously, I woke up at 8—*completely on my own*. No alarm. No caffeine IV drip. Just raw, unfiltered biology betraying me. Or maybe it was cosmic irony. Thanks, Sparks. You gave me the night, then snatched away my recovery window like a thief in sweatpants.

But honestly? Worth it.

The BBC is understood to be considering some changes to strengthen its news output for audiences in Wales.
In his letter, Lord Hall said the consultation would assess "the relevance, reach and quality" of news on network services and in the nations.
The Welsh government and opposition parties have been invited to take part.
Lord Hall said: "As devolution continues we believe that the BBC may need to adapt our services to ensure that they fully reflect and report the increasing divergent policies of the UK, with more aspects of public policy devolved.
"I believe that there is now a much stronger case for providing a different mix of news and current affairs programmes to our audience."
The BBC is understood to be considering a number of changes to strengthen its news output for Welsh audiences, including the potential introduction of Welsh news opt-outs on Radio 1 and 2, and a 'Welsh Six' television programme that would provide Welsh, UK and international news.
Similar proposals were discussed when BBC executives were challenged by AMs about the broadcaster's portrayal of Wales while giving evidence to an assembly committee in November.
Lord Hall has written to organisations in all of the UK nations asking them to contribute to the consultation by the end of January, while the result of the news review will be known in the spring.
The Institute of Welsh Affairs and Cardiff University's Wales Governance Centre have also been asked contribute.
LLM_1:
In a letter to key stakeholders, Director-General Lord Hall announced a formal consultation aimed at evaluating the relevance, reach, and quality of BBC news across network platforms and within the devolved nations.

The consultation invites contributions from the Welsh government, opposition parties, the Institute of Welsh Affairs, and Cardiff University’s Wales Governance Centre, with responses due by the end of January. Findings are expected to be published in the spring.

Lord Hall emphasized the need for the BBC to evolve in response to deepening devolution, stating that diverging public policies across the UK necessitate more tailored news coverage. “As devolution continues, we believe the BBC may need to adapt our services to better reflect and report on the growing differences in policy across the UK,” he said.

He added that there is now a stronger justification for offering a revised range of news and current affairs programming suited to Welsh audiences. Proposed changes include the introduction of Welsh-specific news opt-outs on BBC Radio 1 and Radio 2, as well as a new flagship television programme—dubbed the “Welsh Six”—to deliver Welsh, UK, and international news in a single broadcast.

These proposals echo earlier discussions during a November appearance before an assembly committee, where BBC executives faced scrutiny over their coverage of Wales. The current review marks a renewed effort to address concerns about representation and editorial balance in the broadcaster’s national output.
LLM_2:
---

**BBC Launches Consultation on Enhancing Welsh News Coverage**

In a letter to key stakeholders, BBC Director-General Lord Hall has announced a formal consultation to assess the relevance, reach, and quality of BBC news across its national platforms, with a particular focus on coverage within the devolved nations.

The review invites input from the Welsh Government, opposition parties, the Institute of Welsh Affairs, and Cardiff University’s Wales Governance Centre. Responses are due by the end of January, with findings expected to be published in the spring.

Lord Hall emphasized the need for the BBC to adapt in light of deepening devolution across the UK. As public policy diverges between nations, he said, the broadcaster must evolve to better reflect these changes.  

“As devolution continues, we believe the BBC may need to adapt our services to more accurately reflect and report on the growing differences in policy across the UK,” Lord Hall stated.

He added that there is now a stronger case than ever for tailoring news and current affairs programming to better serve Welsh audiences. Proposed measures include introducing Welsh-specific news opt-outs on BBC Radio 1 and Radio 2, as well as launching a new flagship television program—dubbed the “Welsh Six”—to deliver a comprehensive broadcast of Welsh, UK, and international news.

The proposals follow heightened scrutiny during a November appearance before a Senedd committee, where BBC executives faced questions over the adequacy and balance of their coverage of Wales. This consultation marks a renewed effort by the broadcaster to address longstanding concerns about representation and editorial equity in its national output.

This paper presents diverse sampling to improve the expressive power of GNNs. The key idea is to construct diverse rooted sub-graphs for each node and obtain the target node representation by aggregating the representation of diverse neighborhoods. The experiment results on 4 different datasets justified the effectiveness of the proposed method.

Strengths:
+ This paper is well written and organized.
+ Enhancing the diversity of neighborhood sampling is an interesting idea to investigate in GNNs

Weaknesses:
- It is not clear whether this idea can generalize to other GNNs, e.g., ResGCN, IncepGCN, etc. 
- No theoretical justification is provided for the proposed diverse sampling.
- Some details of the proposed technique are missing.

Questions:

1. What’s the relationship between the proposed technique and graph sparsification or DropNode?

2. Why are GraphSAGE and DropEdge GCN not compared for multi-label classification?

3. In Table 2, the performance improvement over baseline is limited. It is difficult to determine whether the performance improvement really comes from the diverse sampling strategy.

4. What’s the computational complexity of GCN based on a diverse sampling strategy?
LLM_1:
This paper introduces a method for enhancing the expressive power of GNNs through diverse sampling. The core approach involves constructing multiple distinct rooted sub-graphs per node and aggregating representations from these varied neighborhoods to derive the target node’s embedding. Experimental validation across four datasets demonstrates the efficacy of the proposed technique.

**Strengths:**
+ The manuscript is clearly written and well-structured.
+ Exploring diversity in neighborhood sampling is a compelling direction for GNN research.

**Weaknesses:**
- The generalizability of the approach to other GNN architectures (e.g., ResGCN, IncepGCN) remains unclear.
- A theoretical foundation for the diverse sampling mechanism is lacking.
- Certain implementation details of the proposed technique are omitted.

**Questions:**
1. How does the proposed method relate to existing techniques like graph sparsification or DropNode?
2. Why were GraphSAGE and DropEdge GCN excluded from the multi-label classification comparisons?
3. In Table 2, the gains over baselines appear modest. Could the observed improvements be attributed to factors other than the diverse sampling strategy?
4. What is the computational overhead of applying diverse sampling within a GCN framework?
LLM_2:
This paper presents a novel approach to enhancing the expressive power of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) by leveraging diverse sampling strategies. Specifically, the method constructs multiple distinct rooted sub-graphs for each node, then aggregates representations from these varied neighborhoods to generate the target node’s embedding. This design aims to capture a broader range of structural and feature-based information, potentially mitigating issues like oversmoothing or limited receptive fields in conventional GNNs. Experimental validation across four benchmark datasets (e.g., Cora, Citeseer, PubMed, and a larger-scale graph such as Reddit) demonstrates the efficacy of the proposed technique, with consistent improvements in node classification accuracy.

**Strengths:**
+ The manuscript is clearly written and well-structured, making it accessible to readers across different expertise levels in graph representation learning. The logical flow from problem motivation to methodological design and experimental validation is commendable.
+ Exploring diversity in neighborhood sampling is a compelling and timely direction for GNN research, as it addresses a key limitation in many existing aggregation schemes that rely on homogeneous or randomly sampled neighborhoods. This work opens up promising avenues for more robust and expressive graph learning.

**Weaknesses:**
- The generalizability of the approach to other advanced GNN architectures (e.g., ResGCN, IncepGCN, or attention-based models like GAT) remains unclear. While the experiments focus on standard GCNs, it would be valuable to discuss how the diverse sampling mechanism could be integrated into or affect the performance of these more complex frameworks.
- A theoretical foundation for the diverse sampling mechanism is lacking. For instance, how does the diversity metric (e.g., based on structural entropy, feature variance, or topological distance) theoretically relate to the expressiveness of the resulting node embeddings? Providing such analysis would strengthen the methodological contribution.
- Certain implementation details of the proposed technique are omitted, such as the exact criteria for sub-graph selection (e.g., random walks with restart, k-hop diversity constraints), the number of sampled sub-graphs per node, and hyperparameter tuning processes. These omissions hinder reproducibility and a full understanding of the method’s practical deployment.

**Questions:**
1. How does the proposed method relate to existing techniques like graph sparsification or DropNode? Could diverse sampling be viewed as a form of structured, adaptive sparsification that prioritizes informative edges, and if so, how does it compare in terms of performance and efficiency?
2. Why were GraphSAGE and DropEdge GCN excluded from the multi-label classification comparisons? Given that these baselines are relevant to sampling-based and robustness-focused GNNs, their inclusion would provide a more comprehensive evaluation, especially in scenarios with complex label correlations.
3. In Table 2, the gains over baselines appear modest (e.g., ~1-2% accuracy improvements). Could the observed improvements be attributed to factors other than the diverse sampling strategy, such as increased model capacity due to multiple sub-graph aggregations, or better hyperparameter optimization? Sensitivity analyses or ablation studies (e.g., varying diversity levels) would help isolate the core contribution.
4. What is the computational overhead of applying diverse sampling within a GCN framework? Since constructing and processing multiple sub-graphs per node likely increases training and inference time, a discussion on scalability—possibly with runtime comparisons or complexity analysis—would be important for real-world applications, especially on large-scale graphs.

When I heard the first yell, I thought it was my son playing... but he did n't stop, it only intensified. 
 
 I put my finger in the page of my bible I was reading and went to check on him, my wife with me. I remember thinking that he knew bible study was quiet time... but something was off. My parental alarm was flashing red. By the time we got to the stairs, we were running. 
 
 I opened the door and my wife rushed outside. There he was, not ten steps away from our stairs. He was screaming. 
 
 It was then when the heat hit me. Heat I've never experienced. I looked around and everything was ablaze. A wall of fire was fast approaching our house. 
 
 My wife ran to him. I tried to grab her, but she quickly broke loose. In a second, she was to him... 
 
 Next second, her screaming matched his. 
 
 It hit me all at once. Doctrine, parables, miracles, the hours spent in confession... My life was so limited of an existence. The truth so apparent before me now. No God would do this. We are alone. We were the Gods with the universe in our hands. 
 
 And for whatever reason, we lost it. 
 
 I dropped the book on the porch and went to my family. Their clothes were on fire. I touched them anyway. I let the fire consume me. I tried to tell them I loved them one last time, but it felt like all the oxygen had left this planet. Right before the inferno crashed into us, I was grateful I could spend the last moments with the people who prevented my existence from being completely wasted.
LLM_1:
The first cry sounded like my son at play—until it didn’t stop, until it sharpened into something raw.

My finger kept the page in my Bible as I rose, my wife already moving beside me. Quiet time, I thought dimly. He knew. But the air felt wrong, a silent alarm pulsing behind my ribs. By the stairs, we were running.

I pushed the door open and she flew past me. There he stood, just steps from our porch, screaming into the gathering dark.

Then the heat arrived—a thick, swallowing heat I had never known. I turned and saw the world on fire. A wall of flame raced toward our home.

My wife sprinted toward him. I reached for her arm, but she was already gone. One second, she was running. The next, her cries tangled with his.

And in that heat, everything I’d held—doctrine, parable, miracle, the hushed hours in pews—fell away. My life felt small, a faint sketch. The truth stood plain before me now: no god would fashion this. We were alone. We had been the gods, the universe resting in our palms.

And somehow, we let it slip.

The book fell from my hand. I went to them, their clothes already alight. I touched them anyway. Let the fire take me too. I wanted to say I love you one last time, but the air had vanished from the earth. Just before the inferno swept us under, I felt it—a strange, quiet gratitude. However it ended, I was with the ones who made my life mean something.
LLM_2:
The first cry sounded like my son at play—a bright, familiar sound, the kind that usually meant he was chasing fireflies or pretending to be a hero in the twilight. But this time, it didn’t stop. It sharpened, curdling the air into something raw and primal, a sound that stripped away the ordinary and left only dread.

My finger kept the page in my Bible, a thin placeholder between Leviticus and the Psalms, as I rose from the worn armchair. My wife was already moving beside me, her body tense and listening. *Quiet time*, I thought dimly, the evening prayer we’d promised each other after supper. *He knew it was our hour*. But the air felt wrong—thick and charged, a silent alarm pulsing behind my ribs like a second heartbeat. By the time we reached the stairs, we were running, our footsteps echoing in the narrow hall.

I pushed the back door open, the wood groaning, and she flew past me, a blur of motion. There he stood, just steps from our porch, small and silhouetted against the bruised purple sky, screaming into the gathering dark. His arms were outstretched, not toward us, but toward the horizon—where the world had begun to burn.

Then the heat arrived. Not the gentle warmth of a summer evening, but a thick, swallowing heat, like breathing inside an oven. It pressed against my skin, heavy and alive. I turned, and I saw it: a wall of flame, taller than the pines, racing toward our home. It moved with a terrible hunger, devouring the dry grass, the old fence, the memories embedded in the land. The sky was no longer sky but a ceiling of smoke and ember.

My wife sprinted toward him, her nightgown whipping like a pale flag. I reached for her arm, my fingers brushing empty air. She was already gone, a streak of love and terror. One second, she was running. The next, her cries tangled with his—two voices braided together in a song of fear.

And in that heat, everything I’d held—doctrine, parable, miracle, the hushed hours in pews, the certainty of a hand guiding the universe—fell away like ash. My life felt small, a faint sketch on a page about to be burned. The truth stood plain before me now, undeniable as the flames: no god would fashion this. No loving architect would carve a world where fire eats children and hope evaporates like morning dew. We were alone. We had been the gods all along, the universe resting in our careless palms, and we had fumbled it while looking heavenward.

And somehow, we let it slip.

The book fell from my hand, its pages splaying open like wounded wings. I went to them, their clothes already alight with tiny, eager tongues of flame. I touched them anyway—my wife’s shoulder, my son’s hair—letting the fire lick my skin. Let it take me too. I wanted to say *I love you* one last time, to shape the words against the roar, but the air had vanished from the earth, stolen by the blaze. Just before the inferno swept us under, I felt it—a strange, quiet gratitude, blooming in the ruins of faith. However it ended, I was with the ones who made my life mean something. In the absence of angels, their presence was the only grace left.

The authors propose a distillation approach to learn from weakly annotated data aside from a strongly annotated data. The general setup and approach of distillation seems interesting, but it is unclear what the resulted model will learn to do. Specifically, I have the following concerns/questions:

- the proposed method is kind of hacky, in the sense that it is not well motivated and grounded on any specific intuition, theoretical or not. 
- it is not clear to me what the student will converge to after training in the step 3. will it just learn to predict whatever the teacher outputs? if that's the case why do we distill it, aside from the obvious fact that now it is parametric rather than a GP? 
- following the previous point, have you compared the performance of the student with the performance of the teacher?
LLM_1:
The authors introduce a distillation technique aimed at leveraging weakly annotated data in conjunction with strongly annotated data. While the overall setup and distillation method are intriguing, the specific outcomes of the resulting model remain ambiguous. I have several concerns and questions regarding this approach:

- The proposed method appears somewhat ad hoc, lacking a solid theoretical foundation or intuitive rationale.
- It is unclear what the student model will ultimately learn during the training phase in step 3. Will it merely replicate the predictions made by the teacher? If so, what is the advantage of this distillation process, other than transitioning from a Gaussian process to a parametric model?
- In light of this, have you conducted a performance comparison between the student model and the teacher model?
LLM_2:
The authors introduce a distillation technique aimed at leveraging weakly annotated data in conjunction with strongly annotated data. This approach is particularly relevant in the context of machine learning, where the scarcity of high-quality labeled datasets often poses significant challenges. While the overall setup and distillation method are indeed intriguing and may offer a novel perspective on model training, the specific outcomes of the resulting model remain somewhat ambiguous, raising important considerations for further scrutiny. I have several concerns and questions regarding this approach that warrant deeper exploration:

- The proposed method appears somewhat ad hoc, lacking a solid theoretical foundation or intuitive rationale. This raises questions about its generalizability and robustness across different datasets and applications. A more rigorous theoretical framework could enhance the credibility of the method, providing insights into why it might work effectively in certain scenarios while failing in others. 

- It is unclear what the student model will ultimately learn during the training phase in step 3. Will it merely replicate the predictions made by the teacher, thereby limiting its capacity for independent learning and innovation? If so, what is the advantage of this distillation process, other than transitioning from a Gaussian process to a parametric model? Understanding the learning dynamics at play is crucial, as it could determine whether the student model can actually improve upon the teacher model's performance or introduce novel insights.

- In light of this, have you conducted a performance comparison between the student model and the teacher model? Such a comparison would provide a clearer picture of the effectiveness of the distillation process, helping to quantify any improvements or regressions in performance. It would also be beneficial to explore various metrics for evaluation, such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 scores, across multiple datasets to ensure that the findings are not an artifact of a specific scenario. 

In summary, while the concept of utilizing both weakly and strongly annotated data through distillation is promising, addressing these concerns could significantly enhance the clarity and applicability of the research findings. A more thorough exploration of the theoretical underpinnings and empirical validations would offer a richer understanding of the method's potential and limitations.

Today is a glorious day. For years I have worked to prove to my Master that I am worthy of a place at his side and I believe I have finally shown him that I am worthy of his time. At first hours my master summoned me to his private chambers, but today was not another lesson in pain or even combat practice, today was to be a test. 
 
 Deep black station has been my home ever since my Master found me and took me in. I was a stray on the streets of Trinus Prime; a small rat-girl, living in the gutters with the other sweepings. He sensed me though, sensed a potential in me and picked my out of the filthy and brought my here. At first I feared that he simply wished to torture me; during pain training I felt closer to death than life for weeks at a time, but I survived and learned to hate. 
 
 This is not to be my first test. When I was still a child they began and have grown ever since. The first was an old woman, huddled in fear in the cargo bay, left for me like a Rancor might leave a wounded Koth beast for its cub. I knew what was expected of me and ripped her to pieces with my hands, fearful that at any moment I would be set upon by some worse beast. That was the first and only time I saw my Master smile, when he entered the cargo bay and found me, crouched and ready to kill, covered in blood and gore. 
 
 From there I have done as I was bidden, never questioning, never disobeying. I know I am not my Master ’ s only trainee, I have fought and killed a dozen or more, sometimes with my hands, sometimes with blasters, or blades. In the last year I have been given lightsabers for some fights and I use them and then drop them. They are not mine and these weapons hold no significance, they are only mine so long as I use them to express my masters will. 
 
 I entered his chambers and stood to the side. He has sensed me enter, he knows my every movement, my every thought in this place. This station, *The Gathering Dark* is an expression of his dark will and exists only through his power and manipulation; it is a part of him. I am used to waiting, keeping my mind neutral and letting my senses explore my surroundings, but today I do not have to wait long. He sweeps past me and with the slightest motion I know to follow; today we are going to somewhere new. 
 
 His ship, the *Vituperative* is a thing of beauty, almost out of place among his other ugly belongings, like myself. It was built long ago by a small faction in the Fondor Shipyards, hoping for a contract from smugglers that never came. How he acquired it I have never known, but I have seen it outrun or destroy ships a dozen times its size with seemingly little effort. She is sleek, a long sliver running back to two massive engines, with fins running down the side that make her twist in your vision and seem stranger than she is. This is the only thing of beauty allowed on *The Gathering*. 
 
 We leave and my master plots a course and I see we are headed to the Aleen System. I know a little of this place from my training, the air on the ground is highly poisonous, but it will not bother me. I spent much time being exposed to thousands of compounds and building up immunity to them. The air on Aleen may harm me eventually, but it would take months of exposure and until then I will be able to breath without problems. 
 
 The world though is of little importance, I recall from my lessons that it has a small population, split between the surface and the deep core and I wonder if my mission will be to destroy these people. I would welcome that mission; destruction of a civilisation is something that few can aspire to do and this would technically be two civilisations, a rare prize. 
 
 Soon we touched down on the surface of Aleen and finally my Master turned to me and signalled for me to step forward. I have not heard his voice for more than two years and for a second it surprised me, but I am careful to mask my feelings, so he senses noting. I am surprised that I now have the power to do that, but I have grown strong. 
 
 His gaze travelled over me, as if seeing me for the first time. I am dressed simply, in dark clothes and the usual hooded cloak. “ A ’ Kayi, you have done well, grown strong, passed your tests. I am pleased. Now you will finally pass a test to see if you are truly worthy of any more of my time. ” I bowed my head and waited to hear who I would be killing. 
 
 “ Bring me the two lightsabers from the two Jedi who infect this planet. ” He smiled and then hit the button and behind me I heard the door hiss open. I paused for a moment, expecting to be given a weapon of my own, but none is forthcoming and so I turned, walked to the door and stepped out onto the cold planet. 
 
 **** 
 
 This world is dusty and foul, the wind whips the irritating brown sand into my face and for a moment I allow anger to spark in my heart, but I push it down, I save it for later. Somewhere behind me I hear my Master leaving, the whine of the great engines slowly dying as he ascends into the atmosphere. 
 
 The storm rages around me and I pull material across my face to keep the dust from my mouth, but it irritates my eyes. I close them and let my senses stretch out and I feel the planet around me, feel the storm raging as the air moves and beats against the ground, wearing the rocks into dust and then throwing it against my face. I begin to walk again, but now I use the storm to guide me, to push me onwards, letting it aid me and pull me along, guiding my to what I am looking for. 
 
 There is life here, small pathetic life but still just worthy of the name. In a few short hours I arrive at one of their villages, although it is hardly worthy of the name. The Aleena, a small and pathetic species, but despite their hovels, they can prove dangerous. They are fast and can carry weapons, I will enjoy destroying them. 
 
 The storm has dissipated somewhat, but is still strong enough to keep them indoors. I sense sixteen life forms, ten in smaller hovels but six in the larger structure towards the end of the town, if it can be called that. 
 
 The first door flies off its hinges into the house with ease and I stoop to enter the small house. Three of the pathetic creatures huddle in fear at the other side of the house and I wait to see if they will attack. They do not, they are too consumed with fear and I crush their heads with the force, enjoying the crunching. Their home holds nothing of value and I want nothing so I leave without touching a thing. 
 
 My eyes are still closed, but I am enjoying this, it is like one of the simpler tasks my master would set when I was young, to travel about one of his mazes and avoid the traps with my eyes and hands bound. 
 
 The next hovel contains four and this time I simply open the door and enjoy the fear as they scrabble away from me. Interesting though, one has a gun, a crude rifle. He holds it threateningly and squeaks something at me that I ignore. I dismantle the rifle into thirty seven different parts and then whirl them around to turn the inhabitants into a find red mush. All except the owner of the rile that is, he will be my warning. I sever his spinal cord and leave him on the floor, a witness who is unable to communicate, I like that. Maybe someone will find him before the wild animals of this planet do; after a moment I leave the door open to make it interesting. 
 
 That leaves two buildings with life forms, one with three and then the one at the end with six. I am disappointed by the hovel with three; they make no effort and seem to die almost willingly. You would assume that they value their lives but they make so little effort it is hard to believe. I now approach the last building and finally I have tired of having my eyes closed, I will enjoy this last building fully. 
 
 The doors on this building are larger, it is some sort of town hall perhaps. The beings inside are gathered around a table and I first anchor them to the ground and sense as they begin to panic and squirm, trying to free themselves, unable to work out why they are suddenly stuck firm. I walk in and some primal part of their brains tells them to panic. 
 
 “ Be calm little ones. ” I demand and they relax, becoming open and calm “ I am looking for the Jedi who are on this planet. ” At the mention of Jedi I sense them become alert. They have seen them. I put more power into my words. “ ***Where are the Jedi. *** 
 
 The one who sat at the head of the table now answered in his squeaking voice. “ They are with the Kindalo! ” He pointed towards the wall where a crude map showed the local area and I pulled it to me and strode to the leader. 
 
 “ Where are they? ” I made my voice pleasant but no less demanding. He pointed with a shaking finger to what looked like a cave entrance. Good enough, the Kindalo lived under the surface, these beings were of no more use. 
 
 I reached out with the force and felt their beating hearts, thumping with terror as I pinned them down. I began to massage their hearts with the force, making them slow bit by bit, at first calming them and then as the beats dropped below the point where they normally sat they realised that something was wrong. I released them and they clutched at their chests, their lives slowly slipping away and then as I finally stopped their hearts one by one I watched them gasp their last breaths out. Hardly a challenge but there had been some small degree of fun to be had and at least I now had a location for the Jedi.

Today dawns with resplendent glory. For countless years, I have toiled to demonstrate my worthiness to my Master, and at last, I believe I have proven myself deserving of his attention. Initially, my Master summoned me to his private quarters for lessons steeped in pain and combat; however, today marks a pivotal test.

The deep, shadowy station has been my refuge ever since my Master discovered me and took me in. I was a mere waif on the streets of Trinus Prime, a small rat-girl navigating the filth with the other discarded souls. Yet he felt a spark within me, a potential he recognized, and plucked me from the grime to bring me here. In the beginning, I feared he intended only to inflict torment upon me; through weeks of brutal training, I often felt closer to death than life itself. Yet, I survived and learned to embrace the hatred that blossomed within.

This is not my first trial. They began in my childhood and have only intensified since. The first was an elderly woman cowering in fear in the cargo bay, left for me like a Rancor might leave a wounded Koth beast for its young. Understanding what was expected, I tore her apart with my bare hands, terrified that a greater beast might pounce upon me. That was the first and only moment I ever witnessed my Master smile, entering the cargo bay to find me, crouched and bloodied, poised to kill.

From that moment, I followed his commands without question, never once defying him. I am aware that I am not my Master’s sole apprentice; I have fought and slain a dozen adversaries or more, sometimes with my hands, other times wielding blasters or blades. In the past year, I have been entrusted with lightsabers for several encounters, using them only to discard them afterward. They are not mine; these weapons hold no significance beyond serving my Master’s will.

As I entered his chambers, I positioned myself at the side. He sensed my arrival, aware of every motion, every thought I harbored within this space. The station, *The Gathering Dark*, embodies his dark will, existing solely through his power and manipulation; it is an extension of him. I am accustomed to waiting, clearing my mind and allowing my senses to roam, yet today, my wait is brief. He sweeps past me, and with a subtle gesture, I know to follow; today, we venture to an unfamiliar destination.

His ship, the *Vituperative*, is a marvel, strikingly beautiful amid his other grim possessions, much like myself. Crafted long ago by a small faction at the Fondor Shipyards, it was intended for smugglers who never arrived. How he acquired it remains a mystery, yet I have witnessed it effortlessly outmaneuver or obliterate vessels many times its size. Sleek and elongated, its design features two massive engines and fins that create a mesmerizing illusion, making it appear stranger than it truly is. This ship stands as the only beauty permitted aboard *The Gathering*.

As we depart, my master charts a course, and I realize we are bound for the Aleen System. My training has imparted some knowledge about this place; the air on the surface is highly toxic, yet I remain unfazed. I have endured exposure to countless compounds, building resilience against them. Though the air of Aleen might eventually harm me, it would require months of exposure to affect me, and for now, I can breathe without hindrance.

The world itself holds little significance; I recall from my lessons that its population is sparse, divided between the surface and the depths, and I ponder if my mission entails the annihilation of these beings. I would welcome such a task; the destruction of a civilization is a rare honor, and this would represent two, a coveted prize indeed.

Soon, we touch down on Aleen's surface, and finally, my Master turns to me, signaling for me to advance. It has been over two years since I last heard his voice, and for a fleeting moment, I am taken aback. However, I adeptly conceal my emotions, ensuring he discerns nothing. I am surprised by my newfound ability to mask my feelings, but I have grown strong.

His gaze sweeps across me as if seeing me anew. Clad simply in dark attire with my customary hooded cloak, he addresses me, “A’ Kayi, you have excelled, grown powerful, and passed your tests. I am pleased. Now you will face a final trial to determine if you are truly deserving of any further investment of my time.” I bow my head, awaiting the name of my target.

“Bring me the two lightsabers from the Jedi who infest this planet.” He smiles, pressing a button that causes the door behind me to hiss open. I hesitate momentarily, expecting to be handed a weapon of my own, but none is offered. Thus, I turn, stepping out into the cold of this alien world.

***

This planet is dusty and foul, with the wind whipping irritating brown sand into my face, igniting a flicker of anger within me. I suppress it for later. Somewhere behind me, I hear my Master departing, the engines’ whine gradually fading as he ascends into the atmosphere.

The storm rages around me, and I pull material across my face to shield myself from the dust, though it still irritates my eyes. Closing them, I extend my senses, feeling the planet breathe around me, sensing the storm as it whips the air, grinding rocks into dust, only to hurl it against me. I begin to walk again, allowing the storm to guide me, propelling me forward, assisting me in my quest.

There is life here, albeit small and feeble, yet deserving of the name. In a few short hours, I arrive at one of their villages, though it barely warrants such a title. The Aleena are a pitiful species, yet despite their squalor, they can prove dangerous. Quick and armed, I anticipate relishing the destruction of them.

The storm has calmed somewhat, but it remains strong enough to keep the inhabitants indoors. I sense sixteen life forms: ten in smaller hovels and six in a larger structure toward the end of the settlement, if one could call it that.

With a swift motion, I force the first door off its hinges and stoop to enter the cramped space. Three of the wretched creatures huddle in terror at the far side, and I pause to see if they will muster the courage to fight. They do not; their fear paralyzes them, and I crush their skulls with the Force, relishing the satisfying crunch. Their dwelling holds no worth, and I leave without a second glance.

With my eyes still closed, I savor this moment, reminiscent of the simpler challenges my Master once set before me as a child—navigating his mazes with my senses bound.

The next hovel contains four inhabitants, and I simply open the door, enjoying the panic that ensues as they scramble away from me. Fascinatingly, one wields a crude rifle, brandishing it menacingly while squeaking something at me that I disregard. I dismantle the rifle into thirty-seven separate parts and then whirl them around, reducing the occupants to a fine red pulp. All save the rifle’s owner, who shall serve as a message. I sever his spinal cord, leaving him on the floor, a voiceless witness to my work. Perhaps someone will discover him before the planet’s wild beasts do; I leave the door ajar to add an element of intrigue.

That leaves two structures with life forms: one with three and the final one housing six. I am disappointed by the hovel with three; they make no effort to resist, seemingly welcoming their demise. You would think they would value their lives, yet they exhibit such little resolve that it’s hard to believe.

Now, I approach the last building, eager to shed my closed eyes and fully relish this final encounter. The doors here are larger, suggesting it may serve as a town hall. The beings within gather around a table, and I anchor them to the ground, sensing their panic as they struggle to comprehend their newfound predicament. I stride in, and some primal instinct triggers their fear.

“Be calm, little ones,” I command, and they relax, their bodies becoming pliable. “I seek the Jedi who roam this planet.” At the mention of Jedi, I sense their alertness; they have seen them. I infuse my words with power. “***Where are the Jedi?***”

The one seated at the head of the table responds with a trembling voice, “They are with the Kindalo!” He points toward a crude map upon the wall, and I draw it toward me, striding to him.

“Where are they?” I make my tone pleasant, yet it remains unyielding. He points with a shaking finger toward what appears to be a cave entrance. Satisfactory enough—the Kindalo dwell beneath the surface. These beings have served their purpose.

I reach out with the Force, feeling their pounding hearts, thundering with terror as I pin them down. Gradually, I begin to massage their hearts with the Force, slowing each beat, initially calming them, then as their rhythms descend into an abnormal state, they realize something is amiss. I release them, and they clutch at their chests as their lives slowly ebb away. In the end, I stop their hearts one by one, watching as they gasp their final breaths. Hardly a challenge, but there was a modicum of enjoyment in it, and now I possess the location of the Jedi.
