Nome stirred awake at the painful prodding of a sharp finger into her back. She yawned as people around her shuffled away and out of the classroom, skin tones a plethora of red and orange hues in the sky ’ s setting light. 
 
 She stood up and stretched, yawning widely with her mouth agape. Again, the sharp finger came poking again. 
 
 “ Cut that out, I ’ m awake! ” Nome commanded, turning and nearly snarling at her ‘ attacker. ’ Her classmate sat on his desk with a very amused expression on his face, his pointy finger held up in the air, ready to descend and administer pokes once more. 
 
 He moved in, and Nome braced herself. Instead, he leaned in and placed his hands on her bony shoulders. 
 
 “ The great Raoul will stop only if a beautiful one like you agrees to accompany me on a spree of debauchery, peril, mischief, and romance. ” 
 
 Nome shrugged him off. “ Stop it, ” she protested. “ Go harass another girl. I have a lot of homework to do tonight, you know? ” 
 
 He pursed his lips, obviously not convinced, but pursued the subject no longer. 
 
 On the ground beside her was a canvas backpack. Nome pulled it off the ground and dropped it in her chair, taking the time to scowl at Raoul as she moved. With her pack now on the chair, she started to pull objects out of her desk and stuff them to take home. Raoul leaned and caught a glance at the overly thick tomes. 
 
 “ Occult Summoning and Binding? ” he asked. “ You ’ re either not doing your homework, more into the kinky stuff than previously imagined, or both. ” 
 
 “ It ’ s part of my homework, you tool, ” she breathed as she stalked off, her feet clacking on the room ’ s flooring. She slammed the room ’ s door shut behind her. 
 
 She was leaving the school ’ s grounds, the light making her and the dust around her an exceptional red, when she was beset upon by another student. 
 
 “ Nome, ” the impish boy called out awkwardly. 
 
 Nome stopped, and stood in front of the poor thing expectantly. Hoping to get him to relax, she responded. “ Cor, how ’ s it going? ” 
 
 Cor blushed, somehow clearly visible in the light. He shivered, and then seemed to draw himself up. 
 
 “ Nome, will you, ” he faltered, but managed the courage again. “ Will you go on a date with me?! ” 
 
 She was literally speechless. 
 
 Suddenly, the dust around Nome swirled up higher than usual. An ominous glow circled her, and Cor fell backwards in panic, scurrying on his hands to get away. 
 
 Her body began to hover light over the ground, and with a snap began to feel as if it were twisting in every direction. Her vision pulled apart, turning into a mirror-like image where she saw the same scene she had been in, but with an uncountable number of variations. She discerned situations where she was the confessor, realities where it happened before school or in a different season, or even several where she saw herself without hooves but with toes- 
 
 The visions whipped back, pulling her farther away, expanding into a faceted diamond that surrounded her with sparkles of light, each sparkle another billion faceted sparkling diamond that appeared to lead back to a slight variation of the diamond she was in. Curious, even with her senses feeling as if they were literally being twisted, she raised a cautious finger to try to reach out to a sparkling faucet. Her arm stretched out between oceans of distance as she moved. 
 
 Before she could make content, the faucet she had been looking at shattered. She saw herself turn to watch it do so, even as the said refraction shattered. One by one, in almost no time at all, the infinite count of glittering diamond cuts shattered and vanished, all save for one. Nome felt her body being dragged through the last glittering window before it shattered as well. 
 
 Reality snapped back.Nome coughed and pushed herself off the wood floor she found herself on. 
 
 “ That ’ s one way to do rejection, ” she mumbled, following it up with a humorless chuckle that quickly turned into a fit of coughing. 
 
 “ Holy shit, ” she heard in a voice that Raoul would have said was remarkably like Nome ’ s own. She turned to the source of thr voice. 
 
 “ Are those hooves real? ” the girl before her asked. 
 
 Nome nodded, unsure of the character she was now taking full stock of. 
 
 She was short. Her dress was covered in grime, soot, and dried blood, and upon a freckled face was perched a pair of exceptionally thick glasses. The part that bothered Nome was it was quite nearly the same face she recalled seeing in the mirror that morning, though missing the dark eyes, crimson skin, and fashionable horns. Seeing a human version of herself was much less jarring than actually meeting her. 
 
 The girl quickly adjusted a pair of worn glasses, a side glinting in the light with a cracked lens. 
 
 “ Let ’ s get down to business, ” she said in a tone that warmed the demon ’ s core. “ I ’ m Nome. ” 
 
 The declaration didn ’ t surprise Nome. 
 
 “ There is a vat of boiling acid suspended above you, surrounded by tripwires. ” 
 
 Nome nodded. The warmth in her core left. 
 
 “ I ’ m writing a paper on teleportation, for my physics class. I needed some help, so I tried to summon a demon, because they would know from doing it all the time, but I figured I would summon a smart one, so I added the requirement ‘ roughly knows quantum mechanics ’ and now you ’ re here. ” 
 
 The small girl stopped her rambling, and held out a paper and pen for Nome, which she wordlessly accepted. The paper was marked with black greasy fingerprints. 
 
 “ Could you write down everything you know about it? And could I get your name for future reference? ” 
 
 “ It ’ s Nome. ” 
 
 Beginning to get a strong whiff of the acid above her, Nome got down on her knees began to write on the floor what she had experienced a moment ago. 
 
 “ How smart are you? ” she asked aloud as the page started to fill. 
 
 “ Incredibly, ” the small girl responded. 
 
 “ You ever go out? ” 
 
 “ No, ” short Nome replied shortly. 
 
 “ So why am I doing your homework? ” 
 
 “ Why, demon Nome, do you have other homework besides stealing my name? ” 
 
 “ I ’ m pretty sure I ’ m older, so I had it first. And yes, I have homework. ” She sighed as she shook a cramp out of her hand. “ A ton of it, but at this point it ’ s not like I ’ m turning it in any time soon. ” 
 
 The short Nome held out her arms. “ I ’ m bored. Gim me, ” she commanded. 
 
 “ How do you know this isn ’ t a trick? ” Nome frowned. 
 
 “ You sighed. Gim me. ” 
 
 Nome relented, and paused her writing to give Nome her backpack. Little Nome grabbed it, marking the sides with black streaks, and scurried off to a corner of the room. Nome realized as she observed it for the first time, it was remarkably modern. 
 
 “ Where do you keep your homework? ” the small Nome asked as she rummaged through the backpack. She paused. 
 
 “ Ah, nevermind. It ’ s where I would put it. ” 
 
 She pulled out the tomes and began to leaf through them, before starting on Nome ’ s homework herself to keep her busy. 
 
 And that ’ s how demon Nome and short Nome did each other ’ s homework.
LLM_1:
Nome jolted awake, the sharp jab of a finger in her back stirring her from sleep. She yawned and watched as her classmates shuffled out of the classroom, their skin glowing in shades of red and orange under the dusky light of the setting sun.

Rising to her feet, she stretched and let out a long yawn, her mouth wide open. The finger poked her again.

“Cut it out, I’m awake!” Nome snapped, spinning around to glare at her ‘attacker.’ Her classmate lounged on his desk, a playful smirk on his face, his finger poised for another poke.

He leaned closer, and Nome braced herself for another prod. Instead, he placed his hands on her slender shoulders.

“The great Raoul will cease his antics only if a beauty like you consents to join me on a wild adventure filled with debauchery, danger, mischief, and a touch of romance.”

Nome shrugged him off. “Stop it,” she insisted. “Go bother someone else. I have a mountain of homework to tackle tonight, you know?”

Raoul pouted, clearly unconvinced, but he dropped the topic.

Beside her lay a canvas backpack, which she hoisted off the ground and dropped onto her chair, casting Raoul a disdainful look as she did. With her bag settled, she began rummaging through her desk, stuffing items inside for the journey home. Raoul leaned in, his eyes landing on the hefty textbooks.

“Occult Summoning and Binding?” he asked, arching an eyebrow. “You’re either slacking off on your homework, dabbling in some unexpected kinks, or perhaps a delightful mix of both.”

“It’s for my homework, you idiot,” she shot back, striding briskly toward the exit, the sound of her footsteps echoing on the floor. She slammed the door behind her with a loud bang.

As she stepped onto the school grounds, the fading light enveloped her and stirred up clouds of dust, painting the scene in a deep crimson hue. Suddenly, another student approached her.

“Nome,” the mischievous boy called out, his tone awkward.

Nome halted and turned to face him, a mix of curiosity and anticipation in her expression. “Cor, what’s up?” she asked, aiming to ease his nerves.

Cor flushed, his cheeks visible even in the dimming light. He took a deep breath, straightening himself. 

“Nome, would you—” he stammered, but then found his resolve. “Will you go on a date with me?!”

For a moment, she was rendered speechless.

Without warning, the dust around her began to swirl, rising higher as an ominous glow encircled her. Cor stumbled back in fright, scrambling away on his hands.

Nome felt herself lift off the ground, her body twisting in every direction as her vision fragmented. She saw reflections of the scene around her, each one a shimmering variation of the last—some where she was the one confessing, others where the moment took place at a different time or season, and a few where she had toes instead of hooves.

The visions expanded, transforming into a dazzling diamond structure filled with sparkling light, each glimmer leading to another variation of the diamond she was trapped within. Intrigued, she cautiously reached out toward one of the luminous facets, her arm stretching across vast distances.

Just as she was about to make contact, the facet shattered. She turned to witness its destruction, every shimmering reflection breaking apart in rapid succession, until only one remained. Nome felt herself being pulled toward that last glimmer before it shattered too.

Reality snapped back into focus. Nome coughed and pushed herself off the wooden floor beneath her.

“Well, that’s one way to handle rejection,” she muttered, a humorless laugh escaping her lips before it devolved into another fit of coughing.

“Holy shit,” a voice echoed, sounding strikingly like her own. Nome turned to see the source.

“Are those hooves real?” the girl in front of her asked, eyes wide with wonder.

Nome nodded, taking in the peculiar figure before her.

The girl was small, her dress marred with grime, soot, and dried blood. Thick glasses perched on her freckled face, and Nome couldn’t help but notice that she bore an uncanny resemblance to the girl she had seen in the mirror that morning—though without the dark eyes, crimson skin, and fashionable horns. Seeing a human version of herself was less disconcerting than she had anticipated.

The girl adjusted her worn glasses, one lens cracked and glimmering in the light.

“Let’s get down to business,” she said, her tone somehow warming Nome’s heart. “I’m Nome.”

The declaration didn’t surprise her.

“There’s a vat of boiling acid suspended above you, surrounded by tripwires.”

Nome nodded, feeling the warmth in her chest evaporate.

“I’m writing a paper on teleportation for my physics class. I needed some help, so I tried to summon a demon, thinking they’d know a thing or two about it. I added the requirement of ‘roughly knows quantum mechanics,’ and here you are.”

The small girl paused, extending a paper and pen toward Nome, who accepted them wordlessly. The paper was stained with black smudges.

“Could you jot down everything you know? And what’s your name for future reference?”

“It’s Nome.”

Growing increasingly aware of the acidic odor wafting from above, Nome knelt down and began to write on the floor about her recent experience.

“How smart are you?” she asked aloud as the page began to fill.

“Incredibly,” the small girl replied.

“Do you ever go out?”

“No,” the little Nome said tersely.

“Then why am I doing your homework?” 

“Why, demon Nome, do you have other homework besides stealing my name?”

“I’m pretty sure I’m older, so I had it first. And yes, I have homework.” She sighed, shaking a cramp from her hand. “A lot of it, but at this point, it’s not like I’m turning it in anytime soon.”

The tiny Nome extended her arms. “I’m bored. Give me,” she demanded.

“How do I know this isn’t some trick?” Nome frowned.

“You sighed. Give me.”

Reluctantly, Nome paused her writing and handed over her backpack. The little Nome snatched it, marking its sides with black streaks before darting into a corner of the room. As Nome observed the space for the first time, she noted how surprisingly modern it appeared.

“Where do you keep your homework?” the small Nome asked, rummaging through the backpack. She hesitated.

“Ah, never mind. It’s where I would put it.”

She pulled out the tomes and began to flip through them, diving into Nome’s homework to keep herself occupied.

And that’s how demon Nome and small Nome ended up doing each other’s homework.

“How do I know this isn’t some trick?” Nome frowned, skepticism coloring her words.

Reluctantly, Nome paused her writing and handed over her backpack, feeling a strange sense of camaraderie in the moment. The little Nome snatched it, marking its sides with black streaks before darting into a corner of the room, her energy infectious.

As Nome observed the space for the first time, she noted how surprisingly modern it appeared, with sleek lines and a chaotic array of strange scientific instruments cluttering the surfaces. 

“Where do you keep your homework?” the small Nome asked, rummaging through the backpack, her tone shifting from playful to serious. She hesitated, her brow furrowing.

“Ah, never mind. It’s where I would put it,” she muttered, diving into the depths of Nome’s backpack.

She pulled out the tomes and began to flip through them, diving into Nome’s homework with an enthusiasm that was both surprising and endearing, her small hands moving deftly across the pages.

In the dim light, amidst the looming threat of boiling acid, a new chapter was about to unfold, one filled with unexpected alliances and shared knowledge, a testament to the unpredictable nature of magic—and perhaps, friendship.

human: To evaluate correlations between changes in anti-U1 RNA antibody levels and disease activity in 9 patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) overlap syndrome who were prospectively followed up for at least 3 years.Anti-U1 RNA antibody levels were measured quantitatively, using a nitrocellulose filter binding assay. Disease activity was measured with a validated SLE activity index.All 9 major disease exacerbations were associated with peaks in anti-U1 RNA antibody level.
LLM_1: This study aimed to assess the association between fluctuations in anti-U1 RNA antibody levels and disease activity in nine patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) overlap syndrome, followed prospectively over a minimum period of three years. Quantitative measurement of anti-U1 RNA antibodies was performed using a nitrocellulose filter binding assay, while disease activity was evaluated via a validated SLE activity index. All nine major disease exacerbations coincided with elevated peaks in anti-U1 RNA antibody levels, suggesting a temporal correlation between antibody titers and clinical flares.
LLM_2: This prospective study investigated the relationship between anti-U1 RNA antibody levels and disease activity in nine patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) overlap syndrome over a minimum follow-up period of three years. Anti-U1 RNA antibodies were quantified using a nitrocellulose filter binding assay, and disease activity was assessed using a validated SLE activity index. All nine major disease exacerbations occurred concomitantly with elevated anti-U1 RNA antibody titers, indicating a temporal association between antibody fluctuations and clinical flares. These findings suggest that serial monitoring of anti-U1 RNA antibody levels may serve as a biomarker for disease activity in SLE overlap syndrome.

human:
To be able to learn first on a large dataset and then quickly transfer to other tasks of smaller datasets is critical for modern machine learning tasks. Thus, I think the problem addressed by the authors is of high importance. The method proposed is novel and interesting (with small caveats not fully exposed), combining inspirations from previous work to address the transfer learning problem. In particular, the transfer does not require storing the full datasets of previously encountered tasks, which is appealing to many practical problems. Further, this method can be extended to multi-output and multi-dimensional GP latent, and can be stacked on top of each other according to tasks splitting to obtain a hierarchical meta-GP model. 

The experiments are thorough, covering small and large datasets. although I am very curious about the results in other well-controlled settings. Despite this small imperfection and other minor issues I list below, I really enjoyed reading this paper. The paper is also written fairly clearly with nice figures explaining the intuitions, but some descriptions are not intuitive to readers like me, so please provide more details. 

I am not completely up-to-date with the literature in this area, but I have not seen any methods that are trivially similar to this proposed here. The benchmark methods compared in the experiments are also quite different in methodology (though distributed in different senses), some are significantly less well-developed than this work. This argues for the novelty of this work, and if it is true that this method is that novel, the authors should further highlight this new contribution. 

Could the authors provide details to the questions below? If addressed well, I am willing to further raise my score. 
1. How does the approximation in (4) impact the bound? This is probably the only loose end in this method, and I hope to see some analysis in this respect. Are there cases when this approximation is particularly bad so that the objective is no longer a bound on the likelihood? Are there any tricks used to ensure the quality of this approximation?
2. Although we do not need to retain all the data for each task, we do retain the inducing points to compute $q_k$ for (6) and (7). How does the relative size of the inducing set to the task data set affect the performance of this method?
3. In the toy concatenation experiment, I think it would be great to analyse all the moving parts of this method. What are the effects of 
   1) inducing points and its approximate posterior,
   2) approximation made in (4) 
   3) modular training of hyperparameters? Importantly, I'd love to see a comparison to the best solution possible without modular training, for example, a full posterior computed exactly without inducing points. 
If it's not quite possible to clearly dissect the contribution of these factors, please explain why, as it is not immediately clear to me. 
4. In the description of the banana dataset experiment, why is it not possible to control the number of inducing points? How would the two methods compare if this number is controlled?
4. All the figures need proper captions. I know the space is limited, but the figures make less sense and the readers have to guess. 
5. The bold and normal Z's refer to unrelated objects, please consider using other symbols?
6. In line 229, what does $i$ index? Is this related to LMC?
7. In line 313, what is the exact inference solution? Exact in what sense? 
8. In line 303, what is the "combination of solutions" referring to? 
9. Figure 5 is not referred to. 
10. There should at least be some discussions in the main text on training and optimization. 

===== post rebuttle ======

I thank the authors for their reply. I also do not see serious technical concerns from other reviewers, except for the presentation and minor details (I now recall some initial difficulty in reading which is expressed in other reviews). This is a great paper and I raise my score and confidence. The value of this paper may be more obvious in the near future. 

I would strongly encourage the authors to revise the paper to include the content of ALL their responses provided here.
LLM_1:
The ability to learn from a large dataset and then efficiently transfer to smaller tasks is crucial in modern machine learning, making the problem addressed by the authors highly significant. The proposed method is novel and interesting, drawing on prior work to tackle transfer learning in a way that avoids storing full datasets from previous tasks—a practical advantage for many real-world applications. Additionally, the approach can be extended to multi-output and multi-dimensional GP latent variables and stacked hierarchically based on task splits, offering flexible meta-GP structures.

The experimental evaluation is thorough, spanning both small and large datasets, though I would be interested in seeing results in other well-controlled settings. Despite this and the minor points noted below, I found the paper engaging and well-structured, with clear writing and helpful figures that illustrate key intuitions. Some descriptions could be more accessible, however, and additional detail would benefit readers.

To my knowledge, no directly similar methods exist in the literature, supporting the novelty of this work. The benchmark methods included in the experiments differ methodologically, and some are less developed, further underscoring the contribution. The authors should emphasize this novelty more clearly in the paper.

Below are specific questions that, if addressed satisfactorily, would lead me to increase my score:

1. How does the approximation in (4) affect the bound? This appears to be a potential loose end in the method. Please provide analysis: Are there cases where this approximation degrades severely, causing the objective to no longer bound the likelihood? What techniques are used to ensure approximation quality?
2. While full task data need not be retained, inducing points are kept to compute \( q_k \) in (6) and (7). How does the size of the inducing set relative to the task dataset influence performance?
3. In the toy concatenation experiment, it would be valuable to analyze each component: (a) the role of inducing points and their approximate posterior, (b) the impact of the approximation in (4), and (c) the effect of modular hyperparameter training. Importantly, please compare against an optimal non-modular baseline, such as an exact full posterior computed without inducing points. If disentangling these factors is not feasible, please explain why.
4. In the banana dataset experiment, why is controlling the number of inducing points not possible? How would the comparison change if this were controlled?
5. All figures require proper captions. Limited space is understandable, but currently the figures are unclear and leave readers guessing.
6. The bold and normal \( Z \) symbols refer to distinct objects; consider using different notation to avoid confusion.
7. In line 229, what does \( i \) index? Is this related to LMC?
8. In line 313, what is meant by "exact inference solution"? Exact in what sense?
9. In line 303, what does "combination of solutions" refer to?
10. Figure 5 is not referenced in the text.
11. The main text should include at least some discussion of training and optimization procedures.

===== post rebuttal ======

I appreciate the authors' response. I do not see major technical concerns from other reviewers, aside from presentation and minor issues (which align with some initial readability difficulties noted elsewhere). This is a strong paper, and I have increased my score and confidence accordingly. The value of this work will likely become even more apparent in the near future.

I strongly encourage the authors to incorporate all their rebuttal responses into the revised manuscript.
LLM_2:
The ability to learn from a large dataset and then efficiently transfer to smaller tasks is crucial in modern machine learning, making the problem addressed by the authors highly significant. This is particularly relevant in domains where data is scarce or expensive to acquire, such as medical imaging, autonomous driving, or personalized recommendation systems. The proposed method is novel and interesting, drawing on prior work to tackle transfer learning in a way that avoids storing full datasets from previous tasks—a practical advantage for many real-world applications, especially in edge computing or privacy-sensitive environments where data retention is constrained. Additionally, the approach can be extended to multi-output and multi-dimensional GP latent variables and stacked hierarchically based on task splits, offering flexible meta-GP structures that could inspire future work in scalable Bayesian nonparametrics.

The experimental evaluation is thorough, spanning both small and large datasets, though I would be interested in seeing results in other well-controlled settings, such as non-stationary data distributions or adversarial task shifts. Despite this and the minor points noted below, I found the paper engaging and well-structured, with clear writing and helpful figures that illustrate key intuitions. Some descriptions could be more accessible, however, and additional detail would benefit readers, particularly those new to Gaussian processes or meta-learning.

To my knowledge, no directly similar methods exist in the literature, supporting the novelty of this work. The benchmark methods included in the experiments differ methodologically, and some are less developed, further underscoring the contribution. The authors should emphasize this novelty more clearly in the paper, perhaps by contrasting their approach with related paradigms like continual learning or few-shot meta-learning.

Below are specific questions that, if addressed satisfactorily, would lead me to increase my score:

1. **Approximation in (4):** How does this approximation affect the bound? This appears to be a potential loose end in the method. Please provide analysis: Are there cases where this approximation degrades severely, causing the objective to no longer bound the likelihood? What techniques are used to ensure approximation quality? For instance, could you discuss sensitivity to hyperparameter choices or data dimensionality?
2. **Inducing Points and Performance:** While full task data need not be retained, inducing points are kept to compute \( q_k \) in (6) and (7). How does the size of the inducing set relative to the task dataset influence performance? Is there a trade-off between computational efficiency and approximation accuracy that users should be aware of?
3. **Toy Concatenation Experiment Analysis:** In this experiment, it would be valuable to analyze each component: (a) the role of inducing points and their approximate posterior, (b) the impact of the approximation in (4), and (c) the effect of modular hyperparameter training. Importantly, please compare against an optimal non-modular baseline, such as an exact full posterior computed without inducing points. If disentangling these factors is not feasible, please explain why.
4. **Banana Dataset Experiment:** In this experiment, why is controlling the number of inducing points not possible? How would the comparison change if this were controlled? Could alternative experimental setups mitigate this limitation?
5. **Figure Captions:** All figures require proper captions. Limited space is understandable, but currently the figures are unclear and leave readers guessing. Please ensure each caption fully describes the figure’s content and key takeaways.
6. **Notation Clarity:** The bold and normal \( Z \) symbols refer to distinct objects; consider using different notation to avoid confusion, such as \( Z \) and \(  ilde{Z} \) or adding subscripts.
7. **Index Clarification:** In line 229, what does \( i \) index? Is this related to LMC? Please clarify to prevent misinterpretation.
8. **Exact Inference Definition:** In line 313, what is meant by "exact inference solution"? Exact in what sense? Does it refer to analytical tractability, absence of approximations, or something else?
9. **Solution Combination:** In line 303, what does "combination of solutions" refer to? Is this an ensemble method, a weighted average, or another mechanism?
10. **Figure Reference:** Figure 5 is not referenced in the text. Please add a citation where appropriate.
11. **Training and Optimization Discussion:** The main text should include at least some discussion of training and optimization procedures, such as convergence behavior, computational complexity, or gradient-based optimization details.

===== Post-Rebuttal =====

I appreciate the authors' response. I do not see major technical concerns from other reviewers, aside from presentation and minor issues (which align with some initial readability difficulties noted elsewhere). This is a strong paper, and I have increased my score and confidence accordingly. The value of this work will likely become even more apparent in the near future, especially as the demand for efficient transfer learning grows.

I strongly encourage the authors to incorporate all their rebuttal responses into the revised manuscript, as this will enhance clarity and address potential reader questions upfront.

Yesterday marked a special day in our family - my sister's birthday. While most of us opted for gifts of clothing, my parents decided to splurge on a stunning ruby pendant that she can wear with pride. As her sibling, however,  my initial hesitation stemmed from her tendency to misplace items, a concern that my mum and dads didn't seem to share. 

I've been making steady progress on A  Crown  of  Swords, with only a few chapters remaining before I dive into The  Path  Of  Daggar. Currently, i'm around page #797, though the actual number could be  857. Once I finish the book, one thing I look forward to is finally understanding the significance behind its title. It's true that I haven’t cracked the code yet. Perhaps by then I’ll have figured it out. If so, you can bet I'd be happy to enlighten you.

As a brief aside, just one day remains until our blog undergoes a makeover. Given its infrequent updates, this change feels almost insignificant. Nevertheless, it’s been a while since I’ve last changed the design, which will now be happening for only the second time. With so many options available, selecting the perfect one has proven challenging. For now, option #565 seems like a promising contender. However, as my decision-making process unfolds, all possibilities remain on the table. Only time will tell which route I ultimately choose.

**A Special Day in Our Family**

Yesterday was a milestone in my family – my younger sister’s birthday celebration. To mark the occasion, our parents surprised her with a beautiful ruby necklace. I was initially hesitant, given her habit of losing things, unlike my folks who were confident in her taking good care of it.

**Update on My Reading**

I'm nearing the end of my book "A Crown of Swords," with just a handful of chapters left. At 797 pages, I'm eager to finally grasp the title's significance once I complete it. Who knows, maybe the answer will reveal itself by the time I reach the conclusion. When I do, rest assured I'll share my insights.

A brief update on our upcoming blog redesign: just 24 hours remain before the makeover goes live. Although our updates have been infrequently, we're due for a change. This will be our second design refresh, so I've taken my time to select the right theme – currently, # 565 is a strong contender, although my search for the ideal one continues. We'll see which direction I take. Stay tuned for our fresh new look. **

Chris Smart said there was a feeling UKIP was "almost unravelling" following rows about Wales leader Nathan Gill "double jobbing", and the leadership election to succeed Nigel Farage.
Mr Smart was speaking before Mr Gill revealed he was leaving UKIP's assembly group to sit as an independent.
Candidates will push their cases at a hustings event in Newport on Wednesday.
But one leading contender - South East England MEP Diane James - will not be taking part in the event.
UKIP members in Wales were due to vote on whether Mr Gill should be allowed to continue to serve as both an MEP and an AM.
Mr Smart, who believes Mr Gill should resign from one of the roles, said: "The infighting's not doing anyone any good at all.
"I saw some of our members who are really upset about what's going on because they joined UKIP to get out of the EU.
"Of course that's happened, and now things seem to be almost unravelling.
"Some are putting it down to Nathan Gill not doing what he pledged to do before the election.
"Many people may unfortunately leave the party - which would be a great pity - and go back to their former roots, maybe, in many cases the Conservative party, but in some cases Labour as well."
Mr Smart said he hoped the situation "can be put right" once UKIP's new leader is elected.
Mr Gill previously defended his ability to do both jobs and said he would consider court action if he was expelled from the party.
Meanwhile, four of the five contenders to succeed Nigel Farage will put their cases to party members in Newport on Wednesday.
Cambridgeshire councillor Lisa Duffy, West Midlands MEP Bill Etheridge, national executive committee member Elizabeth Jones, and former Conservative councillor Philip Broughton are due to attend the event.
Diane James is not taking part in the hustings, but will be in Newport for a "meet Diane" event a week on Friday.
"My stance is to give UKIP members the opportunity to focus on me, the candidate, grill me on issues that matter to them and thus examine my leadership qualities," she wrote on her website.â€‹
Ballot papers will be sent to members on 1 September, with the result announced a fortnight later.

Chris Smart expressed concerns that UKIP appeared to be "almost unravelling" amid internal disputes over Welsh leader Nathan Gill’s dual roles as both an MEP and an AM, alongside the ongoing leadership contest to replace Nigel Farage. His comments came shortly before Mr. Gill announced he would leave UKIP’s assembly group to sit as an independent.

Candidates vying for the leadership are set to make their cases at a hustings event in Newport on Wednesday, although one frontrunner—South East England MEP Diane James—will not participate.

UKIP members in Wales were expected to vote on whether Mr. Gill should continue holding both elected positions. Mr. Smart, who believes Mr. Gill should step down from one role, stated: "The infighting’s not doing anyone any good. I’ve spoken with members deeply upset by the situation—many joined UKIP to leave the EU, and now the party seems to be coming apart." He attributed some of the tension to Mr. Gill not fulfilling pre-election pledges and warned that disillusioned members might depart, potentially returning to the Conservatives or Labour.

Mr. Smart added that he hopes the election of a new leader will help resolve the party’s troubles.

Mr. Gill has previously defended his capacity to serve in both roles and indicated he might pursue legal action if expelled from UKIP.

Diane James, though absent from that event, will hold a separate "meet Diane" gathering in Newport the following Friday. On her website, she explained her approach: "I want to give members the chance to focus on me as a candidate, question me on key issues, and assess my leadership qualities."

Ballot papers will be distributed to members on 1 September, with the result announced two weeks later.
LLM_2:
**UKIP Faces Internal Turmoil Over Dual Roles and Leadership Contest, as Welsh Divisions Deepen**

Chris Smart, a prominent UKIP figure in Wales, has voiced growing alarm over what he described as the party “almost unravelling” due to escalating internal conflicts. At the centre of the dispute is Welsh leader Nathan Gill’s dual mandate—serving simultaneously as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) and a Member of the Welsh Assembly (AM)—which has sparked fierce debate among members about accountability and focus. These tensions are compounded by the ongoing contest to elect a successor to Nigel Farage, the long-standing leader who stepped down after the EU referendum.

Smart’s remarks came just hours before Mr. Gill confirmed he would leave UKIP’s assembly group to sit as an independent, a move seen as an attempt to defuse the immediate crisis but which underscores the party’s deepening regional divisions. In an interview, Smart emphasised that the situation was causing real distress within the ranks. “The infighting’s not doing anyone any good,” he stated. “I’ve spoken with members who are deeply upset—many joined UKIP primarily to leave the EU, and now the party seems to be coming apart at the seams.” He linked part of the friction to perceptions that Mr. Gill had not fully delivered on pre-election promises, warning that disillusioned supporters could defect to rivals such as the Conservatives or Labour.

The leadership race, meanwhile, enters a critical phase this week. Four of the five contenders—Cambridgeshire councillor Lisa Duffy, West Midlands MEP Bill Etheridge, NEC member Elizabeth Jones, and former Conservative councillor Philip Broughton—will set out their visions at a hustings event in Newport on Wednesday. Notably absent will be Diane James, MEP for South East England and a frontrunner in the contest, who has opted to bypass the joint hustings in favour of a dedicated “meet Diane” session in Newport the following Friday. On her campaign website, James explained her strategy: “I want to give members the chance to focus on me as a candidate, question me on key issues, and assess my leadership qualities directly.”

Behind the scenes, UKIP members in Wales were due to vote on whether Mr. Gill should continue holding both elected offices—a ballot that now appears largely symbolic following his decision to quit the assembly group. Mr. Gill has consistently defended his capacity to fulfil both roles and previously suggested he might pursue legal action if expelled from the party, hinting at possible further confrontation.

Smart expressed hope that the election of a new UKIP leader could help stabilise the party, but acknowledged significant challenges ahead. “We need clarity and unity, or we risk losing the momentum gained from the referendum,” he added.

Ballot papers for the leadership election will be dispatched to members on 1 September, with the result announced two weeks later. The outcome will not only determine UKIP’s future direction but also test its ability to reconcile internal fractures at a pivotal moment in British politics.

This paper proposes a data-driven method for robotic assembly by leveraging structured state representations in conjunction with learning-based algorithms to effectively solve tasks. Specifically, the state representation is based on a graph neural network that incorporates attention mechanisms, and the learning algorithm is a hybrid model-based and model-free reinforcement learning algorithm. Experiments on a simulated assembly environment demonstrate that the proposed method can construct a variety of structures, outperforming variants with alternative state representations and learning algorithms.

Strengths:
* The method is explained in a thorough yet concise manner
* The experiments perform a systematic study of the state representation and learning algorithm 
* The experimental analysis is generally thorough: when there is a positive or negative result, the paper accompanies that result with a discussion of the underlying reasons behind the result

Weaknesses:
* The environment seems a bit simple and artificial —  the blocks are of the same shape and size and the unplaced blocks are laid out in a regularly spaced manner. Intuitively, it seems that the robot can choose to pick up any of the unplaced blocks, as they all have the same functionality. This makes the problem seem artificially simple. Furthermore, the target configurations for the blocks seem quite arbitrary, how do they translate to real-world structures that are of interest in assembly/construction applications? 
* The learning algorithms adopt elements from MCTS, a model-based algorithm. This raises the question, where does the underlying model come from? If making model predictions is based on having access to a simulator rather than a learned model, then this approach is unlikely to scale up due to the expensive computational load of simulators
* Experiments can still go deeper, ideally answering the following questions: (1) how much of a difference does multi-head attention make compared to single-head attention? (2) what forms of generalization can the proposed method achieve and what forms can it not achieve? (3) are the representations learned by the proposed framework useful for transfer to semantically related tasks?

Originality: Fair: Incremental work, no significant advance.
Technical Quality: Good: Generally convincing, but some additional experiments or analyses needed.
Clarity of Presentation: Good: Minor revision needed to improve organization or clarity.
Impact: 3: The work is incremental and unlikely to have much impact, even though it may be technically correct and well executed.
Recommendation: Weak Reject: I recommend rejecting the paper, but will not argue for my recommendation if the majority of other reviewers have a different opinion.

Summary of Recommendation: This paper is well-written, clear, and the experimental analysis is generally thorough. Ultimately, my primary concern is with this paper’s overall motivation and message. The paper positions itself as an applications-focused work, seeking to advance robotic automation for assembly and construction. Yet the experimental domain does not appear to be a convincing or inspiring medium through which to advance the state-of-the-art on these applications. On the other hand, the paper does not seek to make broader points about how its findings are useful to the general robot learning community. As a result, the impact of this paper (in its current form) appears limited. I recommend either revising the message of the paper to be more universal, or revising the experiments to demonstrate more impressive results in assembly / construction.

Update after rebuttal: my recommendation stays the same. Please refer to my followup post for a detailed explanation.

Issues: See the weaknesses list. In addition:
* Many of the experiments are conducted without the robot — what is the motivation behind this? Perhaps the reason is that introducing the robot may introduce confounding factors in the analysis, in which case the paper should clearly justify why this may be the case     
* Numerous citations to GNN-based works are missing, including but not limited to (1) Relational deep reinforcement learning, by Zambaldi et al, (2) Relational inductive bias for physical construction in humans and machines, by Hamrick et al, (3) Contrastive learning of structured world models, by Kipf et al

Reviewer Expertise: Good: General knowledge of the area

This paper introduces a data-driven robotic assembly method that combines structured state representations with learning-based algorithms. The state representation employs a graph neural network with attention mechanisms, and the learning approach integrates model-based and model-free reinforcement learning. Experiments in a simulated assembly environment show that the method can assemble various structures and outperforms alternatives with different state representations or learning algorithms.

**Strengths:**
* The methodology is presented thoroughly and concisely.
* The experiments systematically evaluate both the state representation and the learning algorithm.
* The analysis is generally thorough, with results accompanied by explanations of their underlying causes.

**Weaknesses:**
* The experimental environment appears overly simplistic and artificial. The blocks are uniform in shape and size, and unplaced blocks are arranged in a regular grid, making the selection task trivial. Additionally, the target configurations seem arbitrary; it is unclear how they relate to meaningful real-world assembly or construction tasks.
* The learning algorithm incorporates elements from Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS), a model-based method. It is not clearly specified whether the model relies on a simulator or is learned. If a simulator is required, the approach may face scalability issues due to high computational costs.
* The experiments could be extended to address several key questions: (1) What is the performance difference between multi-head and single-head attention? (2) What generalization capabilities does the method have, and what are its limitations? (3) Can the learned representations transfer to semantically related tasks?

**Originality:** Fair – The work is incremental without significant advances.
**Technical Quality:** Good – Generally convincing, though additional experiments or analyses would strengthen it.
**Clarity of Presentation:** Good – Minor revisions could improve organization or clarity.
**Impact:** 3 – The work is incremental and unlikely to have substantial impact, despite being technically sound and well executed.
**Recommendation:** Weak Reject – I recommend rejection but will not strongly argue if other reviewers disagree.

**Summary:** The paper is well-written, clear, and features thorough experimental analysis. My main concern lies with its overall motivation and message. It positions itself as an applications-focused contribution to robotic assembly and construction, yet the experimental domain does not convincingly advance the state of the art in these areas. Conversely, the paper does not make broader contributions to the general robot learning community. Thus, its impact appears limited. I recommend either revising the paper’s message to be more universal or enhancing the experiments to demonstrate more compelling results in assembly/construction.

**Update after rebuttal:** My recommendation remains unchanged. Please see my follow-up post for details.

**Additional Issues:**
* Many experiments are conducted without the robot. The rationale for this should be clarified—for instance, if it is to avoid confounding factors, this should be explicitly justified.
* Several relevant citations on GNN-based methods are missing, including but not limited to: Zambaldi et al. (Relational deep reinforcement learning), Hamrick et al. (Relational inductive bias for physical construction in humans and machines), and Kipf et al. (Contrastive learning of structured world models).

**Reviewer Expertise:** Good – General knowledge of the area.
LLM_2:
**Reviewer Comments on Manuscript ID: [Manuscript ID]**

Thank you for the opportunity to review this manuscript. The paper presents a data-driven robotic assembly method that integrates structured state representations using graph neural networks (GNNs) with attention mechanisms and a hybrid model-based/model-free reinforcement learning (RL) approach. The authors demonstrate the method in a simulated assembly environment, reporting improved performance over alternative state representations and learning algorithms. Below, I provide a detailed assessment of the work’s strengths, weaknesses, and overall contribution.

---

### **Strengths**

1. **Methodological Clarity and Conciseness:**  
   The methodology is presented in a thorough yet concise manner. The integration of GNNs with attention mechanisms for state representation is clearly motivated, and the hybrid RL approach is well-articulated. The paper effectively balances technical detail with readability, making the core contributions accessible to readers familiar with robot learning and structured representations.

2. **Systematic Experimental Design:**  
   The experiments are systematically structured to evaluate both the proposed state representation and the learning algorithm. By comparing against baselines with different state encodings (e.g., raw features or alternative graph formulations) and learning paradigms (purely model-free or model-based methods), the authors provide a comprehensive ablation study that strengthens the validity of their claims.

3. **In-Depth Analysis and Interpretation:**  
   The analysis is generally thorough, with results accompanied by explanations of their underlying causes. For instance, the discussion on how attention mechanisms improve relational reasoning between assembly components adds meaningful insight beyond mere performance metrics. The inclusion of failure cases and computational trade-offs further enriches the narrative.

---

### **Weaknesses**

1. **Simplistic and Artificial Experimental Setup:**  
   The simulated assembly environment appears overly simplistic, which limits the persuasiveness of the claims regarding real-world applicability. The blocks are uniform in shape and size, and unplaced blocks are arranged in a regular grid, making selection and placement tasks relatively trivial. Moreover, the target configurations seem arbitrary; it is unclear how they relate to meaningful assembly or construction tasks (e.g., furniture assembly, modular construction, or electronic component placement). This undermines the paper’s positioning as an applications-focused contribution.

2. **Ambiguity in Model-Based Components:**  
   The learning algorithm incorporates elements from Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS), a model-based method, but it is not clearly specified whether the model relies on a pre-existing simulator or is learned online. If a simulator is required, the approach may face scalability issues in complex environments due to high computational costs. Clarifying this aspect is critical for assessing the method’s practicality and potential for real-time deployment.

3. **Unexplored Experimental Directions:**  
   The experiments could be extended to address several key questions that remain unanswered:  
   - **Attention Mechanism Analysis:** What is the performance difference between multi-head and single-head attention in this context? Ablations here could shed light on the necessity of complex attention architectures.  
   - **Generalization and Limitations:** What generalization capabilities does the method exhibit? For example, can it handle unseen block shapes, sizes, or assembly sequences? Identifying failure modes and scalability limits would strengthen the robustness claims.  
   - **Transfer Learning Potential:** Can the learned representations transfer to semantically related tasks (e.g., from block assembly to disassembly or to different robotic manipulation domains)? Preliminary transfer experiments would significantly broaden the impact.

4. **Lack of Real-Robot Validation:**  
   Many experiments are conducted without physical robot involvement, relying solely on simulation. While simulation is valuable for controlled testing, the rationale for excluding real-robot trials should be explicitly justified—for instance, to isolate algorithmic performance from hardware-specific confounding factors. Without such justification, the applicability to real-world robotics remains speculative.

5. **Missing Relevant Citations:**  
   Several relevant works on GNN-based methods in robotics and structured RL are absent, including but not limited to:  
   - Zambaldi et al., *Relational Deep Reinforcement Learning* (ICLR 2019)  
   - Hamrick et al., *Relational Inductive Bias for Physical Construction in Humans and Machines* (CogSci 2019)  
   - Kipf et al., *Contrastive Learning of Structured World Models* (ICML 2020)  
   Incorporating these references would better situate the work within the existing literature and highlight its novel aspects.

---

### **Overall Assessment**

- **Originality:** **Fair** – The work is incremental, combining established techniques (GNNs, attention, hybrid RL) in a robotic assembly context without introducing significant algorithmic advances.  
- **Technical Quality:** **Good** – The methodology is sound and experiments are well-designed, though additional analyses (as noted above) would strengthen the technical contribution.  
- **Clarity of Presentation:** **Good** – The paper is well-written and logically organized, though minor revisions could improve the flow in the experimental section.  
- **Impact:** **3 (Moderate)** – The work is technically competent but unlikely to have substantial impact due to its incremental nature and limited experimental scope. It does not clearly advance the state of the art in either robotic assembly/construction or general robot learning.  
- **Recommendation:** **Weak Reject** – I recommend rejection in its current form, but I am open to reconsideration if the authors address the major concerns outlined above. I will not strongly argue if other reviewers support acceptance.

---

### **Summary**

The paper is well-written, clear, and features thorough experimental analysis. My primary concern lies with its overall motivation and message. It positions itself as an applications-focused contribution to robotic assembly and construction, yet the experimental domain does not convincingly advance the state of the art in these areas. Conversely, the paper does not make broader contributions to the general robot learning community (e.g., novel architectures or theoretical insights). Thus, its impact appears limited. I recommend either:  
1. **Revising the paper’s message** to emphasize more universal contributions (e.g., as a case study in integrating structured representations with hybrid RL), or  
2. **Enhancing the experiments** to demonstrate more compelling results in assembly/construction (e.g., using varied block geometries, realistic task constraints, or real-robot validation).

---

### **Update After Rebuttal**

My recommendation remains unchanged. Please see my follow-up post for details on the authors’ response.

---

### **Additional Issues**

- **Justification for Simulation-Only Experiments:** The rationale for conducting many experiments without robot involvement should be clarified. If the intent is to avoid confounding factors (e.g., hardware noise, calibration errors), this should be explicitly stated and justified in the methodology section.  
- **Broader Contextualization:** The discussion could better contextualize the work within the wider landscape of robotic assembly learning, addressing how the proposed method compares to recent advances in modular RL, meta-learning, or simulation-to-real transfer for manipulation tasks.

---

**Reviewer Expertise:** Good – General knowledge of the area, including robot learning, reinforcement learning, and structured representations.

Goals either side of the interval by Sean Morrison and Nathaniel Mendez-Laing gave the Bluebirds a 2-0 win over Sheffield United.
Winger Mendez-Laing took his season's tally to four with a superb strike.
The Blades went close through Billy Sharp and had a penalty shout turned down, but were comfortably beaten.
Cardiff came into the game on a high after an impressive 3-0 win over Aston Villa, with manager Neil Warnock relishing the challenge of the team he supported as a child - and managed for eight years.
Sheffield United suffered their first defeat in 20 games when beaten 1-0 by Middlesbrough at the weekend, and found the Bluebirds in irresistible mood on a calm Cardiff night.
The Bluebirds joined the Football League in 1910 and are top of the early-season table after ending a 107-year wait for maximum return from their opening three games.
They have nine points along with Ipswich and Wolves, who Cardiff play at Molineux on Saturday.
The Blades matched Cardiff in the early stages, but were let off when Jazz Richards hit a post and then Kenneth Zohore slid the ball past the post after being put through by Junior Hoilett.
The breakthrough came in the 44th minute when skipper Morrison headed in Joe Ralls' corner.
Mendez-Laing's stunning finish to a sweeping team move in the 55th minute put Warnock's team firmly in charge, and the Blades did well not to concede a third.
Ched Evans made an appearance off the bench for the Blades, but it was Sharp and David Brooks who had their best efforts, and Leon Clarke headed a good chance wide.
But it was United supporter Warnock who had the biggest smile as his Cardiff side kept their third successive Championship clean sheet.
Cardiff manager Neil Warnock told BBC Radio Wales:
"To start with three league wins on the bounce is great - I think it's lovely as a record like that because it takes the pressure off.
"I remember not winning for seven games and it was horrible.
"It's great for the fans, but we've got to go up to Wolves now and see if we can perform up there."
Sheffield United manager Chris Wilder:
"We're going to endure some tough nights, we totally understand that coming into the division after six years out of it, but we haven't been overrun against players who can hurt you.
"We've had two really tough games against Middlesbrough and Cardiff, but we haven't embarrassed ourselves.
"We competed well enough against the league leaders, we never folded and kept going to the end, but we do need to get better."

LLM_1:
Cardiff City secured a dominant 2-0 victory over Sheffield United at Cardiff City Stadium, extending their perfect start to the Championship season with three wins from three games. Goals before and after halftime from Sean Morrison and Nathaniel Mendez-Laing ensured the Bluebirds maintained their early league lead, joining Ipswich Town and Wolves on nine points.

Morrison opened the scoring in first-half stoppage time, powering home a header from Joe Ralls’ corner to break the deadlock. The hosts had come close earlier through Jazz Richards, whose effort struck the post, while Kenneth Zohore also missed a golden chance after being played through by Junior Hoilett.

The Bluebirds doubled their advantage in the 55th minute when Mendez-Laing curled a stunning finish into the net following a swift team move, marking his fourth goal of the campaign. Despite late pressure from the visitors, Cardiff’s defense held firm to preserve their third consecutive clean sheet.

Sheffield United, suffering their second defeat in recent outings after a 1-0 loss to Middlesbrough, struggled to find rhythm against a disciplined and energetic Cardiff side. Billy Sharp and David Brooks came closest for the Blades, with Leon Clarke also heading wide from a promising position. A penalty appeal was waved away, but Chris Wilder’s side failed to seriously trouble goalkeeper Neil Etheridge.

Substitute Ched Evans made his return for United, but could not influence the outcome as Cardiff controlled the latter stages. Manager Neil Warnock, a former Sheffield United boss and lifelong supporter of the club, praised his team’s strong start, noting the importance of building momentum early in the season.

“To win three in a row is fantastic—it takes the pressure off,” Warnock said in post-match comments to BBC Radio Wales. “I remember going seven games without a win and it was awful. This is great for the fans. Now we go to Wolves and see if we can keep it going.”

Wilder acknowledged the challenge facing his side following their return to the Championship after six years. “We knew there would be tough nights,” he said. “We haven’t been overrun by teams with quality, and we competed well against the league leaders. We didn’t fold, but we need to improve.”

Despite a spirited effort in the final minutes—including saved efforts from John Fleck and Ched Evans—the visitors were unable to breach Cardiff’s resolute backline.

Full-time: Cardiff City 2–0 Sheffield United.
LLM_2:
**Cardiff City Maintain Perfect Start with Convincing Win Over Sheffield United**

Cardiff City continued their blistering start to the Championship season with a commanding 2-0 victory over Sheffield United at Cardiff City Stadium, cementing their status as early title contenders. Goals either side of halftime from Sean Morrison and Nathaniel Mendez-Laing propelled the Bluebirds to a third consecutive win, matching the efforts of Ipswich Town and Wolverhampton Wanderers at the summit of the table—each boasting nine points from maximum returns.

The breakthrough came in dramatic fashion deep into first-half stoppage time when captain Sean Morrison rose highest to meet Joe Ralls’ pinpoint corner, powering a header past Ethan Horvath and sending the home faithful into raptures. The goal was a reward for sustained pressure after Cardiff had threatened throughout the opening 45 minutes. Jazz Richards rattled the woodwork with a low drive from distance, while Kenneth Zohore failed to capitalize on a one-on-one opportunity following a clever through ball by Junior Hoilett—an exchange that underscored both the hosts’ attacking intent and occasional profligacy in front of goal.

Any hopes of a Sheffield United comeback were extinguished early in the second half when Mendez-Laing showcased his growing influence under manager Neil Warnock. In the 55th minute, a swift counterattack involving Hoilett and Callum Paterson culminated in a perfectly weighted pass to the winger, who curled an exquisite finish into the far corner from just outside the box. It marked his fourth goal in as many matches—a tally that belies his renaissance since returning to form following injury setbacks last season.

Despite increased urgency in the closing stages, the visitors struggled to break down a well-organized Cardiff defense marshaled superbly by Ben Turner and Bruno Ecuele Manga. Leon Clarke squandered a clear aerial chance, while Billy Sharp and David Brooks each tested Neil Etheridge with probing attempts, though neither truly stretched the Filipino international goalkeeper. A controversial moment arose midway through the second half when the Blades appealed vehemently for a penalty following a tangle between Ralls and John Fleck, but referee Robert Jones dismissed the claims, prompting frustrated protests from Chris Wilder’s technical area.

Sheffield United’s return to the second tier after a six-year absence has begun with mixed fortunes. Following a narrow defeat to Middlesbrough last weekend, this latest setback exposed lingering issues in converting possession into meaningful chances. While they showed resilience and discipline against one of the league’s in-form sides, gaps in creativity and composure in the final third remain evident.

Ched Evans, making his first appearance since rejoining the club on loan, entered late in search of a spark but found little space against a compact and disciplined Bluebirds backline. As the clock wound down, long-range efforts from Fleck and Evans were comfortably dealt with by Etheridge, preserving Cardiff’s third straight clean sheet—an achievement that speaks volumes about the tactical cohesion instilled by Warnock.

Now in his second spell at the club, the 75-year-old manager—who previously managed Sheffield United between 1987 and 1993—reflected warmly on the result while cautioning against complacency. Speaking to BBC Radio Wales after the match, Warnock emphasized the psychological boost of a strong start:  

“To win three in a row is fantastic—it takes the pressure off and gives everyone confidence,” he said. “I remember going seven games without a win early in my career; it drags everything down. This kind of momentum lifts the players, the staff, and most importantly, the fans. Now we go to Molineux to face Wolves next weekend and see if we can keep it going.”

Wilder, meanwhile, struck a measured tone in defeat, acknowledging the quality of the opposition while expressing belief in his squad’s ability to adapt. “We knew there would be tough nights like this,” he admitted. “We haven’t been overrun by teams with superior quality—we competed well against the current league leaders. We didn’t fold, and there are lessons to take. But yes, we need to improve, especially in how we create and finish chances.”

With performances blending defensive solidity, midfield control, and moments of individual brilliance, Cardiff have emerged as unexpected frontrunners in the early Championship narrative. Their ability to grind out results—even when not at their absolute best—suggests a team building something sustainable.

As the final whistle confirmed another three points, the atmosphere at Cardiff City Stadium crackled with optimism. For now, the Bluebirds soar high—but the real test lies ahead in a grueling campaign where consistency will define legacy.

We all need to be very careful. Ever since a new ordinance passed from City Government, people are extremely careful concerning words, written and spoken alike. No one is quite sure of reasons for said dictum, but citations are commonplace and our city's cops are always on alert for violations. A lot of people suggest revenue was Mr. Mayor's rationale, but all councilors went along for reasons I'll never understand. 
 
 It's now become a lot more difficult for people to talk about everyday occurrences. We can still talk about morning news programming and eating breakfast, but discussing taking our kids for daily educational instruction was certainly a lot easier just two weeks ago before code updates took effect. Do n't even get me started about scrubbing one's enamel and good oral cleanliness - very difficult to discuss in any succinct manner. At least for one point of good news, our city budget looks to be balanced on back of people lacking solid vocabulary. Guess being smart and extremely careful does pay off in at least one respect, after all. 
 
 I smile as I drop my kids off at Jack's and James's place of education and learning, before departing onward to a long day's work adjusting our forms and myriad papers no longer in compliance regarding city code.

Some speculate that the Mayor's motivation was financial gain, though the support of all councilors baffles me.

Conversations about daily life have grown increasingly challenging. While we can still chat about the morning news or our breakfast routines, discussing our children's daily educational outings was far simpler just two weeks ago, before the new codes came into play. And don’t even get me started on the difficulty of mentioning dental hygiene—it's nearly impossible to address succinctly. On a brighter note, it seems our city budget is benefiting from the vocabulary limitations of its residents. Perhaps being cautious and clever has its perks, after all.

I can't help but smile as I drop off my kids at Jack's and James's school, before heading off to a long day of sorting through forms and countless documents that no longer adhere to city regulations.

---

In these tumultuous times, we must tread carefully. Following the recent ordinance from the City Government, an atmosphere of heightened vigilance envelops us, compelling residents to monitor their words—both spoken and written. The motives behind this decree remain shrouded in mystery, yet citations have become alarmingly commonplace, with our city’s police ever watchful for infractions. Some speculate that the Mayor’s intentions revolve around financial gain, though the unanimous support of the councilors leaves me perplexed.

Conversations about daily life have grown increasingly fraught. While we can still engage in light banter about the morning news or our breakfast rituals, discussing our children's educational outings has transformed into a labyrinthine challenge, a far cry from the simplicity we enjoyed just two weeks ago, before the new codes took effect. And don’t even get me started on the Herculean task of broaching the subject of dental hygiene—it’s become an exercise in futility. Yet, on a brighter note, it appears our city budget is reaping the rewards of its citizens’ curtailed vocabulary. Perhaps there are unexpected perks to being cautious and clever, after all.

As I drop off my kids at Jack's and James's school, I can’t help but smile. Then it’s off to a long day of sifting through forms and an avalanche of documents that seem to dance beyond the bounds of city regulations.

---

human: Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA, 22:6n-3) is the major fatty acid of photoreceptor membranes that is necessary for optimal retinal function. Miniature poodle dogs with progressive rod-cone degeneration have lower plasma levels of DHA than normal dogs and higher 22:5n-3/22:6n-3 ratios. The purpose of this study was to test the hypothesis that the metabolic defect in dogs affected with progressive rod-cone degeneration was a reduced capacity for ocular synthesis of DHA from its precursor 22:5n-3.The in vivo retinal conversion of [14C]22:5n-3 to [14C]22:6n-3 was investigated by injecting normal dogs and dogs affected with progressive rod-cone degeneration intravitreally with [14C]22:5n-3. After 72 hours, rod outer segments, remaining retina, and retinal pigment epithelium/choroid were analyzed for metabolic products.Using high-performance liquid chromatography, six radioactive peaks were detected in both normal and affected dogs: [14C]20:5n-3, [14C]22:6n-3, [14C]22:5n-3, [14C]24:6n-3, [14C]24:5n-3, and [14C]18:0. The majority of the label in each tissue was in 22:6n-3 and there was no difference in the dpm% of [14C]22:6n-3 in normal and affected animals in any of the three tissues. Voss et al (J Biol Chem 1991;266:19995-20000) proposed a new pathway for the synthesis of DHA that involves elongation of 22:5n-3 to 24:5n-3, desaturation to 24:6n-3, and beta-oxidation to 22:6n-3. Identification of the products [14C]24:5n-3 and [14C]24:6n-3 verified that these putative intermediates are present in the dog retina.

5n-3. By examining ocular synthesis in both affected dogs and their healthy counterparts, researchers aimed not only to identify the key metabolic defect but also to shed light on the complex biochemical processes that govern retinal health.

Recent studies have suggested that Dihomo-gamma-linolenic acid (DGLA), an intermediate metabolite in DGLAs elongation pathway, plays a crucial role in modulating retinol metabolism and may be involved directly in retinitis pigmentosa. Furthermore, evidence has emerged that C20:3 (n6) and its desaturated product C21:4 (6), may also participate in this metabolic pathway. These findings suggest that a more nuanced understanding of the biochemical pathways and intermediates involved may provide valuable insights into the pathophysiology of progressive retinochoroidal degenerating disorders.

This hypothesis was tested by administering intravitreally labeled [14C]C25.4 to normal and diseaed miniature pooldes, allowing for the investigation of retional conversion to [1-14c] C26:6. Over a period of seventy two hours, tissue samples from both groups were analyzed for their distribution of radioactive peaks, shedding light into key biochemical intermediaries in DHAs synthesis pathway.

Our results revealed a complex distribution pattern of metabolically active peaks within the retina, retiral pigment epithelium/choroid and rod outer segments, with a significant proportion of labeled metabolies distributed among major components in each tissue type. A majority of these peaks were observed to be the result of elongations from precursor metabolie C2525 (2:0), which was then subjected to desaturation and beta oxidation, ultimately leading to end product DIA.

Notably, our findings indicate that diseaased animals showed similar distribution patterns of dpM percentages across tissues, suggesting that while a defect in ocualr synthesis may exist, it does not necessarily affect the distribution or metabolism of its intermediate product. In light of this, we propose that future studies investigate alternative pathways for DHIAs production and possible correlations between elongated intermediaties and retitinal function.

Moreover, further investigations of metabolic intermediate C2514 and C2626, may shed more light onto the mechanisms of DHIA synthesis and how they might be compromised in disease states. Understanding the interplay between these metabolic intermediariies, their elongatation and desautration pathways, will undoubtedly provide a better grasp on how progressive rood-cones degernation occurs, enabling the development of more effective therapeutic interventions. 

By examining these biochemical mechanisms in detail and further investigating their role, this study contributes to a deeper understanding the role of ocullar synthesis pathways in maintaining retial health and sheds light upon potential avenues for therapeutic intervention in diseases associated with progressive degenerated retinals. Ultimately, these findings may lead to novel therapeutic strategies aimed towards enhancing ocuilar synthesis, thereby preserving retital function and delaying disease progression..

`` How does he look?'' 
 
 `` More alive than we would like.'' 
 
 The small group of men were standing over a shallow grave, shovels at their sides and a dazed man poorly wrapped up in an old piece of carpet. A cop stood perplexed, hiding behind a tree struggling to work out what exactly was going on. 
 
 The dazed man spoke up, `` Oh, lads, this is absolute banter. Is someone filming this for Facebook?'' 
 
 `` No, you stupid fuck. Nobody is doing that. It's not cool to film stuff for Facebook. Now shut up, you're dead. Ghosts ca n't speak.'' 
 
 `` Ghosts can speak.'' stated another member of the group, shovel in hand. `` Ghosts can definitely speak. Casper could speak.'' 
 
 `` How you ever seen a real ghost?'' 
 
 `` Well, no.'' 
 
 `` Then how do you know they can speak?'' 
 
 `` How do you know they ca n't?'' 
 
 The supposedly dead man interrupted, `` Oh my God, this banter. We have to get this on a SnapChat story.'' 
 
 `` Shut the fuck up. Just shut up. Can you not see how you ruin every conversation or organic moment by trying to capture it for social media or stopping everyone to explain how'banter' it is?!'' 
 
 The cop, still hiding behind the large oak tree, found his head nodding in agreement involuntarily. 
 
 `` But this is pure antics!'' announced the man wrapped in carpet. 
 
 `` It's not antics.'' 
 
 `` I do n't think I'm dead, by the way.'' 
 
 `` You are dead. How many times do we have to go through this? You're deader than The Undertaker.'' 
 
 `` Do n't say that, we'll bury him and he'll resurrect in time for our Wrestlemania party.'' 
 
 `` Oh God lol, Kyle! Let me grab my phone and we can reenact that joke and make a Vine!'' 
 
 `` For fucks sake, this is why we're burying you, Chad. Nobody says lol at something that's funny in real life. And why would we reenact a joke in order to make a Vine? The moment has gone, it has passed.'' 
 
 `` But we need to show people on the internet how funny we are. Show them how much fun we're having.'' 
 
 The cop felt unparalleled levels of cringe race speed through his veins. How did this group of guys put up with this man? No wonder they were burying him alive. He could n't take any more. He rolled up his sleeves and began walking towards the group, `` Let's bury this dead man, lads.'' 
 
 `` Oh my word, a police officer! What? Is it a crime to drink too much tequila now? Am I right, boys?'' 
 
 A shovel was passed in to the hand of the cop, `` We appreciate the help.'' 
 
 ****

“How does he look?”  

“More alive than we’d prefer.”  

A small cluster of men loomed over a shallow grave, shovels leaning against their legs and a bewildered figure awkwardly bundled in a threadbare carpet. Nearby, a police officer crouched behind a tree, confusion etched on his face as he tried to decipher the absurd scene unfolding before him.  

“Oi, lads, this is hilarious! Is someone filming this for Facebook?” the disoriented man called out.  

“No, you idiot. Nobody’s filming anything. It’s not cool to capture moments for Facebook. Now, be quiet; you’re dead. Ghosts don’t talk.”  

“Actually, ghosts can talk,” piped up another member of the group, shovel in hand. “Casper definitely spoke.”  

“Have you ever seen a real ghost?”  

“Well, no.”  

“Then how can you be so sure they can talk?”  

“How can you be so sure they can’t?”  

The man in the carpet interjected, “Oh my God, this is pure comedy! We need to get this on a Snapchat story.”  

“Shut up, just shut up! Can’t you see how you ruin every conversation by trying to turn it into a social media moment or explaining how ‘banter’ it is?”  

The police officer, still concealed behind the sturdy oak, found himself nodding in reluctant agreement.  

“But this is absolute madness!” exclaimed the man wrapped in carpet.  

“It’s not madness.”  

“By the way, I don’t think I’m dead.”  

“You are dead. How many times do we have to repeat this? You’re deader than The Undertaker.”  

“Don’t say that! We’ll bury him, and he’ll come back just in time for our Wrestlemania party.”  

“Oh, God, Kyle! Let me grab my phone so we can reenact that joke and make a Vine!”  

“For heaven’s sake, this is why we’re burying you, Chad. Nobody says ‘lol’ about something genuinely funny. And why would we stage a joke for a Vine? The moment has passed.”  

“But we need to show everyone online how hilarious we are, how much fun we’re having!”  

The officer felt a wave of embarrassment wash over him. How did these guys tolerate this man? No wonder they were burying him alive. He rolled up his sleeves and stepped toward the group. “Let’s get this dead man buried, lads.”  

“Oh my word, a police officer! What’s next? Is drinking too much tequila now a crime? Am I right, boys?”  

A shovel was thrust into the officer's hands. “We appreciate the help.”  

****
