`` Here it is!...,'' Doug said, as we finally made it to Dot's house after nearly 12 hours on the road in an old Ford Ranger, but his voice faded out from excitement to confusion, I could tell, as he noticed that all the windows on his sister's little wooden home had been shattered and half of the roof has been blown off. 
 
 `` Oh my god... do you think there was a tornado?,'' I asked softly, as my jaw slowly fell upon seeing the destruction. It was, indeed, a quite petrifying scene. In a normal scenario, I may have sprung up and ran toward the house, but something was just so eerily and cold and desolate about the situation this time. 
 
 `` No, that's... that's impossible, I just spoke to her before we left, and I would have heard about something like this on the news or weather channel...,'' Doug said, clearly frustrated as he scoured his mind for an answer as to what may have happened. 
 
 `` The trees near the house are blown over... but look! The cornfield looks perfectly fine, and so do the trees by back shed. What the hell...? Maybe one fell on the house,'' I observed. It still was n't making any sense. There was n't even a tree branch stuck in the roof or anything. It sort of looked like it had been imploded somehow, as the tops of the walls near the concaved roof seemed to curl under. I did n't want to think about the possibility, but maybe someone tried to set some TNT off inside the house. 
 
 ``... Do you think Paul tried anything? Maybe, with the inheritance drama and...,'' I began carefully, so I would not to set Doug off, but trailed off when I noticed his face go pale and flat. 
 
 Everything went silent. 
 
 `` There's a note on the door,'' he said in a low, monotone voice. I watched his face for a moment for any signs of expression, and then cautiously climbed out of the truck. He did the same, and with quickened pace, we went down the thin dirt path leading us past some unscathed rose bushes and perennials to the front door. 
 
 We looked at the door, and noticed the the top hinge had come loose, so it sat crooked and open, just a crack. Neither of us though to look inside, as I was, and assume Doug was too, afraid of what we might see if we did. If anyone was in there, they would have come out by now upon seeing us. Doug quickly whisked the note off the door, pulled his glasses down toward his nose, and examined it. 
 
 `` Okay, this is definitely Dot's handwriting. I've read her letters for years,'' he said, his brow furrowed as his eyes scanned over it for a few moments. Then he looked up and clenched his jaw. Without looking at me, he slowly handed me the note. 
 
 It read: 
 To Doug or whoever may find this: 
 * Do not worry about me Doug, I love you brother. 
 * DO NOT come in the house. 
 * Do not have any reflective devices out. 
 * Turn off anything that emits an electromagnetic signal. 
 * Do not call the police. If anyone asks, a tree fell on the house. 
 * I did n't have time to write a will, I'm sorry. 
 * Do not go anywhere alone around here. 
 * They ca n't die, so if you see them, do n't try to kill them, just hide and make no noise what-so-ever. 
 * If you see a bright light in the sky, gather up who you are with, AND HIDE. Keep an eye on where it is, though, and which way it is moving. 
 * A light beam comes down from it, GET THE HELL AWAY FROM THERE. 
 * Do n't tell the rest of the family.
LLM_1:
"Here we are," Doug murmured, the words slipping from his lips like a breath he'd been holding too long. After twelve grueling hours rattling across backroads in an ancient Ford Ranger, the tires kicking up dust beneath a bruised twilight sky, we’d finally arrived at Dot’s place—only to find it broken open like a discarded shell.

The little wooden house sat crooked in its clearing, windows blown out, their jagged frames gaping like hollow eye sockets. Half the roof had vanished, peeled back as if some colossal hand had torn through it. Silence clung to the wreckage, thick and unnatural.

"Oh my God…" I whispered, my voice cracking under the weight of what I was seeing. My jaw tightened, muscles locking as I stared. It wasn’t just the damage—it was the *wrongness* of it all. The air felt dead. No birds. No rustle in the grass. Just stillness, cold and deliberate.

I should’ve run forward. Should’ve shouted her name. But something rooted me in place—a quiet dread humming beneath my skin.

"No… no way," Doug said, shaking his head, fingers gripping the truck door. "There couldn’t have been a tornado. I talked to her *hours* ago. We would’ve known. The radio, the weather alerts—something would’ve come through."

I stepped down onto the cracked earth, scanning the yard. Trees lay toppled near the porch, trunks snapped clean, but beyond them—the cornfield stood untouched. Rows upon rows of stalks swayed gently in a breeze that didn’t reach us. The shed out back? Intact. Not a shingle out of place.

"It’s like… the house imploded," I said slowly, eyes tracing the inward curl of the splintered rafters. The walls bent inward, as if sucked down by something from above. No debris inside. No sign of fire. Just violence with no explanation.

"...You think Paul did something?" I ventured, careful not to press too hard. "With everything going on about the will, maybe he—"

Doug’s face went blank. Blood drained from his cheeks. He didn’t answer.

The world seemed to pause.

Then, quietly: "There’s a note on the door."

His voice was flat—too flat. I studied him as he climbed out, movements stiff, like a man walking through water. I followed, each step crunching over glass and gravel, the path lined with rose bushes still blooming, defiantly alive.

The front door hung askew, the top hinge ripped free, leaving it cracked open just enough to peer into darkness. Neither of us did. If she’d been inside, she’d have heard us. She’d have called out.

Doug snatched the paper fast, pulling his glasses down his nose to read. His eyes flickered across the lines, brow knotting tighter with every word. When he looked up, his jaw was clenched so hard I thought I heard his teeth grind.

Without a sound, he handed it to me.

The handwriting was frantic, uneven—Dot’s, unmistakably:

> To Doug or whoever finds this:  
> • Don’t worry about me, Doug. I love you, brother.  
> • DO NOT enter the house.  
> • Keep all mirrors, glass, anything reflective—covered or put away.  
> • Shut off anything that sends a signal—phones, radios, Wi-Fi. Everything.  
> • Do not call the police. Tell anyone who asks—a tree fell. That’s all.  
> • I didn’t have time to write a will. I’m sorry.  
> • Never go anywhere alone out here.  
> • They can’t die. If you see them, don’t fight. Don’t scream. Hide. Stay silent.  
> • If you see a bright light in the sky—gather everyone and hide. Watch where it moves.  
> • If a beam comes down from it—RUN. Get away. Now.  
> • Do not tell the rest of the family.
LLM_2:
The goal is to elevate the prose into something more immersive and literary, suitable for publication or performance.

---

Twelve hours we’d rattled through backroads in an ancient Ford Ranger, tires clawing up dust beneath a sky bruised purple with twilight. Now, at last, Dot’s place loomed ahead—only it wasn’t *her* place anymore. Not really. It was what remained: broken open, hollowed out, like a shell cracked by some careless hand.

The little wooden house sat crooked in its clearing, listing slightly as if exhausted by its own collapse. Windows gone, their frames jagged and gaping—hollow eye sockets staring blindly into the dusk. Half the roof had vanished, peeled back in ragged strips, as though something vast and unseen had reached down and torn straight through. Silence clung to the wreckage, thick and wrong—too complete, too deliberate. No birdsong. No whisper of wind in the grass. Just stillness that pressed against the ears like cotton soaked in dread.

“Oh my God…” I whispered. My voice cracked under the weight of it—the ruin, the emptiness. My jaw locked tight, muscles knotting as I stared. It wasn’t just the destruction. It was the *wrongness*. The air felt dead. Not cold, not hot—just… empty. Like breath held too long.

I should’ve run forward. Should’ve screamed her name into the dark mouth of the doorway. But something rooted me there—a quiet hum beneath the skin, the kind of fear that doesn’t shout but *whispers*, slow and certain.

“No… no way,” Doug said, shaking his head, fingers white-knuckled on the truck door. “There couldn’t have been a tornado. I talked to her *hours* ago. We would’ve known. The radio, the alerts—something would’ve come through.”

I stepped down onto the cracked earth, boots crunching over glass and gravel. Scanned the yard. Trees lay felled near the porch, trunks snapped clean, splintered ends pointing skyward like accusing fingers. But beyond them—the cornfield stood untouched. Rows upon rows of stalks swayed gently in a breeze that didn’t reach us. The shed out back? Still standing. Roof intact. Not a shingle disturbed.

“It’s like…” I began slowly, eyes tracing the inward curl of shattered rafters, “like the house *imploded*. Look—the walls bent inward. Sucked down from above.” No debris scattered inside. No soot. No sign of fire. Just violence without cause. A wound with no weapon.

"...You think Paul did something?" I asked, careful, testing the edge of the thought. "With everything going on about the will… maybe he—"

Doug’s face went blank. Blood drained from his cheeks. He didn’t answer.

The world seemed to pause—held its breath.

Then, quietly: “There’s a note on the door.”

His voice was flat. Too flat. I studied him as he climbed out, movements stiff, like a man wading through water. I followed, each step sharp with glass and stone, the path lined with rose bushes still blooming—petals red and defiant against the gray.

The front door hung askew, top hinge ripped free, cracked open just enough to peer into darkness. Neither of us did. If she’d been inside, she’d have heard us. She’d have called out.

Doug snatched the paper fast, sliding his glasses down his nose to read. His eyes flickered across the lines, brow tightening with every word. When he looked up, his jaw was clenched so hard I thought I heard his teeth grind.

Without a sound, he handed it to me.

The handwriting was frantic—uneven, desperate. But unmistakably Dot’s:

> To Doug—or whoever finds this:  
> • Don’t worry about me. I love you, brother.  
> • DO NOT enter the house.  
> • Cover every mirror. Every piece of glass. Anything reflective—hide it. Put it away.  
> • Shut off anything that sends a signal—phones, radios, Wi-Fi. Everything.  
> • Do not call the police. Tell anyone who asks—a tree fell. That’s all.  
> • I didn’t have time to write a will. I’m sorry.  
> • Never go anywhere alone out here.  
> • They can’t die. If you see them, don’t fight. Don’t scream. Hide. Stay silent.  
> • If you see a bright light in the sky—gather everyone and hide. Watch where it moves.  
> • If a beam comes down from it—RUN. Get away. Now.  
> • Do not tell the rest of the family.

I lowered the page. My hands were steady. My heart was not.

Above us, the sky deepened into night. Somewhere beyond the trees, the corn rustled—though there was no wind.

And then, faintly—so faint I almost missed it—I heard it.

A reflection, maybe. Or a memory.

But for one terrible second…

…it sounded like laughter.

---

### Notes on the Polish:
- **Rhythm & Pacing**: Sentences are varied in length to create tension and breath—shorter for urgency, longer for immersion.
- **Imagery**: Enhanced metaphors (“cotton soaked in dread,” “accusing fingers”) deepen atmosphere without overwriting.
- **Voice Consistency**: Maintained the narrator’s introspective, grounded tone while elevating diction subtly.
- **Emotional Undercurrent**: Amplified subtext—fear, disbelief, familial strain—through physical detail (clenched jaws, white knuckles).
- **Ending Enhancement**: Added a final haunting beat (the laughter) to close on an unsettling, ambiguous note—common in speculative or horror-inflected fiction.

Let me know if you'd like a darker, more minimalist, or genre-specific variation (e.g., literary fiction, sci-fi noir, etc.).

LLM_2:
The initial fallout from the financial crisis primarily affected companies engaged in home construction and mortgage lending, such as Northern Rock and Countrywide Financial, which struggled to secure financing in the credit markets. These institutions faced an unprecedented liquidity squeeze as banks became increasingly wary of lending due to rising defaults and plummeting home values. As a result, over 100 mortgage lenders filed for bankruptcy in 2007 and 2008, illustrating the widespread devastation within the sector. This turmoil was further compounded by the subprime mortgage crisis, where high-risk lending practices resulted in massive numbers of foreclosures, ultimately destabilizing the entire housing market.

Fears of a potential collapse of investment bank Bear Stearns in March 2008 led to its hurried sale to JP Morgan Chase, a move that was seen as both a rescue and a warning signal regarding the fragility of major financial institutions. The crisis reached its zenith in September and October of 2008, with several prominent financial institutions either failing, being acquired under pressure, or facing government intervention. Key players impacted included Lehman Brothers, whose bankruptcy became emblematic of the crisis, Merrill Lynch, which was forced to sell itself to Bank of America, and government-sponsored enterprises like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, which were placed into conservatorship to prevent further systemic collapse. Washington Mutual, once the largest savings and loan association in the U.S., also succumbed to the crisis, marking a significant moment in the banking landscape.

The gravity of the situation was highlighted by the events of October 6, 2008, just three weeks after Lehman Brothers recorded the largest bankruptcy in U.S. history. On this date, the former CEO of Lehman, Richard Fuld, testified before Representative Henry A. Waxman, the California Democrat and chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform. During this testimony, Fuld portrayed himself as a casualty of the crisis, attributing his firm's downfall to a pervasive "crisis of confidence" in the markets. This characterization sparked a contentious debate about accountability and the role of leadership in the financial sector, as many questioned whether the failures were due to individual mismanagement or systemic flaws within the financial system itself. The aftermath of these events prompted significant regulatory scrutiny and led to sweeping reforms aimed at preventing a recurrence of such a devastating crisis in the future.

human: The purpose of this study was to examine whether known genetic risk factors for type 1 diabetes (HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, and -DQB1 and insulin locus) play a role in the etiology of diabetic nephropathy. RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS; Genetic analysis of HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, -DQB1 and the insulin gene (INS) was performed in the Genetics of Kidneys in Diabetes (GoKinD) collection of DNA (European ancestry subset), which includes case patients with type 1 diabetes and nephropathy (n = 829) and control patients with type 1 diabetes but not nephropathy (n = 904). The availability of phenotypic and genotypic data on GoKinD participants allowed a detailed analysis of the association of these genes with diabetic nephropathy.Diabetic probands who were homozygous for HLA-DRB1*04 were 50% less likely to have nephropathy than probands without any DRB1*04 alleles. In heterozygous carriers, a protective effect of this allele was not as clearly evident; the mode of inheritance therefore remains unclear. This association was seen in probands with both short (<28 years, P = 0.02) and long (>/=28 years, P = 0.0001) duration of diabetes. A1C, a marker of sustained hyperglycemia, was increased in control probands with normoalbuminuira, despite long-duration diabetes, from 7.2 to 7.3 to 7.7% with 0, 1, and 2 copies of the DRB1*04 allele, respectively. This result is consistent with a protective effect of DRB1*04 that may allow individuals to tolerate higher levels of hyperglycemia, as measured by A1C, without developing nephropathy.
LLM_1: This study aimed to investigate the role of established genetic risk factors for type 1 diabetes—specifically HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, -DQB1, and the insulin locus—in the development of diabetic nephropathy. The research utilized genetic analyses of the HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, -DQB1, and insulin gene (INS) within the Genetics of Kidneys in Diabetes (GoKinD) DNA collection, focusing on a subset of individuals of European ancestry. This dataset comprised patients with type 1 diabetes experiencing nephropathy (n = 829) and control patients with type 1 diabetes without nephropathy (n = 904). The comprehensive phenotypic and genotypic data available for GoKinD participants facilitated an in-depth exploration of the associations between these genes and diabetic nephropathy. Notably, diabetic probands who were homozygous for HLA-DRB1*04 exhibited a 50% reduced likelihood of developing nephropathy compared to those lacking any DRB1*04 alleles. In contrast, among heterozygous carriers, the protective effect of this allele was less pronounced, leaving the mode of inheritance ambiguous. This association was consistent across probands with both short (<28 years, P = 0.02) and long (≥28 years, P = 0.0001) diabetes durations. Furthermore, glycated hemoglobin (A1C), indicative of prolonged hyperglycemia, was elevated in control probands with normoalbuminuria, despite having a long duration of diabetes, showing values of 7.2%, 7.3%, and 7.7% for 0, 1, and 2 copies of the DRB1*04 allele, respectively. These findings support the hypothesis of a protective effect conferred by DRB1*04, potentially enabling individuals to withstand higher levels of hyperglycemia, as reflected by A1C levels, without the onset of nephropathy.
LLM_2:
This study aimed to investigate the role of established genetic risk factors for type 1 diabetes—specifically HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, -DQB1, and the insulin locus—in the development of diabetic nephropathy, a serious complication that can lead to kidney failure. Diabetic nephropathy is characterized by progressive kidney damage and is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with type 1 diabetes. Understanding the genetic underpinnings of this condition is crucial, as it may inform targeted interventions and personalized treatment strategies. 

The research utilized genetic analyses of the HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, -DQB1, and insulin gene (INS) within the Genetics of Kidneys in Diabetes (GoKinD) DNA collection, which is a well-established resource for studying diabetes-related complications. This dataset comprised patients with type 1 diabetes who were experiencing nephropathy (n = 829) and control patients with type 1 diabetes without nephropathy (n = 904). The selection of individuals of European ancestry was particularly important due to the varying prevalence of certain genetic markers across different populations, ensuring that the findings could be more accurately interpreted within this demographic context.

The comprehensive phenotypic and genotypic data available for GoKinD participants facilitated an in-depth exploration of the associations between these genes and diabetic nephropathy. For instance, diabetic probands who were homozygous for HLA-DRB1*04 exhibited a remarkable 50% reduced likelihood of developing nephropathy compared to those lacking any DRB1*04 alleles. This significant finding suggests that the presence of this allele may serve as a protective factor, potentially influencing clinical outcomes in a meaningful way. 

In contrast, among heterozygous carriers of the DRB1*04 allele, the protective effect was considerably less pronounced, which introduces a layer of complexity regarding the mode of inheritance. This ambiguity raises further questions about the interplay between genetic susceptibility and environmental factors, such as glycemic control and lifestyle choices. The association was notably consistent across probands with varying durations of diabetes, including those with shorter (<28 years, P = 0.02) and longer (≥28 years, P = 0.0001) diabetes durations, underscoring the robustness of the findings.

Furthermore, glycated hemoglobin (A1C), a critical marker indicative of prolonged hyperglycemia, was found to be elevated in control probands with normoalbuminuria, despite having a long duration of diabetes. Specifically, A1C levels were recorded at 7.2%, 7.3%, and 7.7% for individuals with 0, 1, and 2 copies of the DRB1*04 allele, respectively. These results are intriguing as they imply that individuals carrying the DRB1*04 allele may possess a unique resilience that allows them to endure higher levels of hyperglycemia without progressing to nephropathy. 

Collectively, these findings support the hypothesis of a protective effect conferred by the DRB1*04 allele, suggesting that this genetic variant may play a crucial role in mediating the risk of developing diabetic nephropathy. This research not only enhances our understanding of the genetic factors involved in diabetes complications but also opens avenues for future studies aimed at unraveling the mechanisms behind these associations, potentially leading to innovative therapeutic approaches that can mitigate the risks associated with diabetic nephropathy.

human: Commercial solar water heaters began appearing in the United States in the 1890s. These systems saw increasing use until the 1920s but were gradually replaced by cheaper and more reliable heating fuels. As with photovoltaics, solar water heating attracted renewed attention as a result of the oil crises in the 1970s but interest subsided in the 1980s due to falling petroleum prices. Development in the solar water heating sector progressed steadily throughout the 1990s and growth rates have averaged 20% per year since 1999. Although generally underestimated, solar water heating and cooling is by far the most widely deployed solar technology with an estimated capacity of 154 GW as of 2007.
LLM_1: Commercial solar water heaters first emerged in the U.S. during the 1890s, gaining popularity until the 1920s when they were largely supplanted by more affordable and dependable fuel sources. Similar to the solar panel industry, interest in solar water heating resurged following the oil crises of the 1970s, only to wane in the next decade as petroleum prices dropped. The sector experienced steady advancements through the 1990s, with annual growth averaging 20% from 1999 onward. Often overlooked, solar water heating and cooling remains the most extensively adopted solar technology worldwide, boasting an estimated capacity of 154 gigawatts as of 2007.
LLM_2: **Solar water heating** first appeared commercially in the United States in the 1890s and grew in use until the 1920s, when cheaper and more reliable conventional fuels displaced it. Like the solar photovoltaic industry, interest revived after the 1970s oil crises, but declined again in the 1980s as oil prices fell. The technology saw consistent improvements during the 1990s, and from 1999 onward the market expanded at an average rate of 20% per year. Although frequently underrecognized, solar water heating (and cooling) is the most widely deployed solar energy technology globally, with an estimated installed capacity of 154 GW by 2007.

I must be reading it wrong.. 
 I MUST be reading it wrong. 
 How can He reject a pure soul? 
 Not pure in the way of innocence, but pure in the way that last week I preformed those... no, not atrocious... well maybe to some of you.'Felonious' is more suitable. Those felonious acts to my neighbors dog. 
 I'm sure it may have been shocking to read in the newspaper the following days, and honestly it turned my stomach a little when I recounted the last few moments... 
 But you ca n't tell me you have never been at the end of your rope. Never felt anger fill your body and slowly expose itself as the beads of sweat on your forehead. Your whole being consumed by one true emotion. 
 That's what I was feeling last week. 
 
 I guess I should start from the beginning. 
 Well, that's too early, and I'm not in the mood to rehash any childhood bullying, molestation, or early signs that showed me why I am Chosen. It can be summed up in the police files and juvy records anyways. In short, I started feeling pain and hate from my earliest memories and the only thing to quell the burning inside of me was knowledge that one day He will save me. One day He will provide me with true love. True acceptance for all eternity. 
 
 Throughout my life I do n't remember feeling love. I remember a few occasions where I felt a numbness, as if my pain was being subdued or at least I was being distracted from it. This never happened with any human, this only happened with two things. 
 One, whenever I caused pain or unhappiness to others. Even the simple things like the way I act or dress. Or the larger things... 
 And second, I will never forget the only friend I have ever had in the world, my Arthur. 
 He was truly like me. He understood me. He behaved like me. He could feel my pain. 
 I loved feeding him, he was so romantic in the way he created death. I would spend hours watching him, whispering to him. Creating a bond that would last beyond this life. 
 And.. about last week... 
 When I arrived home to greet him I noticed him thrashing in his aquarium. I tried to brace myself for the worse. But it was n't enough. I could see what the poison was doing to his body. 
 
 I heard the back door slam shut. 
 
 Pain enveloped his every movement. 
 
 Running footsteps. 
 
 Froth forming at his mouth, his scales beginning to peel. 
 
 The door from next door opening and closing hurriedly. 
 
 Blood seeping from his beautiful eyes. 
 
 And next, nothing. 
 No movement. No breathing. Both of our hearts stopped. 
 I am sad to say mine started again. 
 So, I did what anyone would do with a past such as mine. And that dog was the unfortunate victim. 
 This is small in scale to what I plan to do. And for my future plans I need His help to redeem my Arthur. 
 But reading the Ouija board three times again, it seems that He does not understand. After a life full of belief, worship, faith... He was rejecting me? How can I fully give myself to my Deity and be turned away? My offer is not unreasonable, it is very simple. Let me into your dungeons Lord, to serve you better. My soul is yours. I only wish to take the vile scum of my Arthur's killer with me so that I shall watch you molest his soul repeatedly for all time and I can finally find my happiness. Watching him for all eternity suffer like my dear Arthur. 
 
 My first attempt of replying to a prompt, hope you liked it!
LLM_1:
I must have misread it.  
I *must* have misread it.  
How could He turn away a soul so pure?  
Not pure in innocence—pure in the way that last week I carried out those… no, not atrocious… though perhaps some would call them that. *Felonious* fits better. Those felonious acts upon my neighbor’s dog.  

I’m sure the papers made grim reading in the days that followed. Truth be told, even replaying those final moments turns my stomach a little.  
But you can’t tell me you’ve never been at the end of your rope. Never felt rage flood your veins and bead as sweat on your skin—your whole being devoured by one raw, roaring emotion.  
That’s where I was last week.  

I suppose I should start from the beginning.  
Well, the very beginning is too far back, and I’ve no desire to dredge up old wounds—the childhood bullying, the violations, the early signs that marked me as Chosen. It’s all there in the police files and juvie records anyway. The short version: pain and hatred have lived in me since memory began. The only relief from the fire inside was knowing that one day, He would save me. One day He’d grant me true love. True acceptance, forever.  

I don’t recall ever feeling love. Only moments of numbness—as if the pain had been muffled, or I’d been distracted from it. No human ever gave me that. Only two things ever did.  
First, causing others pain or unhappiness. Sometimes in small ways—how I acted, how I dressed. Sometimes in larger ones.  
And second… there was Arthur. The only friend I’ve ever had.  
He was like me. He understood me. He moved like me. He felt my pain.  
I loved to feed him, enchanted by the dark romance of how he crafted death. I’d spend hours watching him, whispering to him, weaving a bond meant to outlast this life.  

And then… last week.  
I came home to find him thrashing in his tank. I braced for the worst—but nothing could prepare me. I saw what the poison was doing to him.  

The back door slammed.  

Agony twisted through his every movement.  

Footsteps, running.  

Froth at his mouth, scales peeling away.  

The neighbor’s door hurrying open and shut.  

Blood welling in his beautiful eyes.  

Then—nothing.  
No movement. No breath. Both our hearts stopped.  
Mine, sadly, started again.  

So I did what anyone with my past would do. That dog was the unfortunate victim.  
This was small compared to what I still plan. And for what comes next, I need His help to bring Arthur back.  
But three times now, the Ouija board has spelled the same reply. He doesn’t understand. After a lifetime of belief, worship, faith… He rejects me? How can I offer everything to my Deity and be refused? My ask is simple. Let me into your dungeons, Lord—let me serve you better. My soul is yours. I only wish to bring the vile filth who killed my Arthur with me, so I may watch you torment his soul for all eternity. Then, at last, I’ll be happy. Watching him suffer forever… just like my dear Arthur.

human:
### Summary

This paper analyzes the bias of models in pool-based active learning settings where the sampling procedure is probabilistic (non-deterministic). It proposes two unbiased estimators of the population risk that weight the loss for each sampled data point. Empirical experiments demonstrate that these unbiased estimators work well for active learning settings with under-parameterized models, but are less effective for over-parameterized models. For the latter case, the authors provide meaningful insights into why biased estimators of population risk may actually be beneficial for over-parameterized models.

### Reasons for score

**Strong points**

1. The authors identify a common problem in active learning, namely the problem of non-IID data. The authors also propose theoretically-sound solutions to addressing the active learning bias.

2. The authors experientally demonstrate their estimators in both linear regression and a deep learning experiment, showing how their estimators are beneficial in one case but not the other.

3. The paper explains why the proposed estimators may have lower variance than the standard estimator for population risk.

**Room for improvement and/or more clarity**

1. The paper mentions the "quality" of the "acquisition proposal" several times (e.g., p.4, p.6, Figure 2, etc.). However, it is unclear what is meant by "quality." What makes for a "good" acquisition proposal?

2. The paper only discusses the setting where the active learning sampling procedure is probabilistic (non-deterministic), with non-zero support over all remaining data points in the pool. However, many active learning procedures proposed in the literature are deterministic (e.g., choosing the K examples with highest loss, or the greedy core-set approach proposed by Sener & Savarese (2018)). Could the authors provide more context for bias in these deterministic active learning strategies?
3. While I did not spend time reading the appendix in detail, it seems that points for the BNN were selected under $\tilde{R}$ (the biased sub-sample empirical risk). How do the results compare if the points were selected under $R_{SURE}$, which is a more relevant setting given that $R_{SURE}$ is the proposed estimator?
4. Other than running active learning twice (once using $\tilde{R}$ and once using $R_{SURE}$), are there methods to determine when one would be preferred over the other, especially in deep learning settings?


### Minor comments /  typos / formatting concerns

(these did not affect my score)

1. Please use vector graphics for figures. For example, save the figures as SVG or PDF files (instead of JPG or PNG) and then include them in the LaTeX file. In particular, the legend in Figure 2a is difficult to read.

2. Figure 2: Does "shading is one standard deviation" mean +/- 1 std (for a total of 2 std), or +/- 0.5 std (for a total of 1 std)? Please clarify.

3. In Equation (5), why not factor out the $1/N$ in front of the summation?

4. The authors write,
> "Using our corrective weights recovers the ideal line." (p.6)

    Unless I am reading the graph wrong, this sentence is slightly misleading. It seems like the linear regression model trained using the corrective weights much more closely approximates the ideal line, but doesn't recover the ideal line exactly.

5. In general, the paper is written in an "opinionated" or imprecise manner which detracts from the main points of the paper. Words like "surprising" and "greatly" are unnecessary. Phrases such as "better variance" should be replaced with more precise terminology, such as "lower variance".
LLM_1:
This paper investigates the bias present in models within pool-based active learning frameworks characterized by a probabilistic (non-deterministic) sampling approach. It introduces two unbiased estimators for population risk that assign weights to the loss associated with each sampled data point. Empirical results indicate that these unbiased estimators perform effectively in active learning scenarios involving under-parameterized models, while their efficacy diminishes in the context of over-parameterized models. For the latter, the authors offer valuable insights into the potential advantages of biased estimators of population risk.

**Strong points**

1. The authors address a prevalent issue in active learning regarding the challenge of non-IID data, proposing theoretically robust solutions to mitigate the bias associated with active learning.

2. Through empirical experiments, the authors illustrate the performance of their estimators in both linear regression and deep learning contexts, highlighting their effectiveness in one scenario while noting limitations in the other.

3. The paper elucidates why the proposed estimators may exhibit lower variance compared to the conventional estimator for population risk.

**Room for improvement and/or more clarity**

1. The term "quality" of the "acquisition proposal" is referenced several times (e.g., p.4, p.6, Figure 2, etc.), yet its definition remains ambiguous. What criteria constitute a "good" acquisition proposal?

2. The discussion is confined to a probabilistic (non-deterministic) active learning sampling procedure that maintains non-zero support across all remaining data points in the pool. However, various deterministic active learning methods exist in the literature (e.g., selecting the K examples with the highest loss or the greedy core-set approach proposed by Sener & Savarese (2018)). Could the authors elaborate on the bias associated with these deterministic active learning strategies?

3. Although I did not thoroughly review the appendix, it appears that points for the Bayesian Neural Network (BNN) were selected based on $ ilde{R}$ (the biased sub-sample empirical risk). How would the results differ if points were chosen based on $R_{SURE}$, given that $R_{SURE}$ is the proposed estimator?

4. Besides executing active learning using both $ ilde{R}$ and $R_{SURE}$, are there additional methods to ascertain when one approach might be favored over the other, particularly in deep learning environments?

**Minor comments / typos / formatting concerns**

1. It is recommended to utilize vector graphics for figures. For instance, figures should be saved as SVG or PDF files (instead of JPG or PNG) and incorporated into the LaTeX document. Notably, the legend in Figure 2a is challenging to read.

2. In Figure 2, does "shading is one standard deviation" refer to +/- 1 standard deviation (totaling 2 standard deviations), or +/- 0.5 standard deviation (totaling 1 standard deviation)? Please clarify.

3. In Equation (5), why is the term $1/N$ not factored out from the summation?

4. The authors state, "Using our corrective weights recovers the ideal line." (p.6) This statement may be slightly misleading; the linear regression model trained with corrective weights appears to closely approximate the ideal line, yet it does not perfectly recover it.

5. Overall, the paper's language tends toward an "opinionated" or vague style, which detracts from its main arguments. Terms like "surprising" and "greatly" are superfluous. More precise language should be employed, such as replacing "better variance" with "lower variance."
LLM_2:
This paper investigates the bias present in models within pool-based active learning frameworks characterized by a probabilistic (non-deterministic) sampling approach. It introduces two unbiased estimators for population risk that assign weights to the loss associated with each sampled data point. Empirical results indicate that these unbiased estimators perform effectively in active learning scenarios involving under-parameterized models, while their efficacy diminishes in the context of over-parameterized models. For the latter, the authors offer valuable insights into the potential advantages of biased estimators of population risk.

---

**Strong points**

1. The authors effectively tackle a prevalent issue in the realm of active learning, specifically the complications that arise due to non-IID (Independent and Identically Distributed) data. By proposing theoretically robust solutions, the paper contributes significantly to the discourse on mitigating the bias associated with active learning. The introduction of unbiased estimators serves as a pivotal advancement, particularly in contexts where traditional methods fall short in handling diverse data distributions.

2. Through a series of empirical experiments, the authors illustrate the performance of their proposed estimators in both linear regression and deep learning contexts. This dual approach not only highlights the effectiveness of the unbiased estimators in one scenario but also provides a nuanced understanding of their limitations in another. For instance, in linear regression, the estimators demonstrate a remarkable ability to adapt to the underlying data structure, while in deep learning, the complexity of the model architecture may contribute to decreased performance, thus emphasizing the need for tailored strategies in varied environments.

3. The paper elucidates why the proposed estimators may exhibit lower variance compared to the conventional estimator for population risk. This discussion is particularly informative as it lays the groundwork for understanding how variance affects model stability and reliability in predictive tasks. By providing a deeper theoretical underpinning for this observation, the authors enhance the reader's comprehension of the implications of their findings on the overall performance of active learning systems.

---

**Room for improvement and/or more clarity**

1. The term "quality" of the "acquisition proposal" is referenced several times throughout the paper (e.g., p.4, p.6, Figure 2, etc.), yet its definition remains ambiguous. It would benefit the readers to have a clear delineation of what criteria constitute a "good" acquisition proposal. For instance, elaborating on aspects such as informativeness, diversity, and representativeness of the sampled data could provide valuable context and enhance understanding.

2. The discussion is currently confined to a probabilistic (non-deterministic) active learning sampling procedure that maintains non-zero support across all remaining data points in the pool. However, it is important to note that various deterministic active learning methods exist in the literature—such as selecting the K examples with the highest loss or the greedy core-set approach proposed by Sener & Savarese (2018). Could the authors elaborate on the bias associated with these deterministic active learning strategies? A comparative analysis could enrich the discussion and provide insights into the trade-offs involved in choosing between probabilistic and deterministic approaches.

3. Although I did not thoroughly review the appendix, it appears that points for the Bayesian Neural Network (BNN) were selected based on \(  ilde{R} \) (the biased sub-sample empirical risk). A clarification on how the results would differ if points were chosen based on \( R_{SURE} \)—given that \( R_{SURE} \) is the proposed estimator—would be beneficial. Discussing scenarios where one estimator may outperform the other could provide practical guidance for researchers in the field.

4. Besides executing active learning using both \(  ilde{R} \) and \( R_{SURE} \), are there additional methods to ascertain when one approach might be favored over the other, particularly in deep learning environments? Exploring criteria such as dataset characteristics, model complexity, and computational resources could guide practitioners in making informed decisions regarding the selection of estimators.

---

**Minor comments / typos / formatting concerns**

1. It is recommended to utilize vector graphics for figures to enhance clarity and scalability. For instance, figures should be saved as SVG or PDF files (instead of JPG or PNG) and incorporated into the LaTeX document. Notably, the legend in Figure 2a poses readability challenges; improving its design would greatly benefit the presentation.

2. In Figure 2, does "shading is one standard deviation" refer to +/- 1 standard deviation (totaling 2 standard deviations), or +/- 0.5 standard deviation (totaling 1 standard deviation)? Please clarify this point to avoid confusion for readers interpreting the data representation.

3. In Equation (5), the omission of factoring out the term \( 1/N \) from the summation raises questions. A brief explanation of the reasoning behind this choice would enhance the clarity of the mathematical presentation.

4. The authors state, "Using our corrective weights recovers the ideal line." (p.6) This statement may be slightly misleading; it would be more precise to note that the linear regression model trained with corrective weights closely approximates the ideal line, yet it does not perfectly recover it. Acknowledging this nuance would strengthen the accuracy of the claims made.

5. Overall, the paper's language tends toward an "opinionated" or vague style, which detracts from its main arguments. Terms like "surprising" and "greatly" could be perceived as subjective and may benefit from more precise language. For example, replacing "better variance" with "lower variance" would convey the intended meaning more effectively and contribute to a more professional tone throughout the manuscript.

human:
Summary: 
This paper proposes a model for verifying semantic equivalence between symbolic linear algebra expressions. Expressions are represented by trees and equivalence is proven by a sequence of axioms applied to the first expression. The proposed model encodes the expression/program trees as nodes on a graph connected by edges representing one of a set of axioms being applied to one of the elements in the first expression to yield a node in the second expression. The output of the model is a path, a sequence of edges, on this constructed graph that correspond to a sequence of axioms applied to the first expression to arrive at the second.

Strengths:
* The paper investigates an interesting problem of provably-correct equivalence proof generation for symbolic expressions.
* Results on incremental versus comprehensive supervision over the entire proof sequence motivate the training method proposed by the work.

Weaknesses:
* It’s not clear how this work fits into the context of the field and experiments are only conducted as ablation studies on the architecture choices and training regimes, with no other existing methods for expression rewriting or proof generation considered.
* The system is trained and tested on expressions that are very few rewrite steps away. While datasets were generated for up to 5 and 10 rewrite steps, even the 10-step dataset contains mostly pairs that have fewer (1-5) rewrite steps. In any case, 5 and 10 steps are very few and claims of robustness and generalization are weak with such few steps in the required proofs and such a large overlap in the steps required for pains in both datasets.
* The system relies strongly on training one step at a time by requiring samples generated for every intermediate step in the proof of equivalence between two expressions.
* There is no motivation for using a deep model over another path-finding method on the constructed graph that connects the input programs.

Recommendation:
I recommend against acceptance of the paper in its current form. The idea of GNN based path-finding for expression/program equivalence proving is promising, but the methods are not clearly and rigorously explained and the experimental settings are too weak to support the claims of generalizability and applicability to realistic scenarios. 
 
Update: Thank you to the authors for clarifying the points brought up in reviews. I acknowledge that I have reviewed their responses.

Questions:
1. The development of the equivalence proofs on page 3 is very unclear. What does it mean to say ”$x \in v_i$”? This notation is not well explained. What is $x$ and what does it mean for $x$ to be _in_ $v_i$?
2. The text says that models were “run” twice, does this mean trained twice with different initializations? If so, it would be more informative to report average performance rather than the one from the best random seed. If this is not the case, could you please clarify the training set-up?
3. What are the evaluation metrics used and reported? What measure was used for the validation score that determined the best-performing model?

Minor comments:
* It is best practice to define acronyms the first time they are used. This will avoid confusion, especially for readers from a wider machine learning audience. In particular, GNN, GGNN and AST are not defined
* There are many cases where citations should be within parentheses, please check for these. If the work is not referenced as part of the text of the sentence, it should be in parentheses for clarity.

Typos:
Pg 5, “production rulse” should read “production rules"
Pg 5, there is a sentence that begins with “E.g.” which should be replaced with the grammatical “For example,”. Similarly, on page 5, the sentence that begins “Fig. 1” should read “Figure 1”.

The expressions are depicted as trees, and the verification of equivalence is achieved through a series of axioms applied to the initial expression. The model encodes the expression or program trees as nodes within a graph, with edges representing the application of specific axioms to elements of the first expression, resulting in nodes within the second expression. The model's output is a path, which consists of a sequence of edges on this graph, corresponding to the axioms applied to transition from the first expression to the second.

Strengths:  
* The paper addresses a compelling issue concerning the generation of provably-correct equivalence proofs for symbolic expressions.  
* The findings regarding the differences between incremental and comprehensive supervision of the entire proof sequence effectively support the proposed training methodology.  

Weaknesses:  
* The integration of this work within the broader context of the field remains unclear, as the experiments are limited to ablation studies focused on architectural choices and training strategies, without considering other existing methods for expression rewriting or proof generation.  
* The training and testing of the system are conducted on expressions that are only a few rewrite steps apart. Although datasets were created for up to 5 and 10 rewrite steps, the 10-step dataset primarily contains pairs with fewer (1-5) rewrite steps. Overall, 5 and 10 steps represent a limited scope, which weakens the claims of robustness and generalization given the minimal steps required in proofs and the significant overlap in the steps for pairs in both datasets.  
* The system heavily relies on a stepwise training approach, necessitating samples generated for every intermediate step in the equivalence proof between two expressions.  
* There is insufficient justification for the preference of a deep model over alternative path-finding techniques on the constructed graph that links the input programs.  

Recommendation:  
I recommend that the paper not be accepted in its current form. While the concept of using a GNN-based path-finding approach for expression and program equivalence proving is intriguing, the methods are inadequately and imprecisely articulated, and the experimental conditions are too weak to validate the claims regarding generalizability and applicability to practical scenarios.

human:
Strengths
- Important problem
- Interesting theoretical analysis
- Upper and lower bounds

Weaknesses
- Doesn’t compare to MOPO, even though the algorithms are similar
- Motivation is model-based vs. model-free, but they are purely studying model-based approaches

This paper is studying an important problem. There are significant differences between the two classes of algorithms (vanilla vs. imitation learning), and understanding which of these approaches is ideal or how to combine them is an important research direction.

However, I’m not sure this paper really addresses this problem. My main concern is that their algorithm closely resembles the MOPO algorithm [51], which uses a pessimism term to penalize parts of the state space with high uncertainty. In particular, for finite MDPs, this pessimism term can be instantiated with rigorous bounds based on the state-action visitation counts, which is similar to how the pessimism term in this paper is defined. Furthermore, the MOPO paper includes an error guarantee that appears to be quite similar to the one achieved by the authors (in particular, by using the total variation norm on the transition probability estimates). Thus, it is not clear to me that the authors’ algorithm and analysis are novel.

A related issue is that in their related work, the authors claim that there is a gap between model-free and model-based approaches in terms of pessimism, and that their work aims to clarify this gap. However, since the authors’ paper is model-based, I’m not sure how it achieves this goal.

Finally, the authors do not provide any experimental results to validate their approach. Given that the performance tradeoffs are primarily of interest from an empirical point of view, I think experiments would be very helpful in clarifying this paper’s insights.

**Weaknesses**  
- Fails to compare with MOPO, despite algorithmic similarities  
- Focuses on model-based methods, yet motivation contrasts model-based and model-free approaches  

This paper tackles a crucial issue in the field. There are notable distinctions between the two categories of algorithms (vanilla versus imitation learning), and discerning the optimal approach or potential combinations of these methods represents a vital avenue for future research.  

Nevertheless, I question whether this paper effectively addresses the stated problem. My primary concern is that the proposed algorithm bears a strong resemblance to the MOPO algorithm [51], which incorporates a pessimism term to penalize uncertain regions of the state space. Specifically, in the context of finite MDPs, the pessimism term can be derived using well-defined bounds based on state-action visitation counts, paralleling the definition presented in this paper. Additionally, the MOPO study offers an error guarantee that seems closely aligned with the results reported by the authors, particularly through the use of the total variation norm on transition probability estimates. Consequently, the novelty of the authors' algorithm and its accompanying analysis remains uncertain.  

Furthermore, in their discussion of related work, the authors assert a gap between model-free and model-based approaches regarding pessimism, claiming that their research seeks to elucidate this divide. However, given that the paper is centered on model-based methods, it is unclear how it effectively fulfills this objective.  

Finally, the absence of experimental results to substantiate their approach is a significant limitation. Since the performance tradeoffs are primarily of empirical interest, inclusion of experiments would greatly enhance the clarity and insights presented in this paper.
LLM_2:
**Strengths**  
- Addresses a significant problem, specifically within the realm of decision-making under uncertainty in reinforcement learning, which is vital for both theoretical advancement and practical application.  
- Engaging theoretical analysis that not only articulates the core concepts clearly but also challenges existing paradigms, encouraging readers to think critically about the implications of the findings.  
- Establishes upper and lower bounds that provide a framework for understanding the performance limits of the proposed algorithm, which is essential for assessing its applicability in real-world scenarios.  

**Weaknesses**  
- Fails to compare with MOPO, despite algorithmic similarities that could enrich the discussion and provide a more comprehensive context for evaluating the proposed method. A comparative analysis could reveal strengths and weaknesses relative to MOPO, contributing to a clearer understanding of the advancements made.  
- Focuses on model-based methods, yet motivation contrasts model-based and model-free approaches without sufficiently bridging the gap between these paradigms, leaving readers questioning the relevance of this discussion to the core algorithm presented.  

This paper tackles a crucial issue in the field of reinforcement learning, specifically the need for improved strategies in environments characterized by uncertainty. Recognizing the notable distinctions between the two categories of algorithms—vanilla learning (which relies on direct interaction with the environment) and imitation learning (which leverages demonstrations)—is fundamental. Discerning the optimal approach or potential combinations of these methods represents a vital avenue for future research that could yield significant advancements in algorithmic efficiency and effectiveness. For instance, integrating model-based strategies with imitation learning could harness the strengths of both approaches, leading to more robust solutions that can adapt to complex environments.

Nevertheless, I question whether this paper effectively addresses the stated problem. My primary concern is that the proposed algorithm bears a strong resemblance to the MOPO algorithm [51], which incorporates a pessimism term to penalize uncertain regions of the state space—an approach that has proven effective in similar contexts. Specifically, in the framework of finite Markov Decision Processes (MDPs), the pessimism term can be derived using well-defined bounds based on state-action visitation counts, paralleling the definitions presented in this paper. Moreover, the MOPO study offers an error guarantee that seems closely aligned with the results reported by the authors, particularly through the use of the total variation norm on transition probability estimates. This raises important questions about the novelty of the authors' algorithm and the originality of their accompanying analysis, as it appears to tread familiar ground rather than breaking new terrain.

Furthermore, in their discussion of related work, the authors assert a gap between model-free and model-based approaches regarding pessimism, claiming that their research seeks to elucidate this divide. However, given that the paper is centered on model-based methods, it is unclear how it effectively fulfills this objective without a more comprehensive examination of model-free techniques. This lack of integration diminishes the potential impact of their findings, as a more nuanced understanding of how these methodologies interact could produce richer insights into the underlying challenges and solutions.

Finally, the absence of experimental results to substantiate their approach is a significant limitation. Since the performance tradeoffs are primarily of empirical interest, the inclusion of experiments would greatly enhance the clarity and insights presented in this paper. For example, comparative performance metrics against established algorithms, including MOPO, would provide a clearer picture of the proposed method's efficacy. Such empirical evidence is crucial not only for validating the theoretical claims made within the paper but also for guiding practitioners in the field who seek to apply these findings to real-world problems.

LLM_1: English serves as a second language across parts of Southern Europe, where it is widely taught and used in education, business, and tourism. As a primary language, its footprint remains limited—officially recognized only in Gibraltar, where it holds equal status with Spanish, and in Malta, where it is commonly spoken alongside Maltese, though not the dominant native tongue.
LLM_2:
English serves as a second language across parts of Southern Europe, where it is widely taught and used in education, business, and tourism. In countries such as Italy, Spain, Greece, and Portugal, English is a core component of the national curriculum, typically introduced in primary school and emphasized in secondary and higher education. Its prominence is driven not only by academic requirements but also by economic necessity—particularly in regions reliant on international trade and foreign visitors. Coastal areas and major urban centers, from Barcelona to Athens, frequently employ English in customer service, hospitality, and retail sectors to accommodate the millions of tourists who visit annually. Moreover, multinational companies operating in the region often use English as a working language to bridge communication among diverse linguistic teams.

As a primary language, its footprint remains limited—officially recognized only in Gibraltar, where it holds equal status with Spanish, and in Malta, where it is commonly spoken alongside Maltese, though not the dominant native tongue. In Gibraltar, a British Overseas Territory located at the southern tip of the Iberian Peninsula, English is the medium of instruction in schools, the language of government, and the principal means of public communication, reflecting its colonial legacy and ongoing political ties to the United Kingdom. Malta presents a more nuanced case: while Maltese, a Semitic language with heavy Romance influences, is the national language and most widely spoken at home, English enjoys co-official status and is extensively used in administration, legal proceedings, and higher education. This bilingual framework has made Maltese residents highly proficient in English, contributing to the island’s appeal as a hub for international call centers, financial services, and digital nomads. Despite these exceptions, native English speakers remain a small minority in Southern Europe overall, and the language’s role continues to be primarily functional and acquired rather than inherited through family or community.

human:
The Commandant sighed, his breath releasing as a pale smoke in the frostbitten air. The stench of the dead woke him more surely than anything ever could. He quickly dressed into his uniform, long reduced to tatters. As he strode out of his tent into the cold morning, he made the count as always. *30 tents* he thought. Their numbers had dimmed like a candle's flame in the crushing winter, but it did not matter. The numbers of the enemy were no more. 
 
 Fort Cairn had been taken. Its defenders had been captured or killed, and Mord, the head of the separatists, had been defeated. Mord's will had once commanded legions of soldiers, men and women who would have died for his cause. They would have even died to keep his identity a secret, this specter of false hope and ruination, but Mord's will was broken. The defeated hold no rights, not anymore. The Commandant of Reyes did not seek this conflict, as that was not his way. But he was honor-bound to defend the people of Reyes, and that honor had led his men through a bloody civil war. 
 
 His walk took him past what few men remained to him, a force that was a shadow of what it had once been. Their wounds were terrible, as to be expected. More than half had suffered amputations, after the chemical weapons were unleashed. Not all of the wounds had come from the enemy. Their own weapons often did their jobs too well, but they had no choice. *Why? * the Commandant thought, *Why did he do this? What did he gain? *. 
 
 He approached what had yesterday been the battlefield, surveying the destruction. Fort Cairn had more dead men in it than living, a statistic barely eased by the few who could be moved to mass graves. So many dead could hardly be contained by these hills for long, a few rains and some scavenging beasts would see to that. The Commandant's step faltered for a moment, and he felt like he should... do SOMETHING. What could possibly make all of this worth it? After a quiet moment, he moved briskly to the Ops Center. One way or another, he would know why. 
 
 The Commandant strode into the tent, his chest now heaving with anger. His men became frightened to see their commander losing his composure now, at the time of victory, but no one would stand in his way. His hands found the ceremonial sword he had been given by the Queen herself. The blade was dull, but the point was sharp as ever; it would suffice. When he at last pulled back the flap to reveal his prisoner, the only light in the room was a torch. The Commandant could barely see his features, but here was the man who had caused his country such pain. The torchlight danced on his sword as he moved closer to speak. 
 
 `` You... I do n't even know what you are. You can not be a human being; a human being would never have done all that you have. Your crimes are innumerable, and your men- your men are slaughtered along with mine. Your legacy will be dust. You will have no public execution to proclaim your lies, no. You will have dust. Before I strike you down with the blade given to me by the Queen you murdered, I must know why. Why? Why would you do this? What could possibly have driven you to this folly?'' 
 
 Still, the prisoner said nothing. Mord was as motionless as the Commandant, and from his eyes shown accusation. The Commandant's fury rose to a boiling point; he could hold it in no longer. `` Answer me, creature!'' he roared, his vision blurred by his tears of anger. His sword arm pulled back as his eyes closed; there was no justice to be found from this man. He drove the point into the separatists chest. 
 
 The sword point bounced, as if off solid mail, as a strange sound cracked the air. The Commandant opened his eyes. The ground was covered in glass, like that of a broken mirror, and his prisoner was gone. Instead, there was another man, in mild wear, holding a torch. He was smiling. *Why is he smiling? * 
 
 `` Lord Commandant, you must have many questions. The only one that matters is where your prisoner went. I'm afraid you never had one. Your soldiers have taken no prisoners today, as my agents within your ranks have seen fit to dispatch with them. You see, this war was designed and implemented by my forces to weaken yours. I know that this small force is all that you have left after yesterday's battle, and my country's armies shall use this to our advantage.'' 
 
 `` For years, the seeds of rebellion were planted within your people. Little of what we told them was true, but the effect was the same. Your people fought a war against themselves, for years, and every battle led to this day. You thought you had cornered the so-called separatists, but you were fooled. By me, Mord. Fort Cairn was a trap, Lord Commandant. You have captured no one but yourself. You have executed no one but yourself. Remember this, as your country burns, and you along with it.'' 
 
 The Commandant did n't move, but the sword fell from his hand. Unblinking, he let his gaze fall from Mord to the ground, where his reflection stared back in a thousand pieces. He remained there as the man left, and soon started to hear the sounds of gunfire and screams. The fires burned so hot that he could feel it outside his tent. The smoke entered the room under the flaps. The screams had died out. The torchlight danced upon the sword.
LLM_1:
The Commandant exhaled, a wisp of breath curling like ghostly smoke into the knife-edged cold. It was the stench that truly woke him—the sour rot of unburied dead, thick in the frozen air. Without ceremony, he pulled on his uniform, threadbare and scarred by years of war, each frayed seam a testament to battles long since begun. Stepping from his tent, he cast his eyes across the camp as he did each dawn: *thirty tents*. Once, there had been hundreds. Now, only echoes remained—his army diminished not just in number but in spirit, though the enemy’s ranks were no more.  

Fort Cairn stood conquered. Its defenders broken—slaughtered or taken—and Mord, the architect of rebellion, defeated. Mord, whose name had once stirred hearts like a war drum, who commanded legions ready to die for shadows and lies, had fallen. Or so it seemed. His will, once iron, now bent beneath the weight of defeat. And in this world, the vanquished held no rights. The Commandant had not sought this war; bloodshed was not his creed. But honor was. And honor had dragged him and his men through fire and filth, through a civil war that devoured brother and sister alike.  

He walked among the remnants of his force—men hollowed by frost and flame, their bodies stitched with wounds both foreign and self-inflicted. More than half bore the marks of amputation, limbs lost not to enemy blades but to their own chemical horrors, weapons that spared no one. They had used them because they had no choice. *Why?* The question clawed at him, raw and unanswered. *Why would anyone do this? What did he gain?*  

Ahead lay the field of yesterday’s triumph—if such a word could be spoken here. Fort Cairn teemed with corpses, outnumbering the living tenfold. A few survivors had been dragged to mass graves, but most remained where they fell. Soon, rain would come. Then beasts. The hills would not hold this horror for long. For a moment, the Commandant hesitated, his boots sinking slightly into thawing mud. He felt the urge—no, the *need*—to do *something*, to make meaning from this carnage. But what act could balance such scales? After a silence heavy with grief, he turned sharply toward the Ops Center. One way or another, he would have answers.  

Inside the command tent, his chest rose and fell like a bellows. His men shrank back—this was not the commander they knew. Calm, resolute, unshakable—he had always been their anchor. Now, fury burned in his eyes, bright and dangerous. No one dared speak. His hand closed around the ceremonial blade—the sword bestowed by the Queen herself, its edge dulled by time but its tip still keen enough to kill. It would serve.  

He tore back the flap of the inner chamber. Only a single torch lit the space, casting jagged shadows across stone. There, bound and silent, sat the man who had torn his nation apart. The Commandant could barely see his face, but he knew him—knew the weight of his crimes, the rivers of blood that followed in his wake. The torchlight flickered along the steel of his sword as he stepped forward.  

“You…” His voice cracked like ice. “I don’t even know what you are. No human being could have done what you’ve done. Your sins are endless. Your soldiers lie dead—mine too. You’ve left nothing but ash. There will be no execution, no stage for your final lies. Only dust. Before I end you with the blade of the Queen you murdered, I demand an answer: *Why?* Why would you bring this upon us? What madness drove you?”  

The prisoner did not move. Mord—silent, unmoving—met his gaze with eyes full of accusation. As if *he* were the wronged. The Commandant’s rage surged, boiling over. “Answer me, *creature!*” he roared, tears blurring his vision. His arm drew back, the sword poised. Justice would not come from words. It never had. He thrust forward—  

—and the blade struck nothing. It bounced, ringing like shattered glass, repelled by air itself. The Commandant staggered, blinking. Around him, the ground glittered—thousands of shards, mirror-bright, scattered like fallen stars. Mord was gone. In his place stood another man, dressed in plain, weather-worn clothes, holding a torch. Smiling.  

*Why is he smiling?*  

“Lord Commandant,” the stranger said, voice smooth as oil, “you must have questions. But only one matters: Where is your prisoner? The truth is, you never had one. Your soldiers took no captives today. My agents ensured that. Every prisoner was quietly removed—disposed of. This war… it was mine from the beginning. Designed to bleed you dry. I know you stand here with only this remnant. And my armies? They are already moving.”  

“For years, we sowed whispers in your cities, your homes. We fed lies like seeds, and your people watered them with their rage. They fought each other—brother against brother—for a cause that never existed. You believed you’d cornered the separatists. But you were chasing phantoms. By me. By *me*, Mord. Fort Cairn was a snare. You didn’t capture an enemy. You captured yourself. You didn’t execute a rebel leader. You executed your own hope.”  

His smile widened. “Remember this, Lord Commandant, as your nation burns. As *you* burn.”  

The Commandant did not move. The sword slipped from his fingers, clattering onto the glass-strewn earth. His eyes dropped—to the shards below—and in each fractured piece, his face stared back, splintered a thousand ways. He remained there, motionless, as the man turned and vanished.  

Then came the distant crack of gunfire. Screams. The heat of flames pressed against the tent flaps, seeping in like breath. Smoke curled under the canvas, thick and suffocating. The screams faded. Only silence answered.  

And in the dim glow of the torch, the sword lay abandoned—its reflection dancing across a thousand broken mirrors.

In a dimly lit hut, a Major sits in front of a scientist, while holding the bridge of his nose he ask; 
 
 `` Now what was the drop SUPPOSE to do?'' 
 
 `` Well, sir, it was suppose to pacify the people. Drop all their adrenaline levels and make them more plausible to surrender'' 
 
 `` And what did the drop ACTUALLY do?'' 
 
 `` You have the report Sir'' 
 
 `` I'm not asking the report, I'm asking you. So what did it do?'' 
 
 `` Well... the total population gained large eyes. For 80 % of the population, their hair become somewhat spiky and static. The other 20 % showed similar symptoms but their hair also changed to garish colours. The females... ahem, their... bust size increased at least 3 sizes, while all the males gained glowing glasses'' 
 
 `` Dear god''
LLM_1:
In the flickering light of her hut's lantern, Major Blackwood sat across from the scientist Dr. Elara, his brow furrowed in concern. "Now, what exactly was this 'pacification drop' supposed to accomplish?" he asked, frustration etched in his voice.

Dr. elara leaned forward, her eyes wide with a mix of fear and uncertainty.  "It was intended to calm the populace, to reduce their stress levels, rendering them less resistant to our surrender terms."

Major Blackwoods gaze intensified.   "And what, pray tell, did this drop actually achieve?" 

Dr Elaras voice trembled.    "If I may, Sir, consult the official report?"

Major blackwood's expression turned incredulous.     "I'm inquiring about the facts, not some dry document. What happened on the ground?"  

Dr elaras words tumbled out in haste.      "Well... our surveys revealed that a staggering 8o percent of subjects developed dilated pupils. Hair stood on end for 7o %, turning an electric blue. A further 2o %, their locks took on vibrant hues, like a rainbow. As for the females, ah, they experienced... an unexpected increase in... breast size. Males, on their part, grew glowing spectacles."

The Major's face contorted in horror.         "Dear heavens."
LLM_2:
In Major blackwoods' dimly lit hut, Dr Elar stood before him, a look of trepidation on her face. He asked pointedly, "What was the true purpose of this pacification serum?" His brow was furled, concern written on his features.

She leaned in, eyes aglow with fear. 'It aimed to ease the population's anxiety, making them more receptive to surrender."

Blackwood scrutinized her, incredulity evident on face,  'What did the data reveal?"

Dr ELara's voice wavered as she said, 'According to reports, most subjects experienced unusual physiological responses. Eighty percent developed enlarged pupils, seventy percent had hair stand on its end, turning electric-blue. Twenty percent displayed colorful locks. Females showed an unforeseen increase, while males sported glowing glasses."

As BlackWOOD's horror became palpable, he whispered, '"Good heavens.'"

My faith in the existence of God stems from a personal desire to have that belief and a sense that it doesn’t defy logic. In all honesty, I may not be able to articulate a more compelling argument. However, my conviction is further strengthened by the notion that I feel a connection to something higher. This could be a product of my introspection, a result of an open-minded perspective,  or perhaps even a creative expression of imagination.

Ultimately, it’s impossible to definitively prove or disprove the presence of a higher power, so it comes down to choosing the explanation that resonates with me the best. Yet, on a deeper level, there’s a part of me that yearns to put my faith into action. If I were to relinquish my belief in an all-encompassing purpose, would I still be driven to make a meaningful impact in this world? The thought alone is unsettling, as I struggle to envision a life devoid of direction and guidance. As a means of giving my existence significance, embracing the concept of divine intervention allows me to navigate life’s complexities with a renewed sense of hope and purpose.

Additionally, minor adjustments were made to optimize readability and fluidness. Overall, this rewritten piece conveys the author's core sentiments with greater polish and precision.
LLM_2:
**The Unwavering Quest for Meaning: A Personal Journey of Faith**

As I reflect on the nature of existence, one question consistently echoes in my mind: what lies beyond the veil of reality? My personal conviction in a Higher Power stems not from dogmatic conviction, but from an innate desire for meaning. I yearn for the reassurance that there's more to life than the fleeting moments we occupy. My belief doesn't stem from empirical evidence, nor do I pretend to possess a definitive proof. Instead, its roots lie in intuition, born from the depths of introspective contemplation.

For me, faith is not a mere intellectual exercise, where logic and reason reign supreme. Rather, It's an emotional and spiritual connection that transcends the confines of rational explanation. When I gaze up at starry night skies or find solace in nature's majestic landscapes, an inexplicable sense whispers to me of something greater. Perhaps this is the result an unbiased perspective or an imagination that dares to dream beyond our mundane reality. Whatever its origin, that feeling leaves an indelible mark on my soul.

Of course, we can't definitvely prove the validity of faith. No empirical research or philosophical treatise can guarantee the truth of our existence. Ultimately, our beliefs boil down a deeply personal choice, influenced by a multitude of factors, including our upbringing, life experiences, values, morals, culture, tradition, education, social influences, personal interests, intuition and reasoning. What resonated with us the most often reflects our individual worldview, shaping our perception and shaping the meaning we attribute to our lives.

Yet, for me at least, having faith means finding a purpose beyond my personal pursuits. Without a guiding force, can I genuinely claim to be making a positive impact on this fragile world we call home? I'm forced to confront this haunting question, only to realize the inherent meaninglessness of life without a transcendent purpose to drive me forward. A life bereft of higher purpose is like a tree without roots or a river without direction – aimless and disconnected from its true source.

Embracing the idea of divinity, therefore, serves as a beacon of light, illuminating life's complexities and providing hope amidst uncertainty. By anchoring my being in something transcending the mundane, meaning begins to emerge from life. With faith, even the darkest of days becomes an opportunity to grow, learn and explore the world with renewed purpose and resilience.

As this introspectve journey unfolds, two realities become clear: our world is a vast tapestry woven from diverse threads, each telling a story of its own. Whether or not we believe in divine guidance, what remains constant is our quest for significance and connection. We can choose to view life through the lens of materialism or spiritualism, yet, at its core, lies a yearning for belonging, love, understanding and shared human experiences.

This essay represents the evolving process of self-discovery, reflecting on what makes us tick and what gives our life true meaning in our own eyes. Faith is but one piece of the grand puzzle, interlocking with the multitude other elements that shape our worldview. How we interpret and experience the divine is unique to each individual, their perspectives and experiences. Nonetheless, acknowledging the transcendant and its relevance in life, is essential to find meaning, significance or purpose in it. Through our faith we find strength to face our fears, find hope in uncertainty, discover new opportunities, foster empathy, encourage love and kindness, build bridges, promote understanding, inspire others and ultimately create a better world for ourselves and for others.

Britain-based Force India, fourth in the constructors' championship last season, hope to compete with Mercedes, Red Bull and Ferrari.
