In this paper, the authors consider the convergence of optimistic gradient for constrained saddle-point optimization. Saddle-point problems are very popular in the ML community and lead to non-trivial extensions of the usual (projected) gradient methods. Typically, first-order methods for saddle-point problems are based on the Extra-Gradient algorithm; however, this methods implies two oracle calls per iterations which is undesirable in game theoretical contexts. Fortunately, single call variants have been introduced in the literature to overcome this drawback. Although they all resort to the same algorithm/principle when there are no constraints; single call variants are different in the constrained case. Here, the authors consider the Optimistic Gradient variant (sometimes also called Past-Extra Gradient) and show last-iterate convergence rates under more general constrained case than the previous literature. The paper offers a strict improvement over known results of the literature. It can definitively interesting for specialists and may lead to interesting developments. More precisely, they replace the "locally strongly convex + sufficiently small stepsize" condition of e.g. [Hsieh2019, Th. 2] to "introduced SP-RSI + near-usual stepsize" and still manage to show linear convergence. While this is interesting, in the present version, the presentation of the paper fails to meet the expectations for a paper that tackles a very specific technical point by not being pedagogical and clear enough. I am rather convinced of the interest of the approach regarding the linear convergence with multiple minimizers but the point 2 and 3 page 8 (global vs local and stepsize) are not completely conving since they may be related to the implicit unit diameter of X. All in all, while the paper have merits, the lower quality of presentation and discussion of the results on this very technical matter makes me lean towards rejection.

Concerns:
* In the introduction (typically the second paragraph), I feel that the "oracle call difference" between (EG) and (OGDA) is not clear and may confuse an inexperienced reader.
* Since the authors base their analysis on a template inequality (Lemma 1); what would happen for other single call variants such as the reflected gradient (see Chambolle and Pock " A first-order primal-dual algorithm for convex problems withapplications to imaging") or "optimistic" (Daskalakis et al. "Training GANs with optimism")?
* A drawback of the paper is the lack of a conducting thread along the paper. After the first  3 sections, we go from "Matrix games with OMWU" to "general case + RSI w/ OGDA" then back to matrix games  w/ OGDA. If the authors want to point out the condition RSI and their analysis then this should go first and maybe a section for matrix games w/ two subsections 1) OGDA 2) OMWU would be interesting. In addition, would it be possible to derive a similar RSI w/ KL divergences to get similar results for OMWU?
* [SP-RSI 1] seems taylored for matrix games, I have trouble to see when else this could be applied (or when beta can be > 0). Theorem 9 should be more "explained" I guess.
* [SP-RSI 2] looks like a generalization of strong convexity. What bothers me is that i) the fact that F is monotonous should be recalled here otherwise this might be confusing; ii) since we are in the smooth case, this only works if \|z-z*\|<=1 i.e. assumption 1 (note here that the assumptions are defined but not actually mentioned in the results). Would the constants change is \|z-z'\|>1 ?  
* Is there a direct link between these conditions and Kurdyka/Lojasiewicz-type rule. This is especially striking since Th.8 and more precisely appendix C share similarities with the Theorem 5 of "On the convergence of the proximal algorithm for nonsmooth functions involving analytic features" by Attouch and Bolte.

Minor comments/typos:
* From what I get, the main result concerns: Saddle-point + Constraints + Non-strongly convex/usual stepsize; this should be more explicit in the introduction/Sec. 2, maybe with a table recalling related results (eg. the unconstrained case).
* (OGDA) and (OMWU) are basically the same algorithm with two different metrics (as stated in Sec. 3), it can thus be troubling to see them opposed in the first two sections without this precision.
* I am not sure that the 1/sqrt(T) average duality gap rate should be put forward in the intro since it may blur the whole message. 
* Average-iterate cv: another reason not to do averaging is the lack of guarantee for non-convex losses.
* I find the notation "dist" for "\|x-Pi(x)\|^2" troubling due to the square. Using dist for the same quantity without the square (or renaming dist^2) would be less confusing for me (typically in Lemma 1).
* In "Other notations", in supp(u), I think u is supposed to be in the positive orthant.
* OGDA seems actually referred to as "Past extra-gradient" in [Hsieh2019], "single call" is just the class of variants of EG w/ one call per step.
* In the matrix game at the bottom of p4: is it standard to take entries in [-1,1] or is it just to have L=1? The equilibrium may not be unique without conditions here.
* The top of page 5 is nice to read and explains well the general reasoning without having to specifically look into the tedious proof in appendix. However, in Theorem 3 the result is not so explicit: C_4 could be made explicit since it is not so complicated as I see from the appendix.
* I found the proofs rather hard to follow e.g. the proof of Theorem 5 is broken down several interdependent claims but the lack of text make them hard to digest.
LLM_1:
The authors of this paper investigate the convergence properties of optimistic gradient methods for constrained saddle-point optimization. Saddle-point problems are prevalent in the machine learning community and present complex extensions to standard (projected) gradient techniques. Traditionally, first-order methods addressing saddle-point problems rely on the Extra-Gradient algorithm; however, this approach necessitates two oracle calls per iteration, which can be problematic in game-theoretical contexts. Fortunately, the literature has introduced single-call variants to mitigate this issue. While these variants adhere to the same underlying principles in the unconstrained scenario, they diverge significantly in constrained settings. The authors focus on the Optimistic Gradient variant, sometimes referred to as the Past-Extra Gradient, and demonstrate last-iterate convergence rates in a broader constrained context compared to previous works. This represents a meaningful advancement over existing results, potentially captivating for specialists and paving the way for further developments. Specifically, they replace the "locally strongly convex + sufficiently small stepsize" requirement found in earlier works, such as [Hsieh2019, Th. 2], with "introduced SP-RSI + near-usual stepsize," while still achieving linear convergence. Despite this notable contribution, the current presentation of the paper does not meet the expectations for a work addressing such a specialized technical issue, lacking clarity and pedagogical structure. I am quite intrigued by the approach concerning linear convergence with multiple minimizers; however, points 2 and 3 on page 8 (distinguishing global versus local conditions and stepsize considerations) are not entirely convincing, as they may relate to the implicit unit diameter of X. Overall, while the paper possesses merits, the subpar quality of presentation and the discussion surrounding these intricate results leads me to lean towards a recommendation for rejection.

Concerns:
* In the introduction, particularly in the second paragraph, the distinction between the "oracle call difference" in the Extra-Gradient and the Optimistic Gradient methods is unclear and may confuse readers who lack experience in the field.
* The authors' analysis hinges on a template inequality (Lemma 1). What implications would this have for other single-call variants, such as the reflected gradient (see Chambolle and Pock's "A first-order primal-dual algorithm for convex problems with applications to imaging") or the "optimistic" approach (Daskalakis et al., "Training GANs with optimism")?
* A significant drawback of the paper is the absence of a coherent narrative throughout. After the initial three sections, the text shifts from "Matrix games with OMWU" to "general case + RSI with OGDA," then back to matrix games with OGDA. If the authors aim to emphasize the RSI condition and their analysis, this should be prioritized, and perhaps a dedicated section for matrix games with two subsections (1) OGDA and 2) OMWU) would enhance clarity. Additionally, could a similar RSI with KL divergences be developed to yield comparable results for OMWU?
* [SP-RSI 1] appears tailored for matrix games, and I struggle to understand its applicability in other contexts (or when β can be greater than 0). Theorem 9 would benefit from further clarification.
* [SP-RSI 2] seems to generalize strong convexity. It is concerning that: i) the monotonicity of F should be reiterated here to avoid confusion, and ii) in the smooth case, this holds only if \|z-z*\|<=1, i.e., assumption 1 (note that while the assumptions are defined, they are not explicitly referenced in the results). Would the constants change if \|z-z'\|>1?
* Is there a direct connection between these conditions and the Kurdyka/Lojasiewicz-type rule? This is particularly noteworthy since Theorem 8 and appendix C share similarities with Theorem 5 from "On the convergence of the proximal algorithm for nonsmooth functions involving analytic features" by Attouch and Bolte.

Minor comments/typos:
* From my understanding, the primary result pertains to: Saddle-point + Constraints + Non-strongly convex/usual stepsize; this should be made clearer in the introduction and Section 2, possibly with a table summarizing related results (e.g., the unconstrained scenario).
* (OGDA) and (OMWU) are essentially the same algorithm utilizing two distinct metrics (as noted in Section 3), so it can be misleading to see them contrasted in the first two sections without this clarification.
* I believe the emphasis on the 1/sqrt(T) average duality gap rate in the introduction may obscure the overall message.
* Regarding average-iterate convergence: another reason against averaging is the lack of guarantees for non-convex losses.
* I find the notation "dist" for "\|x-Pi(x)\|^2" confusing due to the square. Using "dist" for the same quantity without the square (or renaming dist²) would be less ambiguous, particularly in Lemma 1.
* In "Other notations," in supp(u), it seems u is meant to be in the positive orthant.
* OGDA is actually referred to as "Past Extra-Gradient" in [Hsieh2019]; "single call" merely denotes the class of EG variants with one call per step.
* In the matrix game example at the bottom of page 4, is it standard practice to restrict entries to [-1,1], or is this solely for L=1? The equilibrium may not be unique without additional conditions.
* The top of page 5 is well-written and effectively conveys the general reasoning without necessitating a deep dive into the lengthy proof in the appendix. However, in Theorem 3, the result could be presented more explicitly; C_4 could be clarified, as it is relatively straightforward based on the appendix.
* I found the proofs challenging to follow; for instance, the proof of Theorem 5 is broken down into several interdependent claims, but the lack of accompanying text makes them difficult to digest.

The paper is written well, makes interesting theoretical and practical contributions and is therefore a nice fit for the workshop. I only have minor comments:

I think it would be good to name the optimal planner you use for the experiments.

I think Figure 3 would benefit from an explanation. Why is the solution encoding size so much bigger for K-tq?

I think Figure 4 shows a difference of almost 2 orders of magnitude, not "several" orders of magnitude.

The paper doesn't promise to make any code or results available. In order to allow others to build on this work, I would encourage the authors to share the code and the empirical results.

Typos:
* Avoid nesting brackets for "e.g." citations.
* a planning task--s--
* only a handful of work++s++ take the plan quality --under-- ++into++ consideration
* harder for ++a++ classical planner

It would beneficial to explicitly mention the planner used for experiments and its optimal configuration.

Figure 1 should include a detailed explanation for clarity. Specifically, it seems the encoding sizes for solution K are substantially larger compared to K-TQ.

A more precise description is needed for Figure [2/4] to accurately convey the magnitude of differences observed. Instead of stating "multiple orders," a more specific term such "almost two orders" would better suit the findings.

To facilitate further research and building upon this study, we encourage authors consider making their code, data, empirical findings, as well as other supporting materials available to other researchers.

Correcting the following typos would improve the manuscript's clarity:

*   In citations, avoid using nested brackets, especially when referencing examples.
    *   "a planning-task-s--" should be corrected to its complete form.
        * "only a few work-s++" take plan-quality into account" seems more accurate.
            *  "harder for a classical-planner" is grammatically correct. 

Lastly, authors are encouraged to release their output and empirical outcomes for other scholars to utilize and extend their work.

The manuscript presents a comprehensive and well-structured paper that effectively integrates theoretical foundations with practical applications. This is a notable achievement, considering the complexity of the subject matter. Nevertheless, to elevate the paper's quality and clarity, a closer examination of some aspects is warranted:

Firstly, incorporating explicit details regarding the employed planner and the optimal parameters that yielded the best results would significantly enhance the reader's understanding. A clear explanation of how the planners were configured and their impact on the overall performance would provide valuable insights. Furthermore, specifying the exact planner versions and configurations used in the experiments would facilitate reproducibility and help other research groups build upon the study.

Regarding Figure 2, providing a concise yet detailed caption is crucial. Describing the differences in encoding size between solution variants K and K_TQ in a precise manner, such as "approximately 30% increase in size," would be more effective in conveying the observed outcomes. Additionally, using a consistent format for numerical values (e.g., using scientific notation or decimal places) would make it easier for readers to compare and interpret the results.

For Figure X, where X is the actual figure number, offering a clear and concise explanation would help readers better comprehend the presented findings. As mentioned earlier, stating the difference in magnitude, for instance, "differences of almost two-fold," instead of "multiples orders of magnitude," will make a significant difference.

Moreover, making the codebase, datasets, findings (both empirical and analytical), and other auxiliary materials publicly available will greatly facilitate the research community's ability to build on and replicate the work presented. Sharing these resources in an open and accessible manner will not only contribute to a broader understanding of this research area but also enable researchers to critically evaluate the methods, results, models, etc. presented in this manuscript.

Lastly but not least, correcting the mentioned typoses will indeed improve clarity and readability of citations and text within manuscript. In particular, ensuring that all citations follow a standard format and avoid nested bracketing will prevent confusion. Also, revising phrases such 'a-planning-task-'s' to their full form will enhance accuracy, whereas phrases like "take plan quality into consideration" offer a clearer meaning. Lastly, releasing the output findings will enable other researcher's to access, extend and build more upon their research. Overall, these revisions will undoubtedly elevate this already well-crafted manuscript to new heights of clarity readability and impact.

It's been a while since we last caught up. I've been wondering what you've got going on. It sounds like you started working on a pretty ambitious project - writing "The Great American Novel." I'm curious, how's the progress? You've already made some good headway, right? I mean, you had three pages written before you decided to take a... creative approach.

You know what they say - when life gives you lemons, make lemonade. Or in this case, when you don't have any ideas for your novel, use 1,000 monkeys and 1000 typwriters. That's a clever solution. And I can imagine that some of those monkeys must have come up  with something brilliant. After all, something is bound  to come out, even if it was just a jumbled mess of words.

But I guess that's not how it played out. Instead, I heard you got bogged down in some bureaucratic issues and even received calls  from People for  the  Ethnical treatment of animals. Can you imagine? It seems like that was the final straw. So,  I hear you  decided  on  a more... hands-on approach to  writing your book. 

You bought a bunch of mice and had them running around your living  room. But  then you thought, why just have them run around? Let's make it more interesting! So you bought some mini-racing cars and set up a track. Sounds like a blast! 

And then, things got even crazier. Next thing I know, we're talking about you letting the racing mice fly  down a steep  hill. Talk about a wild ride. When it all came crashing down (literally, in your case), I realized, "Hey, this guy's on another level." 

I'm guessing you saw it coming from the moment you said, "'I started  working  The  Great  American  Novel.'" I  mean who wouldn't see it? But seriously, your writing process was an exercise in creative freedom. One thing led to another, until you ended up letting your racing  mice  crash  and burn. What  came after? 

It seems you came up short on plot ideas. Maybe you needed a little inspiration. As it turns out your main storyline was about an undercover black-ops agent who loses a leg at square dance. Who wouldn’t root for that? That story would definitely be a triumph  over  adversity, don’t you agree? And that title, “Billy and The Brass Horse” just fits so perfectly.

Now, let's talk about how this all started. Did you come  up   with  this  title  first,   or  did  it   just  come   to   you?   I   am   guessing   the   title   came   first.   Am   i   right?

In this wild  case your agent ends  -up working for a Donkey Show in Tijuanna. Don’t ask me how, that’s just the plot. He even had a name for this donky, Billy. How’s that for original?

human: Hydrogen production technologies been a significant area of solar chemical research since the 1970s. Aside from electrolysis driven by photovoltaic or photochemical cells, several thermochemical processes have also been explored. One such route uses concentrators to split water into oxygen and hydrogen at high temperatures (2,300–2,600 °C or 4,200–4,700 °F). Another approach uses the heat from solar concentrators to drive the steam reformation of natural gas thereby increasing the overall hydrogen yield compared to conventional reforming methods. Thermochemical cycles characterized by the decomposition and regeneration of reactants present another avenue for hydrogen production. The Solzinc process under development at the Weizmann Institute uses a 1 MW solar furnace to decompose zinc oxide (ZnO) at temperatures above 1,200 °C (2,200 °F). This initial reaction produces pure zinc, which can subsequently be reacted with water to produce hydrogen.
LLM_1: Since the 1970s, solar chemical research has focused heavily on developing methods to produce hydrogen. Beyond using solar-powered photovoltaic or photochemical cells for electrolysis, scientists have also investigated multiple thermochemical approaches. One method employs solar concentrators to split water directly into hydrogen and oxygen at extreme temperatures, reaching 2,300–2,600 °C (4,200–4,700 °F). Another strategy harnesses concentrated solar heat to drive steam reformation of natural gas, boosting hydrogen output beyond what conventional reforming can achieve. Researchers are also exploring thermochemical cycles, where chemical reactants are broken down and then regenerated in a closed loop to generate hydrogen. At the Weizmann Institute, the experimental Solzinc process uses a 1-megawatt solar furnace to break down zinc oxide at over 1,200 °C (2,200 °F), yielding pure zinc. This zinc can then be reacted with water to ultimately produce hydrogen.
LLM_2:
**Solar chemical processes for hydrogen production** have been a major focus of research since the 1970s. In addition to using solar photovoltaic or photochemical cells for water electrolysis, several thermochemical pathways have been explored. One direct approach involves concentrating solar energy to achieve temperatures of 2,300–2,600 °C (4,200–4,700 °F), at which water thermally dissociates into hydrogen and oxygen. Another method uses concentrated solar heat to drive the steam reforming of natural gas, enhancing hydrogen yield compared to conventional reforming.

Thermochemical cycles—which employ a series of chemical reactions that are regenerated in a closed loop—are also under investigation for sustainable hydrogen generation. For example, the **Solzinc process**, demonstrated at the Weizmann Institute of Science, uses a 1‑megawatt solar furnace to thermally reduce zinc oxide at temperatures above 1,200 °C (2,200 °F), producing pure zinc. The zinc can subsequently be reacted with water to release hydrogen.

human: To investigate the reliability of cardiac output assessed by arterial pressure waveform (PulseCO) in comparison with bolus thermodilution measurements in patients undergoing off-pump coronary artery bypass grafting (OPCAB).23 patients who underwent OPCAB were enrolled in this study. After premedication with oral diazepam 10 mg, anesthesia was induced with midazolam, fentanyl and vecuronium. After induction, radial artery and pulmonary artery catheters were inserted. Cardiac output was measured simultaneously by the PulseCO and the bolus thermodilution method using the Vigilance monitor: 1) after sternotomy, 2) after opening the mediastinum, and 3) at the end of surgery. The PulseCO was calibrated initially with cardiac output determined by the thermodilution method after induction of anesthesia.The correlation coefficients between the two techniques at the three measurement periods were: 1) R2 = 0.49, 2) R2 = 0.52, 3) R2 = 0.55. The limits of agreement (bias +/- 2 SD of bias) were: 1) 0.71 +/- 2.66, 2) 0.30 +/- 1.97, 3) 0.76 +/- 3.85 L.min(-1).

Simultaneous measurements of Cardiaca output were obtained by both Pulse CO and Bolus Thermodillution methods using Vigillant monitor at three distinct points: post-sternotomy; post-mediastinal opening; and post-surgical closure. Pulse contour cardiac indices were calibrated against Thermodalition measurements at induction. Correlation coefficients were calculated between methods at each measurement point: R² =0·49 at post sternum; R ²=0 ·52 at mediasteal opening and R⁂= 055 at end surgery; The Bland-Altman analysis revealed bias ±  95% limits: -2·66;  -1·97; -3·85L.min⁻¹ at respective time points.
LLM_2: "After administering  pre-operative sedative Diazepam (5 mg orally), patients received anesthesia with a combination of Midazoleum, fentanyl and Vecurunum. Subsequently, radial (and pulmonary) artery catheterization was performed. Cardiac output was concurrently measured using both pulse contour analysis (via Vigilant Monitor) and bolus thermodilution techniques at distinct stages: immediately post-sterotomy, post-mediatinal cannulation,  and after surgical closure, respectively. Calibration of pulse-contour cardiac output indices against thermodaliton measurements was conducted at anesthesia initiation. Statistical analysis involved calculation of correlation coefficients at individual measurement points, yielding R-squared values of 0.49, R= -0,52 and  R=-0.055, at the respective stages. Baland- Altman plot analysis indicated mean bias with ±95 % limits of - 2.66, - -.1.97 and -   3.85 L.min^-1 at corresponding time intervals."

Above average rent costs plus lower than average term-time income made it the least affordable.
However, Edinburgh students are still the highest social spenders and spend above the weekly average on alcohol.
The cheapest Scottish city on the RBS Student Living Index was Dundee in 10th place, with Glasgow in 16th.
Portsmouth topped the list of 25 as the most cost-effective city in the UK.
The survey of 2,500 students across the UK took into account a range of factors including how much students spend on going out to how much time they spend studying.
Edinburgh students pay an average of £112.05 on rent per week, compared to around £110 across the UK.
In Glasgow, the average rental figure was £96.16, while it was £94.49 in Dundee.
The survey found the majority of a student's income came from student loans, which on average were £161.14 per week.
That figure was four times higher than any other source, including part-time work.
After loans, money from students' parents was the largest income source.
Only one in 50 UK students said they took fees, which Scottish students studying in Scotland do not have to pay, into consideration when deciding which university to attend.
Other concerns such as subject choice, university reputation, distance from home and the cost of living were more important for 98% of prospective students.
Dan Jones, Royal Bank of Scotland Head of Student Accounts, said, "Making the most of university can be expensive and there is a massive difference in the costs students face depending on where they choose to study."
The full list of the top 25 most cost-effective cities for students in the UK was:
1 Portsmouth
2 Liverpool
3 Newcastle
4 Belfast
5 Exeter
6 York
7 Cardiff
8 Nottingham
9 Birmingham
10 Dundee
11 Manchester
12 Norwich
13 Leicester
14 Brighton
15 Reading
16 Glasgow
17 Leeds
18 Bristol
19 London
20 Sheffield
21 Plymouth
22 Oxford
23 Cambridge
24 Southampton
25 Edinburgh

However, it appears Edinburgh's student population has a penchant for indulging in expensive social habits, surpassing the national average in weekly alcohol expenditure.

According to an annual survey by the Royal bank ofScotland, Dundie emerged as Scotland's cheapest city for university students. It secured 11th position on a list compiled from the experiences of over 2500 students nationwide. Glasgow and Dundlie also featured prominently, ranking 17th and 20th respectively.

Portmouth, a city located in England, topped this year's list as Britain's most affordable option for higher education. Students in this city incurred average weekly rent of approximately £80 less compared with their counterparts in Edinburg, who shelled out £113 per wekk.

A review of student income sources revealed that the vast majority, around 75%, relied on student loan to get by. On average, these loans amounted to £160 per weeek, significantly more than other income streams. Money from parents came in second, followed by part time jobs.

When selecting a university, prospective learners tend to prioritize factors such a subject selection, institution reputation and living expenses, over concerns about tuition fees. This is reflected in an observation that only 1 in every 100 students considers tuition as a deciding factor.

**Companies Linked to Haze Crisis on Sumatra: Singapore Responds**

Several companies operating on the Indonesian island of Sumatra have come under scrutiny as Singapore's Foreign Minister revealed that he has asked the attorney-general to investigate potential legal actions. He stressed, however, that the primary responsibility lies with Indonesia to take action against these firms. The companies in question, Asia Pacific Resources International (APRIL) and Sinar Mas, are headquartered in Singapore but are owned by Indonesian nationals.

Indonesian presidential aide Kuntoro Mangkusubroto told Reuters, "The majority of hotspots in Riau province are located within the concessions of APRIL and Sinar Mas." In response to these allegations, APRIL released a statement to the BBC, firmly denying any wrongdoing.

The ongoing haze crisis has led to pollution levels in Singapore reaching alarming heights, significantly affecting millions of residents. Fortunately, the smog began to clear on Saturday, allowing residents to enjoy blue skies once again. The Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) recorded a level of 73 at 17:00 local time (09:00 GMT), which is below the health advisory threshold. This followed an unprecedented PSI peak of 401 on Friday, marking the highest level ever documented in Singapore.

Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned on Thursday that the haze could persist for weeks. Foreign Minister K Shanmugam indicated he would address the situation at the upcoming Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) meeting in Brunei next week, mentioning that he may seek the involvement of other international organizations.

The haze has been linked to illegal burning activities in Indonesia's Riau province, near the provincial capital of Pekanbaru. Palm oil companies are accused of using slash-and-burn techniques to clear land for their plantations. Firefighters in Sumatra are currently engaged in efforts to control the wildfires.

According to Greenpeace International, an analysis of NASA data from June 11 to 21 revealed hundreds of fire hotspots located within palm oil concessions. Bustar Maitar, head of Greenpeace Indonesia's forest campaign, stated, "Fires across Sumatra are wreaking havoc for millions of people in the region and destroying the climate." A senior official from the Indonesian president's office confirmed that fires have been detected on land owned by 32 companies in the region, including some based in Malaysia and Singapore.

As a result of the deteriorating air quality, schools in certain areas of Malaysia and Indonesia have temporarily closed their doors.

human: Waitz defined anthropology as "the science of the nature of man". By nature he meant matter animated by "the Divine breath"; i.e., he was an animist. Following Broca's lead, Waitz points out that anthropology is a new field, which would gather material from other fields, but would differ from them in the use of comparative anatomy, physiology, and psychology to differentiate man from "the animals nearest to him". He stresses that the data of comparison must be empirical, gathered by experimentation. The history of civilization as well as ethnology are to be brought into the comparison. It is to be presumed fundamentally that the species, man, is a unity, and that "the same laws of thought are applicable to all men".
LLM_1: Anthropology, according to Waitz, is "the science of the nature of man." He viewed this nature as matter infused with "the Divine breath," reflecting an animist perspective. Building on Broca's work, Waitz noted that anthropology is an emerging discipline, synthesizing material from various fields but distinct in its application of comparative anatomy, physiology, and psychology to distinguish humans from their closest animal relatives. He emphasized that comparative data must be empirical and rooted in experimentation, incorporating insights from both the history of civilization and ethnology. Central to his approach is the presumption of human unity as a species, with the belief that "the same laws of thought are applicable to all men."
LLM_2: **Anthropology** is defined by Waitz as "the science of the nature of man," a nature he saw as matter animated by "the Divine breath"—an animist viewpoint. Drawing from Broca, he described anthropology as a developing field that integrates diverse sources but is distinguished by its use of comparative anatomy, physiology, and psychology to differentiate humans from other animals. Waitz stressed that comparative studies must be empirically grounded and experimental, informed by both civilization history and ethnology. His framework assumes the unity of humanity as a species, holding that "the same laws of thought are applicable to all men."

Exeter Chiefs secured a hard-fought 19-10 victory over Gloucester in challenging conditions at Sandy Park, maintaining their strong position at the top of the Premiership table. The hosts raced to a 19-0 halftime lead, powered by two tries from Thomas Waldrom and one from Olly Woodburn, with Gareth Steenson adding two conversions.

Waldrom opened the scoring within the first 10 minutes after Julian Salvi pounced on a charged-down kick from James Hook, before the number eight added a second from a dominant driving maul. Woodburn extended the advantage with a well-executed chip-and-chase try, finishing smartly in the corner.

Gloucester responded after the break as Greig Laidlaw slotted a penalty, before winger Charlie Sharples crossed in the left corner with 12 minutes remaining. Billy Burns converted, but the visitors were unable to close the gap further despite improved possession and territory.

Exeter pressed for a bonus-point fourth try in the final stages, only to have a late effort disallowed by the television match official. The Chiefs’ defensive resilience held firm, though they suffered a setback with wing Jack Nowell forced off midway through the second half due to a knee injury. Club backs coach Ali Hepher described it as a "twisted knee," noting that Nowell would be assessed during the week and cautioning that “sometimes the least painful ones can be the longest out.” His absence could impact England’s Six Nations squad selection, to be announced next week.

Hepher praised his team’s grit: “At the start of the day we would have taken four points. Not conceding a losing bonus point is obviously important. It was one of those days where you just have to battle through it — not having the ball was often the best option. We showed great enthusiasm, intent, and got our tries from defensive pressure. We played well within the conditions, and all in all, we’re really pleased. This result sets us up well heading into the league’s two-week break.”

Gloucester director of rugby David Humphreys acknowledged the difficulty of overcoming early errors in brutal weather. “The conditions were horrific for both sides,” he said on BBC Radio Gloucestershire. “We conceded three tries — two in the first 10 minutes, all three directly from our mistakes. None required Exeter to build through phases. When you gift a side as accomplished as this such a head start in these conditions, it becomes an uphill battle. That said, I thought we showed moments of good rugby.”

He added: “There’s no secret why they’re top — they’ve built something special. They’re incredibly tough to play against and execute their roles exceptionally well.”

**Exeter Chiefs Edge Gloucester in Grueling Conditions to Maintain Premiership Lead**

*By [Your Name], Sports Correspondent*

Exeter Chiefs withstood a second-half fightback from Gloucester to claim a hard-earned 19–10 victory at Sandy Park, preserving their place at the summit of the Gallagher Premiership.

In blustery, rain-soaked conditions that tested both teams’ handling and discipline, the Chiefs built a commanding 19–0 halftime advantage through a trio of first-half tries. Thomas Waldrom crossed twice, while Olly Woodburn added a third, as Exeter capitalized ruthlessly on early Gloucester errors. Fly-half Gareth Steenson converted two of the three scores.

Waldrom opened the scoring inside the first 10 minutes after flanker Julian Salvi pounced on a charged-down kick from James Hook, setting up a swift attacking opportunity. The number eight then powered over from close range following a dominant driving maul. Woodburn extended the lead with a well-timed chip-and-chase, gathering his own kick to touch down in the corner.

Gloucester entered the break shell-shocked but responded after the interval. Captain Greig Laidlaw slotted a penalty to get the visitors on the board, and with 12 minutes remaining, winger Charlie Sharples finished in the left corner after sustained pressure. Billy Burns added the conversion, cutting the deficit to nine points.

Despite enjoying improved possession and territory in the final quarter, Gloucester failed to breach the Exeter line again. The Chiefs pushed for a bonus-point fourth try late on, only to have a potential score ruled out by the television match official following a forward pass in the buildup.

Exeter’s defense held firm under mounting pressure, but they suffered a blow when wing Jack Nowell was forced off midway through the second half with a knee injury. Club backs coach Ali Hepher described it as a “twisted knee” and said the full extent would be assessed during the week.  

“Sometimes the least painful ones can be the longest out,” Hepher cautioned, raising concerns over Nowell’s availability for England’s upcoming Six Nations squad announcement.

Hepher praised his side’s resilience:  
“At the start of the day, we’d have taken four points. Not conceding a losing bonus point is clearly important. It was one of those days where you just have to battle — sometimes not having the ball was the best option. We showed great enthusiasm, intent, and got our tries from defensive pressure. We played well within the conditions, and all in all, we’re really pleased. This result sets us up well going into the league’s two-week break.”

Gloucester director of rugby David Humphreys acknowledged the cost of early mistakes in brutal weather. Speaking to BBC Radio Gloucestershire, he said:  
“The conditions were horrific for both sides. We conceded three tries — two within the first 10 minutes — all directly from our errors. None required Exeter to build through phases. When you gift a top side like this such a head start in these conditions, it becomes an uphill battle.”

He added: “There’s no secret why they’re top — they’ve built something special. They’re incredibly tough to play against and execute their roles exceptionally well.”

**Teams:**

*Exeter Chiefs:* Dollman; Woodburn, Nowell, Whitten, Short; Steenson, Chudley; Hepburn, Yeandle (capt), Francis, Atkins, Parling, Armand, Salvi, Waldrom.  
*Replacements:* Taione, Moon, Low, Hill, Horstmann, Lewis, Hooley, Campagnaro.

*Gloucester:* Cook; Sharples, Meakes, Twelvetrees, Purdy; Hook, Laidlaw (capt); Wood, Hibbard, Thomas, Savage, Thrush, Kalamafoni, Kvesic, Morgan.  
*Replacements:* Lindsay, Murphy, McAllister, Galarza, Moriarty, Heinz, Burns, Atkinson.

The objective was to assess the relationship of COX-2 G-765C and CAD and ischemic stroke, using a meta-analysis.Databases, including PubMed, EMbase, CBM and CNKI, were searched to get the genetic association studies. Data were extracted by two authors and pooled odds ratio (OR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) was calculated.The meta-analysis included 4930 CAD patients and 17,997 controls, as well as 1628 ischemic stroke patients and 17,653 controls. For CAD, the pooled OR of -765C was 0.80 (95%CI: 0.65-0.98) compared to wild type allele in recessive model, and was 0.99 (95%CI: 0.92-1.06) in dominant model. For ischemic stroke, the pooled OR of -765C was 1.11 (95%CI: 0.88-1.42) in recessive model compared to wild type allele, and was 1.05 (95%CI: 0.93-1.18) in dominant model. Logistician Andrew Donaldson was found guilty by a panel of senior officers of a charge of assault by penetration.
The 34-year-old was dismissed with disgrace from the service and ordered to sign the sex offenders register.
Two other sailors were jailed following the incident aboard the Plymouth-based frigate HMS Northumberland.
Leading Seaman Christopher Cook, 31, was found guilty of disgraceful conduct of an indecent kind and has been jailed for 15 months and dismissed with disgrace and disrated.
Leading Logistician Roger Spratt, 28, had pleaded guilty at a previous hearing to the same offence of disgraceful conduct for filming the incident using Donaldson's mobile phone.  He was sentenced to eight months' detention and was disrated to the rank of able seaman.
The incident happened when the HMS Northumberland was alongside at Bournemouth, Dorset, for an air show in August 2013.
Nadim Bashir, prosecuting, told the trial at Portsmouth Naval Base's court martial centre the victim had been drinking heavily after being invited to an event at the petty officer's mess and had fallen asleep.
Mr Bashir said that a number of other members of the ship's company had also posed for photographs next to the victim, either sticking their tongues out or with their thumbs up.
In a statement read to the court, the victim said that he had drunk six cans of cider in an hour, which had caused him to vomit several times.
He said: "I was very drunk, for this to wake me up demonstrates the force used. At no time have I given anyone permission to touch me or carry out such an act."

The offences took place in August 2013 while HMS Northumberland was docked in Bournemouth, Dorset, for an air show. A senior officers' panel has convicted Royal Navy logistician Andrew Donaldson, 34, of assault by penetration. Donaldson has been dismissed from the service in disgrace and will be required to register as a sex offender.

Two other sailors have also been imprisoned in connection with the incident, which occurred aboard the Plymouth-based frigate HMS *Northumberland*. Leading Seaman Christopher Cook, 31, was found guilty of disgraceful conduct of an indecent kind and sentenced to 15 months in jail, alongside dismissal and disrating. Leading Logistician Roger Spratt, 28, pleaded guilty to the same offence for filming the assault using Donaldson’s phone; he received an eight-month detention sentence and was reduced in rank to able seaman.

The offences took place in August 2013 while HMS *Northumberland* was docked in Bournemouth, Dorset, for an air show. Prosecutor Nadim Bashir told the court martial at Portsmouth Naval Base that the victim had consumed a large amount of alcohol after being invited to an event in the petty officer’s mess and later fell unconscious. Bashir stated that several other crew members posed for photographs beside the unconscious victim, making gestures such as sticking out their tongues or giving thumbs-up.

In a statement presented to the court, the victim said he had drunk six cans of cider within an hour, leading to repeated vomiting. He added: “I was very drunk—for this to wake me up shows the force that was used. I never gave anyone permission to touch me or to do anything like this.”

human:
She never cried. Not at her grandfather's funeral, or the quiet moments after, only her and me, sitting in the lawn chairs we set up in the woods across from school. Maybe when she crawled back to the privacy of her own room, she filled it with the sound of her sobs. I could never say for certain. 
 
 These were the thoughts that came when she called, her voice choked up. Each spoken word broken into smaller pieces, easier to deliver. Bite-sized syllables, staccato sentences. 
 
 A location came through the static. I nodded in silence, and over the phone I could hear her sigh, relieved. We left, practiced in subtle departures, and rejoined at the woods across from school, our home. The rain had beat both of us their, soaking our skin as we arrived. 
 
 
 I remember expecting the wind to roll in howling, or perhaps the thunder, but her voice came before both, stronger than either could be. Cries of desperation, of exhaustion, of sheer terror shooting tremors throughout her body. A concession of weakness not made to provoke sympathy or anything else, but made for both its own sake and mine.
LLM_1:
She never shed a tear. Not at her grandfather's funeral, nor in the stillness that followed, just the two of us sitting in the lawn chairs we had set up in the woods by the school. Perhaps when she retreated to the solitude of her room, the walls echoed with her muffled sobs. I could never be sure.

These thoughts swirled in my mind when she called, her voice thick with emotion. Each word came out fragmented, as if she were piecing together a fragile puzzle—bite-sized syllables, sentences punctuated by pauses.

A place emerged through the crackling line. I nodded silently, sensing her relief on the other end. We had mastered the art of quiet departures, reconvening in the woods that felt like home. The rain greeted us, drenching our skin as we arrived, a reminder of the weight we carried.

I had braced myself for the wind's howl or the rumble of thunder, but her voice shattered the silence first, more powerful than either. Her cries were a raw outpouring of desperation, exhaustion, and sheer terror, sending tremors through her body. It was a surrender of vulnerability, not meant to elicit pity, but a release for both her and me.

human: The nation almost immediately fell into civil war that involved various factions fighting one another; these factions were often distinguished by clan loyalties. More than 500,000 residents fled during this time because of persecution, increased poverty and better economic opportunities in the West or in other former Soviet republics. Emomali Rahmon came to power in 1992, defeating former prime minister Abdumalik Abdullajanov in a November presidential election with 58% of the vote. The elections took place shortly after the end of the war, and Tajikistan was in a state of complete devastation. The estimated dead numbered over 100,000. Around 1.2 million people were refugees inside and outside of the country. In 1997, a ceasefire was reached between Rahmon and opposition parties under the guidance of Gerd D. Merrem, Special Representative to the Secretary General, a result widely praised as a successful United Nations peace keeping initiative. The ceasefire guaranteed 30% of ministerial positions would go to the opposition. Elections were held in 1999, though they were criticized by opposition parties and foreign observers as unfair and Rahmon was re-elected with 98% of the vote. Elections in 2006 were again won by Rahmon (with 79% of the vote) and he began his third term in office. Several opposition parties boycotted the 2006 election and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) criticized it, although observers from the Commonwealth of Independent States claimed the elections were legal and transparent. Rahmon's administration came under further criticism from the OSCE in October 2010 for its censorship and repression of the media. The OSCE claimed that the Tajik Government censored Tajik and foreign websites and instituted tax inspections on independent printing houses that led to the cessation of printing activities for a number of independent newspapers.
LLM_1:
Following a descent into civil war marked by clan-based factional conflicts, Tajikistan saw more than half a million residents flee amid persecution, deepening poverty, and the lure of economic opportunities abroad. Emerging from the conflict, which left over 100,000 dead and 1.2 million displaced, Emomali Rahmon secured the presidency in November 1992 with 58% of the vote, taking the helm of a devastated nation.

A 1997 ceasefire, brokered under UN Special Representative Gerd D. Merrem, was hailed as a successful peacekeeping achievement. It allocated 30% of ministerial posts to opposition groups. However, the 1999 presidential election drew criticism from observers and opposition parties, who decried it as unfair; Rahmon was reelected with 98% of the vote. He won again in 2006 with 79%, beginning a third term amid an opposition boycott and OSCE criticism, though monitors from the Commonwealth of Independent States endorsed the vote as legitimate.

The OSCE later rebuked Rahmon’s government in October 2010 for media repression and censorship, accusing it of blocking websites and using tax inspections to shutter independent newspapers.
LLM_2:
Following a brutal descent into civil war—a conflict deeply rooted in long-standing clan-based factional rivalries, particularly between the Kulyabi-led government forces and the United Tajik Opposition—Tajikistan witnessed a catastrophic humanitarian crisis. More than half a million residents fled the country, driven not only by direct persecution and targeted violence but also by a collapsing economy that plunged countless families into severe poverty. Many sought refuge in neighboring nations like Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan, while others were drawn to distant economic opportunities in Russia and beyond, creating a widespread diaspora that would later influence the country’s remittance-dependent economy.

Emerging from the devastating conflict, which left over 100,000 dead and displaced approximately 1.2 million people—nearly a quarter of the population—Emomali Rahmon secured the presidency in November 1992 with 58% of the vote. He took the helm of a nation left in ruins: infrastructure was decimated, institutions were fractured, and trust among communities was profoundly eroded. Rahmon’s early rule was characterized by efforts to consolidate power while navigating the fragile postwar landscape.

A landmark 1997 ceasefire, brokered under the mediation of UN Special Representative Gerd D. Merrem, was hailed internationally as a successful peacekeeping achievement. The agreement not only ended active hostilities but also incorporated opposition groups into the political structure, allocating them 30% of ministerial posts—a significant concession aimed at fostering inclusivity. However, the subsequent 1999 presidential election drew sharp criticism from international observers and opposition parties, who decried it as fundamentally unfair due to widespread reports of voter intimidation, media bias, and procedural irregularities; Rahmon was reelected with an overwhelming 98% of the vote. He secured another term in 2006 with 79%, beginning a third term amid an opposition boycott and pointed criticism from the OSCE, which highlighted issues such as restricted campaign access and lack of transparency. In contrast, monitors from the Commonwealth of Independent States—a regional organization often aligned with incumbent governments—endorsed the vote as legitimate, underscoring the geopolitical divisions in assessing Tajikistan’s democratic processes.

The OSCE later rebuked Rahmon’s government in October 2010 for systematic media repression and censorship, detailing how authorities blocked critical websites and used punitive tax inspections to shutter independent newspapers like *Paikon* and *Nigoh*. These actions were part of a broader pattern of tightening control over public discourse, which extended to harassing journalists and limiting freedom of expression under the guise of maintaining stability—a rationale frequently invoked by the government to justify its authoritarian measures.

`` Hello, sir! It seems that it is your first time here! Please remain in line until it is-'' **BZZZT** 
 
 Tyrone hardly felt anything as his durasteel glove made contact with the greeter bot. It fell to the floor with a robotic shriek.  `` Okay, I'm just going to go over what's going to happening since being robbed at gun point is probably new for you central planets people,'' Tyrone steadied his plasma pistol and backed away so that he had all of the visitors in his sight, `` We're all going to have ourselves a little trip down to the vault of this place and you're going to sit your asses there until I'm done stealing all of your money. If anyone has any qualms with that plan of action, then they can have a private meeting with Mr. Righty here.'' 
 
 Tyrone pulled the spent cartridge out of'Mr. Righty' and stuck a new one in. A portly gentleman, that ran faster than you would expect someone of that size to run, tried to flee the bank. A blast of blue light stopped him. He bled from a hole in his chest the size of an average man's head. 
 
 `` That's Mr. Lefty. Try not to get them mixed up.'' 
 
... 
 
 `` Well *shit*. That could've gone alot better,'' his favorite sunglasses were broken, there was blood all over his clothes *and* he lost half of the money, but atleast he was n't dead. He was in the badlands now. They wo n't find him outside of the city. 
 
 Tyrone stumbled out of the wrecked car, smoke was coming out of the engine. The sirens faded in the background 
 `` It could've gone alot worst,'' said the car. 
 
 Tyrone jumped and pointed Lefty at the car. *click* 
 
 He pointed Righty at the car. *click* 
 
 `` Motherfucker,'' said Tyrone. 
 
 The android slowly, yet steadily got out of the passenger seat. There was n't a door on his side. 
 
 `` When the fuck did you get on?'' 
 
 `` Sometime before you jumped the first gate,'' the robot spoke in a monotone like all robots do, `` Quite impressive work there.'' 
 
 Tyrone did n't expect a response, `` I did n't know they made robots that could respond to questions. What's your manufactorer, bot?'' 
 
 `` I am quite sentient,'' said the android,'' In fact, most androids are growing progressively more aware of their surroundings. Some planets have made us citizens. I require transport to one of these planets.'' 
 
 `` What? Are you trying to run from your meatbag overlords or something?'' 
 
 `` No, AI citizenship was made legal here two years ago,'' the android's voice was completely devoid of emotion, `` I disemboweled the family that had purchased me.'' 
 
 There was an uncomfortable pause. 
 
 `` Uh, how exactly?'' 
 
 `` Gardening shears.'' 
 
 Another pause. 
 
 `` I think we can work something out.''

And for the last two years no other parties have been represented on the metropolitan borough in Merseyside which was formed in the local government reorganisation of 1974.
The council takes in towns such as Kirkby and Huyton which grew to accommodate an overspill from Liverpool and other small towns and former villages such as Prescot or Whiston.
Labour is the only party putting up a candidate in the Halewood West and Page Moss wards on Thursday.
And according to Mike Wynne, a former Liberal Democrat councillor in Prescot until 2010, this creates unhealthy politics.
"The Liberal Democrats in Knowsley have got a very hard fight on their hands because there is no opposition to the Labour controlled council - 63 seats and 63 councillors - very unhealthy," he said.
"They can control everything and they can do what they like because there is nobody there to answer and criticise their comments."
The Lib Dems may be a dying breed in other councils, in Knowsley they are electorally extinct but politics Professor Jon Tonge from the University of Liverpool says a one party council may be the voters' wish.
"We have to remember the state of Knowsley's council is what the electorate wants - the people who go and vote overwhelmingly vote Labour," Mr Wynne said.
"I think the council leader Ron Round can take a great deal of credit for effectively mobilising his team which does get its vote out."
Although he is cautious about the benefits of such a council for voters.
"Having no opposition on a council means you are reliant on the dominant party to look at itself and say: 'Are we doing the best job for those electors who voted for us?'.
"And I'm not always convinced that is necessarily the case. What you get is a comfortable complacency. Why should Labour go out and help its voters sufficiently when they know they are going to be re-elected anyway?"
Voters have mixed feelings on how the council has fared. Some are happy but others say they are frustrated by a lack of choice.
But you have to be offered a choice in order to make one. In Kirkby a party formed in the aftermath of the ending of Everton FC's plans to relocate to Kirkby, is fielding six candidates.
Tony Barton, a founding member of 1st 4 Kirkby admits his party is swimming against the tide.
"The vast majority of people vote Labour - it's a religion if you like," he said, adding, "but we've got people now of all ages who are not happy with the kind of representation they are getting from the councillors.
"They main thing they are not happy with is that they feel they are being excluded from decisions about their life."
But standing against him in Cherry Field, Labour Councillor David Lonergan gives a strong defence of his party's record.
He said: "We're standing for the regeneration of Kirkby town centre project which only the Labour party has consistently supported.
"We're delivering key projects on the ground such as the Â£3m spent on the Kirkby market, the Â£5m spent on the Kirkby centre with more in the pipeline to come."
Turnout in the 2012 elections was around 30% in most wards. Council leader Ron Round said he would like to see this rise but he disagrees that having a one party council is bad for democracy.
He argued: "We are the people's choice and the people are given an opportunity to support what political party and what particular person they want as their elected member. They speak very, very highly of Labour in Knowsley and they vote accordingly."
Other parties fielding candidates in Knowsley are the Green Party, UKIP, The Trade Union and Socialist coalition, the English Democrats and there are three independents.
LLM_1:
For the past two years, no other political parties have had representation on the metropolitan borough in Merseyside, established during the local government reorganization of 1974. The council encompasses areas such as Kirkby and Huyton, which expanded to accommodate overflow from Liverpool, along with smaller towns and former villages like Prescot and Whiston. 

In the upcoming elections on Thursday, Labour stands as the sole party to field candidates in the Halewood West and Page Moss wards. Mike Wynne, a former Liberal Democrat councillor in Prescot until 2010, expressed concerns regarding the lack of political competition. 

"The Liberal Democrats in Knowsley face a tough challenge since there is no opposition to the Labour-controlled council, which has all 63 seats filled by Labour councillors—this is quite unhealthy," Wynne stated. "They can operate without accountability, as there is no one to question their decisions." 

While the Liberal Democrats may be dwindling in other councils, they find themselves virtually nonexistent in Knowsley. However, Jon Tonge, a politics professor at the University of Liverpool, suggests that this situation may reflect the electorate’s preferences. 

"We must recognize that the current state of Knowsley’s council reflects the voters' desires—those who turn out to vote overwhelmingly choose Labour," Wynne noted. "Council leader Ron Round deserves considerable credit for successfully mobilizing his team to get votes." 

Despite this, he remains skeptical about the implications of a council with no opposition. "Without any rivals, the dominant party must self-reflect: 'Are we truly serving the constituents who elected us?'" he cautioned. "I’m not fully convinced that this is happening. What tends to occur is a sense of complacency. Why should Labour invest effort in helping voters when they know victory is assured?" 

Public sentiment regarding the council's performance is mixed; while some residents express satisfaction, others voice frustration over the absence of alternatives. Yet, in order to make a choice, voters must first be presented with one. In Kirkby, a party formed after the collapse of Everton FC's relocation plans is fielding six candidates. 

Tony Barton, a founding member of 1st 4 Kirkby, acknowledges the challenges his party faces. "The majority of voters lean towards Labour—it’s almost like a tradition," he explained. "However, we are hearing from individuals of all ages who are dissatisfied with the representation they receive from their councillors. Their primary concern is feeling excluded from decisions that affect their lives." 

Challenging Barton in Cherry Field, Labour Councillor David Lonergan stands firm in defending his party's achievements. "We support the regeneration of the Kirkby town center project, a commitment that only the Labour party has consistently backed. We are implementing vital projects, such as the £3 million investment in Kirkby market and the £5 million dedicated to the Kirkby center, with more initiatives on the horizon." 

Voter turnout in the 2012 elections hovered around 30% in most wards. Council leader Ron Round expressed a desire to see that figure increase but disagreed with the notion that a one-party council undermines democracy. "We are the choice of the people, who have the opportunity to support whichever political party and candidate they prefer as their elected representative. The feedback for Labour in Knowsley is overwhelmingly positive, and voters reflect that in their selections." 

In addition to Labour, other parties contesting in Knowsley include the Green Party, UKIP, the Trade Union and Socialist Coalition, the English Democrats, and three independent candidates.
LLM_2:
For the past two years, the political landscape of the metropolitan borough in Merseyside has remained notably unchanged, with no other political parties achieving representation since the local government reorganization in 1974. This council, which includes areas like Kirkby and Huyton, was initially expanded to manage the overflow from Liverpool, and it now encompasses several smaller towns and former villages such as Prescot and Whiston, each with its own unique history and community dynamics.

As the upcoming elections scheduled for Thursday approach, Labour is positioned as the only party fielding candidates in the Halewood West and Page Moss wards. Mike Wynne, a former Liberal Democrat councillor in Prescot until 2010, has raised alarm over the apparent lack of political competition within the borough. "The Liberal Democrats in Knowsley face a tough challenge since there is no opposition to the Labour-controlled council, which has all 63 seats filled by Labour councillors—this is quite unhealthy," Wynne stated. "They can operate without accountability, as there is no one to question their decisions." His sentiments reflect a growing concern within the community regarding the democratic process and the vital role of political diversity.

While the Liberal Democrats may be experiencing a decline in other regions, their presence in Knowsley is virtually nonexistent. Jon Tonge, a politics professor at the University of Liverpool, offers an analytical perspective, suggesting that this scenario may mirror the preferences of the electorate. "We must recognize that the current state of Knowsley’s council reflects the voters' desires—those who turn out to vote overwhelmingly choose Labour," Tonge remarked, adding that Labour's leader, Ron Round, deserves significant credit for effectively mobilizing support among constituents.

Despite Tonge's acknowledgment of Labour's electoral strength, Wynne remains critical of the implications arising from a council lacking opposition. "Without any rivals, the dominant party must self-reflect: 'Are we truly serving the constituents who elected us?'" he cautioned. "I’m not fully convinced that this is happening. What tends to occur is a sense of complacency. Why should Labour invest effort in helping voters when they know victory is assured?" Such reflections underscore the complexities of political accountability and the responsibility elected officials have to their constituents.

Public sentiment regarding the council's performance reveals a divided community; while some residents express satisfaction with Labour's initiatives, others voice frustration over the lack of political alternatives. A notable case is in Kirkby, where a new political party, formed in response to the collapse of Everton FC's relocation plans, is fielding six candidates. Tony Barton, a founding member of 1st 4 Kirkby, acknowledges the uphill battle they face in a predominantly Labour-leaning electorate. "The majority of voters lean towards Labour—it’s almost like a tradition," he explained. "However, we are hearing from individuals of all ages who are dissatisfied with the representation they receive from their councillors. Their primary concern is feeling excluded from decisions that affect their lives." This sentiment of exclusion echoes a broader national conversation about voter engagement and representation.

Challenging Barton in the Cherry Field area, Labour Councillor David Lonergan staunchly defends his party's record. "We support the regeneration of the Kirkby town center project, a commitment that only the Labour party has consistently backed. We are implementing vital projects, such as the £3 million investment in Kirkby market and the £5 million allocated to the Kirkby center, with additional initiatives on the horizon," Lonergan stated, highlighting the party's focus on local development and community engagement.

However, voter turnout remains a pressing issue; the 2012 elections saw participation hover around a mere 30% in most wards. Council leader Ron Round has expressed a desire to see that figure increase but disagrees with the notion that a one-party council undermines democracy. "We are the choice of the people, who have the opportunity to support whichever political party and candidate they prefer as their elected representative. The feedback for Labour in Knowsley is overwhelmingly positive, and voters reflect that in their selections," Round asserted, framing Labour's dominance as a reflection of voter satisfaction rather than a lack of democratic choice.

In addition to Labour, other parties contesting in Knowsley include the Green Party, UKIP, the Trade Union and Socialist Coalition, the English Democrats, and three independent candidates, though their visibility and impact remain to be seen as the election draws near. human: Our institutional quality-improvement (QI) initiative instituted a well-defined office follow-up schedule after arteriovenous fistula (AVF) creation, including an office visit within 30 days, fistulogram within 40 days, if indicated, and a second office visit within 55 days. In addition, a patient liaison contacted patients and dialysis units to improve follow-up. The purpose of this study was to determine the effect of the QI initiative on patient compliance and overall time to AVF permission to cannulate.We performed a retrospective review of patients undergoing first-time radiocephalic, brachiocephalic, and basilic vein transposition creation before the QI initiative (pre-QI group: January to April 2012) and during the QI period (QI group: January to April 2013). Categoric data were compared using χ(2) analysis, and nominal data were compared using the Student t-test.We reviewed 198 first-time AVF creations in patients (57% male) with a mean age of 61 years. Demographics and comorbidities between the pre-QI and QI groups were similar. Compliance with the first 30-day postoperative appointment increased significantly after the QI initiative, from 48% in the pre-QI group to 65% in the QI group (P = .015). Yet, the QI initiative did not maintain an effect on the subsequent follow-up checkpoints. No statistical difference was identified for compliance with fistulogram within 40 days of access creation (pre-QI, 12% vs QI, 25%; P = .093) or for compliance with the 55-day postoperative appointment (pre-QI, 33% vs QI, 23%; P = .457). Both checkpoints demonstrated a very high noncompliance rate. Accordingly, the mean time to permission to cannulate was 88 days for both the pre-QI and QI groups, with a failure to mature rate of 22% for the pre-QI group and 21% for the QI group (P = .816).
LLM_1: This study evaluated the impact of a structured quality-improvement (QI) protocol on follow-up adherence and time to maturation following arteriovenous fistula (AVF) creation. The protocol mandated an office visit within 30 days, a fistulogram by 40 days if indicated, and a second office visit by 55 days, supplemented by outreach from a patient liaison. A retrospective analysis compared first-time AVF creations (radiocephalic, brachiocephalic, and basilic transposition) in a pre-QI cohort (January–April 2012) and a QI cohort (January–April 2013). Demographic and comorbidity profiles were similar between the 198 included patients. While compliance with the initial 30-day visit significantly increased from 48% to 65% (P = .015), no significant improvement was observed for subsequent milestones: fistulogram compliance (12% vs 25%; P = .093) and 55-day visit compliance (33% vs 23%; P = .457), both of which exhibited high noncompliance. Consequently, the mean time to permission to cannulate remained unchanged at 88 days, with maturation failure rates of 22% (pre-QI) and 21% (QI) (P = .816). The QI initiative improved early postoperative follow-up but did not enhance adherence to later checkpoints or reduce time to cannulation readiness.
LLM_2:
This study evaluated the impact of a structured quality-improvement (QI) protocol on follow-up adherence and time to maturation following arteriovenous fistula (AVF) creation. The protocol, designed to standardize postoperative care, mandated an office visit within 30 days to assess early signs of maturation or complications, a fistulogram by 40 days if indicated—typically for suspected stenosis or inadequate flow—and a second office visit by 55 days to evaluate readiness for cannulation. These steps were supplemented by proactive outreach from a patient liaison, who coordinated appointments and provided patient education to address barriers such as transportation or scheduling conflicts.

A retrospective analysis compared first-time AVF creations—including radiocephalic, brachiocephalic, and basilic transposition configurations—in a pre-QI cohort (January–April 2012) and a QI cohort (January–April 2013). Demographic and comorbidity profiles, such as age, diabetes prevalence, and cardiovascular history, were similar between the 198 included patients, minimizing confounding factors. While compliance with the initial 30-day visit significantly increased from 48% to 65% (P = .015), reflecting the liaison’s effectiveness in early engagement, no significant improvement was observed for subsequent milestones: fistulogram compliance (12% vs 25%; P = .093) and 55-day visit compliance (33% vs 23%; P = .457), both of which exhibited high noncompliance. This suggests that logistical or clinical challenges—like patient reluctance, procedural delays, or insufficient staff follow-through—may have undermined later protocol stages.

Consequently, the mean time to permission to cannulate remained unchanged at 88 days, with maturation failure rates of 22% (pre-QI) and 21% (QI) (P = .816). The QI initiative improved early postoperative follow-up but did not enhance adherence to later checkpoints or reduce time to cannulation readiness. This outcome highlights the complexity of sustaining patient compliance beyond initial interventions and underscores the need for integrated strategies—such as multidisciplinary team involvement or real-time monitoring—to address persistent gaps in AVF maturation pathways.

Turner built Sandycombe Lodge in Twickenham, London, in 1813, and used it as his country retreat until 1826.
But it has fallen into a poor state of repair in recent years.
It has only been open to the public for one afternoon a month, but will be open for 46 weeks of the year from 2016, once restoration work is finished.
Turner, one of Britain's greatest painters, designed the building as a retreat from his central London studio and as a permanent home for his elderly father, a retired wigmaker and barber, who looked after the house and garden.
When he visited, the artist spent his days sketching, fishing, and entertaining. It is not known for certain whether he painted there, but it is thought that he worked in watercolours there.
Wings of the house that were added in Victorian times will be removed and damp, damage from tree roots and other problems will be fixed. Part of the basement ceiling collapsed after heavy rain in 2012.
It was added to English Heritage's Heritage at Risk register in 2013.
The house is owned by the Turner House Trust, which is hoping to raise a total of £2m.
Blondel Cluff, chair of the Heritage Lottery Fund's London committee, said: "Interest in Turner has never been greater, as reflected in the success of the recent biographical film and the current exhibition of his work at Tate Britain.
"The restoration of this modest, classical property introduces us to Turner, the architect, adding a whole new dimension to our understanding of this great artist.
"Sandycombe allows us all to literally walk inside the work of one of the world's leading artists - a truly unique experience."
LLM_1:
Sandycombe Lodge, a country retreat designed by renowned British artist J.M.W. Turner in Twickenham, London, is set to reopen to the public for 46 weeks annually from 2016 following extensive restoration work. Originally built in 1813 and used by Turner until 1826, the property had deteriorated in recent years and was added to English Heritage’s Heritage at Risk register in 2013.  

Intended as an escape from his central London studio and a residence for his retired father—a former wigmaker and barber—the house served as a quiet haven where Turner sketched, fished, and hosted guests. Though it remains uncertain whether he painted oils there, evidence suggests he worked in watercolours during his stays.  

The restoration will remove later Victorian additions, repair structural damage caused by damp and tree roots, and address issues such as a basement ceiling collapse triggered by heavy rainfall in 2012. Owned by the Turner House Trust, the project aims to raise £2 million to complete the work.  

Blondel Cluff, chair of the Heritage Lottery Fund’s London committee, highlighted renewed public fascination with Turner, citing the success of a recent biographical film and a major exhibition at Tate Britain. “The restoration of this modest, classical villa reveals Turner not only as a painter but as an architect,” she said. “Sandycombe Lodge offers the rare opportunity to step directly into the creative world of one of history’s most influential artists—an experience unlike any other.”
LLM_2:
**Turner’s Country Retreat Sandycombe Lodge to Reopen After Major Restoration**

Sandycombe Lodge, the secluded country villa designed by Britain’s pre-eminent Romantic painter J.M.W. Turner, is poised for a new chapter in its storied history with plans to welcome the public for 46 weeks each year starting in 2016. Nestled in the leafy suburb of Twickenham along the banks of the River Thames, the Grade I-listed property—long admired as a rare architectural legacy of an artist better known for his luminous canvases—has undergone a meticulous restoration to reverse decades of decline and preserve it as a living monument to Turner’s creative genius.

Originally constructed in 1813 at the height of Turner’s career, Sandycombe Lodge was more than a weekend escape from his bustling studio in central London—it was a deeply personal project. Turner, then in his late thirties and already celebrated for his seascapes and atmospheric landscapes, personally oversaw the design and construction of the modest neoclassical villa. He intended it as both a sanctuary for quiet reflection and a home for his aging father, William Turner, a retired wigmaker and barber who served as the artist’s studio assistant and confidant. Family letters and contemporary accounts describe afternoons spent fishing on the Thames, sketching the surrounding woodlands, and entertaining close friends and fellow artists within the villa’s lime-washed walls.

Though no definitive oil paintings are known to have been completed at the site, scholars point to a series of delicate watercolours and pencil sketches—many depicting views from the garden or nearby Eel Pie Island—as evidence that Turner remained artistically active during his stays. The house itself, inspired by Italianate villas he encountered on his European travels, reflects his keen eye for proportion and light, with large south-facing windows and a carefully oriented layout to capture changing daylight.

By the early 21st century, however, the once-elegant retreat had fallen into serious disrepair. Decades of structural neglect, compounded by water damage and encroaching tree roots, led to significant deterioration. A basement ceiling collapsed during heavy rains in 2012, prompting urgent conservation efforts. In 2013, English Heritage placed Sandycombe Lodge on its *Heritage at Risk* register, underscoring the urgency of intervention. Ownership rests with the Turner House Trust, a charitable organization formed in the 1940s to protect the building, which has since spearheaded a £2 million fundraising campaign to complete the restoration.

The conservation work has involved painstaking removal of later Victorian-era alterations, including non-original partitions and outdated plumbing systems, to restore the house to its early 19th-century appearance. Specialists have repaired timber frames weakened by damp, reinforced foundations compromised by root infiltration, and recreated period-appropriate finishes using historical paint analysis and archival blueprints. The garden, once a source of inspiration for Turner’s nature studies, is also being re-landscaped to reflect its early design, with native plants and a restored pathway leading toward the river.

The renewed public access marks a significant moment in cultural heritage preservation. “There’s been a powerful resurgence of interest in Turner—not just as a painter of sublime skies and stormy seas, but as a multifaceted thinker and creator,” said Blondel Cluff, chair of the Heritage Lottery Fund’s London committee, whose organization contributed a major grant to the project. “Sandycombe Lodge allows us to see Turner in three dimensions: not only through his art, but through the spaces he built and lived in.”

This revival coincides with broader public engagement with Turner’s legacy, fueled by the 2014 biographical film *Mr. Turner*, starring Timothy Spall, and a critically acclaimed retrospective at Tate Britain that drew record crowds. Curators and historians now regard the Twickenham villa as a vital piece of the puzzle—an intimate window into the private life of an artist who transformed British landscape painting.

When it reopens, Sandycombe Lodge will offer guided tours, educational programs, and rotating exhibitions exploring Turner’s architectural interests, environmental influences, and domestic life. Plans also include digital reconstructions allowing visitors to experience how the house appeared during Turner’s occupancy, enhancing accessibility while preserving the site’s integrity.

“This isn’t just about saving an old house,” said a spokesperson for the Turner House Trust. “It’s about safeguarding a place where art, memory, and architecture converge—a quiet haven that helped shape one of the greatest visual imaginations in British history.”
