Yusuke Katayama played a game of cat and mouse with the authorities, leading them to make numerous wrongful arrests.
He threatened a massacre at a comic book event, as well as to attack a school attended by the grandchildren of Japan's Emperor Akihito.
Katayama's campaign highlighted the difficulties the country's police force has had in dealing with cyber crime.
"He committed the crime, and the purpose of it was [for police] to make wrongful arrests," said presiding judge Katsunori Ohno at Tokyo District Court, adding that Katayama's actions had been "vicious".
Throughout 2012, the 32-year-old used a virus to gain control of strangers' computers. He then issued threats - which appeared to come from the computer's owner - and a series of riddles that captured the attention of the national media.
Among the other threats made by Katayama - who went by the alias Demon Killer - was one to attack a plane.
The case highlighted the Japanese police's tendency to extract confessions from suspects, as four people owned up to crimes which the National Police Agency (NPA) later admitted they did not commit.
Computers belonging to each had been infected with a Trojan Horse virus, introduced via a link on the popular Japanese chat forum 2channel.
The NPA's chief apologised, acknowledging his force had been tricked by the hacker, and promising his cyber crime unit would improve.
Police held one falsely suspected person for several weeks before media and a cyber crime expert received anonymous messages containing information that investigators conceded could only have been known by the real culprit.
Katayama had taunted police in emails that sent them all over Japan.
In one message, investigators were told to go to Enoshima, an island off Tokyo, and to look for a cat that turned out to be wearing a collar on which was a memory card.
The card held details of the code and malicious program he had used to gain remote control of victim's computers.
In December 2012, the police offered a 3m yen (Â£16,822) reward for information leading to the arrest of the culprit.
But it was the cat that led police to arrest Katayama in February 2013, who was seen on CCTV footage with the animal.
LLM_1:
Yusuke Katayama, 32, used a virus to hijack private computers in 2012, issuing threats—including warnings of a massacre at a comic event and an attack on a school attended by Emperor Akihito's grandchildren—that were traced back to the infected devices. Operating under the alias "Demon Killer," he also threatened to target an airplane.

The case underscored the police's reliance on suspect confessions, as four individuals admitted to crimes the National Police Agency later acknowledged they did not commit. This paper explores the task of finding discrete adversarial examples for (current) dialog models in a post hoc manner (i.e., once models are trained). In particular, the authors propose an optimization procedure for crafting inputs (utterances) that trigger trained dialog models to respond in an egregious manner.

This line of research is interesting as it relates to real-world problems that our models face before they can be safely deployed. The paper is easy to read, nicely written, and the proposed optimization method seems reasonable. The study also seems clear and the results are fairly robust across three datasets. It was also interesting to study datasets which, a priori, seem like they would not contain much egregious content (e.g., Ubuntu "help desk" conversations).

My main question is that after reading the paper, I'm not sure that one has an answer to the question that the authors set out to answer. In particular, are our current seq2seq models for dialogs prone to generating egregious responses? On one hand, it seems like models can assign higher-than-average probability to egregious responses. On the other, it is unclear what this means. For example, it seems like the possibility that such a model outputs such an answer in a conversation might still be very small. Quantifying this would be worthwhile.   

Further, one would imagine that a complete dialog system pipeline would contain a collection of different models including a seq2seq model but also others. In that context, is it clear that it's the role of the seq2seq model to limit egregious responses? 

A related aspect is that it would have been interesting to explore a bit more the reasons that cause the generation of such egregious responses. It is unclear how representative is the example that is detailed ("I will kill you" in Section 5.3). Are other examples using words in other contexts? Also, it seems reasonable that if one wants to avoid such answers, countermeasures (e.g., in designing the loss or in adding common sense knowledge) have to be considered.


Other comments:

- I am not sure of the value of Section 3. In particular, it seems like the presentation of the paper would be as effective if this section was summarized in a short paragraph (and perhaps detailed in an appendix).
  
- Section 3.1, "continuous relaxation of the input embedding", what does that mean since the embedding already lives in continuous space?
  
- I understand that your study only considers (when optimizing for egregious responses)) dialogs that are 1-turn long. I wonder if you could increase hit rates by crafting multiple inputs at once.
  
- In Section 4.3, you fix G (size of the word search space) to 100. Have you tried different values? Do you know if larger Gs could have an impact of reported hit metrics?

- In Table 3, results from the first column (normal, o-greedy) seem interesting. Wouldn't one expect that the model can actually generate (almost) all normal responses? Your results indicate that for Ubuntu models can only generate between 65% and 82% of actual (test) responses. Do you know what in the Ubuntu corpus leads to such a result?
  
- In Section 5.3, you seem to say that the lack of diversity of greedy-decoded sentences is related to the low performance of the "o-greedy" metric. Could this result simply be explained because the model is unlikely to generate sentences that it has never seen before? 

 You could try changing the temperature of the decoding distribution, that should improve diversity and you could then check whether or not that also increases the hit rate of the o-greedy metric.

- Perhaps tailoring the mal lists to each specific dataset would make sense (I understand that there is already some differences in between the mal lists of the different datasets but perhaps building the lists with a particular dataset in mind would yield "better" results).
LLM_1:
This paper investigates the task of discovering discrete adversarial examples for existing dialogue models in a post hoc setting—i.e., after models have been trained. Specifically, the authors introduce an optimization method for crafting input utterances that induce trained dialogue models to produce egregious responses.

The research direction is relevant and timely, addressing practical safety concerns that arise prior to model deployment. The paper is well-written and clear, the proposed optimization approach appears sound, and the experimental design is straightforward, with results that hold robustly across three datasets. It is particularly interesting that the study includes datasets like Ubuntu help-desk conversations, which one might not expect to contain overtly harmful content.

My primary concern is that, after reading the paper, I remain uncertain whether the core research question has been fully answered. The authors set out to examine whether current seq2seq dialogue models are prone to generating egregious responses. While the work shows that such models can assign elevated probability to harmful outputs, the practical implications are unclear. For instance, the actual likelihood of a model producing such a response in a real conversation may remain very low. Quantifying this risk more directly would strengthen the contribution.

Moreover, a full dialogue system typically incorporates multiple components beyond a seq2seq model. In such a pipeline, is it clearly the seq2seq model’s responsibility to suppress egregious responses? This point warrants further discussion.

Additionally, the analysis of why these egregious responses arise could be deepened. The example in Section 5.3 (“I will kill you”) is illustrative, but how representative is it? Are other examples context-dependent or tied to specific lexical triggers? Exploring the underlying causes—and potential countermeasures such as loss function design or commonsense knowledge integration—would add valuable insight.

**Other comments:**

- Section 3 could be condensed into a brief summary in the main text, with details moved to an appendix, without losing clarity.
- In Section 3.1, the phrase “continuous relaxation of the input embedding” is confusing since embeddings already reside in a continuous space. Please clarify.
- The study optimizes over single-turn dialogues. Could crafting multi-turn adversarial inputs increase hit rates?
- In Section 4.3, the word search space size G is fixed at 100. Have you experimented with other values? Could larger G affect the reported metrics?
- Table 3 shows that under normal greedy decoding, the model only reproduces 65–82% of actual Ubuntu test responses. Why is performance not closer to 100%? Is there something distinctive about the Ubuntu corpus that limits generation?
- In Section 5.3, you suggest low diversity in greedy decoding may explain the poor performance of the “o-greedy” metric. Could this simply be because the model rarely generates unseen sentences? Adjusting the decoding temperature might increase diversity—does doing so also raise the o-greedy hit rate?
- Tailoring the malicious word lists (mal lists) per dataset, rather than using slight variations, might improve result relevance.
LLM_2:
This paper investigates the discovery of discrete adversarial examples for trained dialogue models in a post hoc setting. The authors propose an optimization method to craft input utterances that induce models to produce egregious responses. The research addresses timely safety concerns, is well-written, and the approach appears sound, with robust results across three datasets, including Ubuntu help-desk conversations where harmful content is not overt.

However, the core research question—whether current seq2seq dialogue models are prone to generating egregious responses—is not fully resolved. While the work shows models can assign elevated probability to harmful outputs, the practical risk in real conversations remains unclear and should be quantified more directly. Additionally, in full dialogue systems with multiple components, the specific responsibility of the seq2seq model in suppressing such responses warrants further discussion. The analysis of why egregious responses arise could also be deepened beyond the provided example, exploring whether they are context-dependent or tied to specific triggers, and considering countermeasures like loss function design or commonsense knowledge integration.

**Other comments:**

- Section 3 could be condensed in the main text, with details moved to an appendix.
- In Section 3.1, clarify “continuous relaxation of the input embedding,” as embeddings already reside in a continuous space.
- Could multi-turn adversarial inputs increase hit rates?
- In Section 4.3, explore the impact of varying the word search space size G beyond 100.
- In Table 3, explain why greedy decoding only reproduces 65–82% of Ubuntu test responses, and whether corpus characteristics limit generation.
- In Section 5.3, consider if adjusting decoding temperature increases diversity and affects the “o-greedy” hit rate.
- Tailoring malicious word lists per dataset might improve relevance.

human: The mechanisms involving light control of vitamin C content in fruits are not yet fully understood. The present study aimed to evaluate the impact of fruit and leaf shading on ascorbate (AsA) accumulation in tomato fruit and to determine how fruit sugar content (as an AsA precursor) affected AsA content.Cherry tomato plants were grown in a glasshouse. The control treatment (normally irradiated fruits and irradiated leaves) was compared with the whole-plant shading treatment and with leaf or fruit shading treatments in fruits harvested at breaker stage. In a second experiment, the correlation between sugars and AsA was studied during ripening.Fruit shading was the most effective treatment in reducing fruit AsA content. Under normal conditions, AsA and sugar content were correlated and increased with the ripening stage. Reducing fruit irradiance strongly decreased the reduced AsA content (-74 %), without affecting sugars, so that sugar and reduced AsA were no longer correlated. Leaf shading delayed fruit ripening: it increased the accumulation of oxidized AsA in green fruits (+98 %), whereas it decreased the reduced AsA content in orange fruits (-19 %), suggesting that fruit AsA metabolism also depends on leaf irradiance.
LLM_1: The mechanisms by which light regulates vitamin C levels in fruits remain incompletely elucidated. This study investigated the effects of shading fruit and leaves on ascorbate (AsA) accumulation in tomato, and assessed the relationship between fruit sugar content—a precursor to AsA—and AsA levels. Experiments were conducted on cherry tomatoes grown under glasshouse conditions. At the breaker stage, fruits from control plants (with both fruits and leaves irradiated normally) were compared with those subjected to whole-plant shading, fruit-only shading, or leaf-only shading. A subsequent experiment examined correlations between sugars and AsA during ripening. Shading of fruits proved most effective in reducing AsA content. Under control conditions, AsA and sugar levels were positively correlated and increased with ripening. Reduced fruit irradiance markedly lowered reduced AsA content (−74%) without altering sugar concentrations, thereby disrupting the correlation between sugars and reduced AsA. Leaf shading delayed fruit ripening, elevating oxidized AsA in green fruits (+98%) while diminishing reduced AsA in orange fruits (−19%), indicating that AsA metabolism in fruit is also influenced by leaf irradiance.
LLM_2:
**

The precise mechanisms through which light exposure modulates vitamin C (ascorbate, AsA) accumulation in fruits are not yet fully understood, representing a significant gap in postharvest physiology and crop quality research. This study systematically explored how shading different plant organs—specifically fruits and leaves—affects AsA levels in tomato, a model species for fleshy fruit development. Additionally, it evaluated the interplay between fruit sugar content, which serves as a biochemical precursor for AsA synthesis, and AsA accumulation patterns.  

Experiments utilized cherry tomatoes (*Solanum lycopersicum*) cultivated under controlled glasshouse conditions to minimize environmental variability. At the breaker stage—a key transitional phase in ripening—fruits from control plants (exposed to normal irradiation on both fruits and leaves) were analyzed alongside three experimental groups: whole-plant shading, fruit-only shading, and leaf-only shading. A follow-up experiment tracked dynamic correlations between soluble sugars (such as glucose and fructose) and AsA pools across multiple ripening stages.  

Results revealed that shading fruits directly had the most pronounced impact, drastically suppressing AsA accumulation. Under control conditions, AsA and sugar levels exhibited a strong positive correlation, both increasing progressively as fruits matured from green to red. However, when fruit irradiance was reduced, the content of reduced AsA—the biologically active form of vitamin C—plummeted by 74%, whereas sugar concentrations remained unchanged. This decoupling of sugar and reduced AsA suggests that light may regulate AsA synthesis or recycling independently of substrate availability, possibly through photoreceptor-mediated signaling or redox modulation.  

Interestingly, shading leaves alone delayed the overall ripening process, leading to distinct shifts in AsA redox state: oxidized AsA (dehydroascorbate) rose sharply in green fruits (+98%), while reduced AsA declined in orange-stage fruits (−19%). These findings imply that leaf irradiance indirectly influences fruit AsA metabolism, potentially via altered photosynthetic output, hormone signaling, or source-sink nutrient partitioning.  

In summary, light acts through organ-specific pathways to fine-tune vitamin C levels in tomatoes—direct fruit irradiation promotes reduced AsA accumulation in synergy with sugars, whereas leaf light exposure affects ripening timing and AsA redox homeostasis. This highlights the complexity of light-regulated nutrient metabolism in plants and underscores the importance of considering both local and systemic effects in optimizing fruit nutritional quality.

In a statement, the rebels cited "many and large violations" of the ceasefire by the Syrian government as the reason for their move.
Turkey and Russia brokered the ceasefire deal that has mostly held since last Thursday.
The peace talks are due to be held in Astana, Kazakhstan.
"The regime and its allies have continued firing and committed many and large violations," said the statement signed by a number of Syrian rebel groups on Monday.
"As these violations are continuing, the rebel factions announce... the freezing of all discussion linked to the Astana negotiations," they said.
The statement highlighted fighting in the rebel-held region of Wadi Barada near Damascus. In recent weeks the rebels have accused the government and its allies of trying to recapture the area, which supplies water to the capital. The military has denied the allegations.
On New Year's Eve, the United Nations Security Council voted unanimously to welcome the Russia-Turkey efforts to end the Syrian fighting and to organise peace talks.
The new ceasefire deal applies across Syria but excludes the jihadists of so-called Islamic State (IS) and Jabhat Fateh al-Sham (JFS), and the Kurdish YPG militia.
On the one side, Syrian government forces, allied militias and the Russian military.
On the other, the FSA plus several other groups.
The Russian defence ministry named seven "moderate opposition formations" included in the truce as Faylaq al-Sham, Ahrar al-Sham, Jaysh al-Islam, Thuwwar Ahl al-Sham, Jaysh al-Mujahidin, Jaysh Idlib and Jabhah al-Shamiya.
Ahrar al-Sham, which said it had "reservations" about the deal, and Jaysh al-Islam are Islamist groups that Russia has previously described as terrorist organisations.
IS and JFS and the groups affiliated to them are not part of the agreement, according to the Syrian army.
JFS said on Friday it would continue to fight President Assad, with a spokesman saying the political solution under the truce would "reproduce the criminal regime".
Members of the group are currently operating as part of a rebel alliance that controls Idlib province.
The FSA also said the deal did not include the Kurdish Popular Protection Units (YPG).
The militia, which has captured large swathes of north-eastern Syria from IS with US support, is designated a terrorist organisation by Turkey.
The truce is nominally nationwide, although it really only covers the areas where the sides who have signed up have a presence - western Syria.

Signatories to the truce include several rebel formations, among them Islamist groups like Ahrar al-Sham and Jaysh al-Islam—both previously designated as terrorist organizations by Russia. Ahrar al-Sham noted it had reservations about the agreement.

While the Syrian military confirms that IS and JFS are not covered by the ceasefire, JFS stated on Friday it would continue fighting the government of President Bashar al-Assad, rejecting any political solution under the truce as an attempt to “reproduce the criminal regime.” The Free Syrian Army (FSA) separately clarified that the Kurdish YPG—considered a terrorist group by Turkey—is also excluded from the deal.

The United Nations Security Council unanimously endorsed the Russia-Turkey peace initiative on December 31. Although described as nationwide, the ceasefire effectively applies only in western Syria, where the signatory factions operate.

*Reporting contributed by international agencies.*

The Inspectorate of Constabulary (HMIC) move follows continuing concerns about the way police keep records.
The watchdog's inspectors will for the first time turn up at the headquarters of each force without notice.
Inspections are normally arranged several weeks in advance, apart from police cell visits which are conducted jointly with the Prisons Inspectorate.
In a letter to chief constables, Chief Inspector of Constabulary Sir Tom Winsor said: "In future, in relation to crime recording, HMIC will carry out unannounced inspections.
"These will not be confined to those forces in which crime recording was found in 2014 to be especially bad. Every force will be inspected.
"The intensity of each inspection and the aspects of crime recording inspected will be at HMIC's discretion. Forces will be told what is required when the inspectors arrive."
BBC home affairs correspondent Danny Shaw said HMIC was "absolutely withering" in its assessment of the way police were recording crimes and that is why inspectors wanted to go back to forces on an unannounced basis and ensure they have got their practices right.
Last year, an HMIC report said a fifth of crimes reported to police in England and Wales could be going unrecorded by them.
It found that 14 alleged rapes were among the offences that had not been recorded by officers.
The inspection of 13 forces found one report of rape was not recorded because of "workload pressure".
Home Secretary Theresa May said the report exposed "unacceptable failings" by the police.
LLM_1:

In a significant shift from standard procedure, inspectors will arrive without prior notice—a move typically reserved only for joint visits with the Prisons Inspectorate to police cells.

Until now, inspections have been scheduled weeks in advance. But in a letter to chief constables, Chief Inspector Sir Tom Winsor announced that, going forward, all forces will face surprise assessments focused on crime recording, regardless of past performance. The scope and depth of each inspection will be determined solely by HMIC, with forces informed of specific requirements upon the inspectors’ arrival.

BBC home affairs correspondent Danny Shaw described HMIC’s evaluation as “absolutely withering,” underscoring the urgency behind the decision to conduct unannounced visits. The move follows a 2023 report revealing that up to 20% of reported crimes may not have been properly recorded by police. Among the most serious findings was the failure to log 14 alleged rapes, including one case dismissed due to "workload pressure" during an internal review of 13 forces.

Then-Home Secretary Theresa May condemned the lapses as “unacceptable failings,” calling for immediate improvements in accountability and transparency. The new inspection protocol aims to ensure accurate crime data and restore public confidence in policing standards.

I'm fairly average. Both my parents are together and I grew up in a fairly well-adjusted, loving family alongside my older brother. We have never struggled nor wanted for anything, money was n't much of a concern to us though we did have to budget occasionally. I went to good schools and though I struggled to make friends I did have them. 
 
 And they were beautiful. 
 
 I was not unaccustomed to sitting with one of them as they cried or recounted a tale from their home lives while their eyes - albeit sparkling and beautiful - looked utterly dead inside. I listened to the stories of rape that resulted in pregnancy that was terminated after a few swift punches to the gut. I loved my friends and I cared about them and they were always welcome in my home whenever and for however long they needed. But I could n't take it any longer. 
 
 I was being crushed under the weight of all their secrets and stories. I could feel my mind slowly disintegrating as I learned every horrible truth this world had to offer. i began crying alongside my friends, not out of empathy for their plight but because I had heard these horrid things before I did n't want to ever have to hear them again. 
 
 I knew too much about pain without ever having to experience it for myself. In the hallways at school my friends would constantly be complimented on their looks while I stood by their side, burdened with the knowledge of why their eyes shined. 
 
 `` Hey, your hair looks really nice today,'' a boy directed towards me.
LLM_1:
I was ordinary, in the way that only someone raised in quiet comfort can be. My parents stayed together, my childhood was whole, and love came easily in our home—steady, unshaken, shared with my older brother in the hushed rhythms of a life without crisis. We never went without. Money was a background hum, not a scream; we budgeted when needed, but scarcity never clawed at our door. I attended good schools, where I drifted through hallways like a shadow, making friends slowly, awkwardly—but I had them.  

And they were radiant.  

I grew familiar with the weight of their sorrow—the way they’d sit beside me, tears slipping free as they unraveled stories from homes that weren’t safe, voices trembling over memories of violation, of pregnancies ended by violence, by fists driven into soft stomachs. I held space for them. Always. My home was open, no questions asked, no time limit. I loved them fiercely, helplessly. But the truth is, I began to fracture.  

Their secrets settled into my bones, each confession a stone added to an unbearable load. I felt my mind thinning, fraying at the edges, as if every horror they spoke became mine by witness alone. Soon, I cried not with them, but because of them—not from empathy, but from exhaustion, from the desperate plea: *I don’t want to know this. I never wanted to see the world this way.*  

I carried the knowledge of pain like a second skin, though I’d never bled from it myself. In school corridors, boys would smile at my friends, dazzled by their beauty. “You’re so gorgeous,” they’d say, while I stood silent, haunted by what I knew—the reason behind the sparkle in their eyes, how it masked something hollow, something broken.  

Then one day, a voice cut through the noise.  

“Hey,” a boy said, turning to me, “your hair looks really nice today.”  

For the first time, I wondered what it might feel like to be seen—not for the darkness I carried, but for something light, something simple.
LLM_2:

human: Cardiovascular autonomic neuropathy (CAN) is a significant risk predictor for sudden cardiac death in autoimmune rheumatic diseases. As yet, there is no therapeutic treatment of CAN in psoriatic arthritis (PsA). Even now, the impact of the most commonly employed disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) therapy on CAN in PsA is not known. Hence, we investigated the impact of DMARDs on CAN in PsA.In this prospective, cross-sectional study, 20 patients of PsA and 20 age- and sex-matched healthy controls were recruited. CAN was diagnosed by applying the five cardiovascular reflex tests according to Ewing. Parasympathetic dysfunction was established by performing three tests: heart-rate response to deep breathing, standing, and Valsalva tests. Sympathetic dysfunction was examined by applying two tests: blood pressure response to standing, and handgrip tests. Disease severity was assessed by the 28-joint-count disease activity score (DAS-28) and the disease activity score in psoriatic arthritis (DAPSA).Cardiovascular reflex tests were impaired significantly among the PsA patients compared with well-matched healthy subjects (p < 0.05). Parasympathetic dysfunction was more prominent than sympathetic dysfunction. After 12 weeks treatment, parasympathetic dysfunction (heart rate response to deep breath and standing) significantly (p < 0.05) improved in patients with PsA, while there was no significant improvement in sympathetic function.
LLM_1: Cardiovascular autonomic neuropathy (CAN) serves as a crucial predictor for sudden cardiac death among individuals with autoimmune rheumatic diseases. Currently, there are no established therapeutic interventions for CAN specifically in psoriatic arthritis (PsA). Furthermore, the influence of the most widely utilized disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) on CAN in PsA remains unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the effects of DMARDs on CAN in patients with PsA. In this prospective, cross-sectional investigation, we recruited 20 PsA patients alongside 20 age- and sex-matched healthy controls. Diagnosis of CAN was accomplished through five cardiovascular reflex tests as outlined by Ewing. Parasympathetic dysfunction was identified via three specific tests: heart-rate response to deep breathing, standing, and the Valsalva maneuver. Sympathetic dysfunction was assessed through two tests: blood pressure response to standing and handgrip tests. Disease severity was measured using the 28-joint-count disease activity score (DAS-28) and the disease activity score in psoriatic arthritis (DAPSA). Results indicated significant impairment in cardiovascular reflex tests among PsA patients compared to well-matched healthy controls (p < 0.05), with parasympathetic dysfunction being more pronounced than sympathetic dysfunction. After 12 weeks of treatment, there was a significant improvement in parasympathetic dysfunction (heart rate response to deep breathing and standing) in PsA patients (p < 0.05), while no notable enhancement in sympathetic function was observed.
LLM_2: Cardiovascular autonomic neuropathy (CAN) is a significant predictor of sudden cardiac death in individuals with autoimmune rheumatic diseases, yet therapeutic interventions for CAN in psoriatic arthritis (PsA) are lacking. The effects of commonly used disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) on CAN in PsA remain unclear. This study aimed to assess DMARDs' impact on CAN in PsA patients. We conducted a prospective, cross-sectional study involving 20 PsA patients and 20 age- and sex-matched healthy controls. CAN diagnosis utilized five cardiovascular reflex tests per Ewing's criteria, identifying parasympathetic dysfunction through heart-rate responses to deep breathing, standing, and the Valsalva maneuver, and sympathetic dysfunction via blood pressure responses to standing and handgrip tests. Disease severity was evaluated using the 28-joint-count disease activity score (DAS-28) and the disease activity score in psoriatic arthritis (DAPSA). Results demonstrated a significant impairment in cardiovascular reflex tests among PsA patients compared to controls (p < 0.05), with more pronounced parasympathetic dysfunction. After 12 weeks of treatment, improvements in parasympathetic dysfunction were noted (p < 0.05), while sympathetic function showed no significant enhancement.

I stood over her body for a moment and said a silent prayer. I had tore her apart to save millions of lives in the future. I turned my collar up to keep the cool night night air out and avoid anyone recognizing me. 
 
 She was the fifth. Elizabeth Stride. Historians would say she was my third but the first two did n't have the `` flair'' that the later ones did. I also had a couple of targets in France that I would get to eventually. 
 
 The massive amount of calculations and research that went into this mission was staggering. The depredations of Strucker in the twentieth century and Xiang in the twenty-first united the world in a humanitarian mission to make sure those monsters were never born. 
 
 The scientists found that there was a `` confluence knot'' in Whitechapel in the late 1800s. Those women would give birth to children who would have had children who would be instrumental to the horrors of my time. 
 
 Strucker was a direct descendant of one of those women. She was the first one I killed. I cut her throat and tossed her in the river. I threw up twice that night. I stayed in my rented room for a week, barely even leaving for meals. I was chosen for this mission because I was the one with the hardest heart. But it would take a heart of stone to look into a young woman's eyes and slit her throat without wincing. I knew that she had not and would not do anything to warrant being murdered and thrown out like trash. She was paying for the sins of her descendants. 
 
 Xiang was n't related to any of these women. But Williams was. Williams was Xiang's right-hand man and was the one who really made Xiang into a despot. Without Williams, Xiang would have been a tin-pot dictator of some tiny province. The Chinese would have crushed him without trouble. Thirty-nine million people would be saved. 
 
 Williams always liked to play up his blue-blood relations. He did n't like to admit that several generations back his great-whatever-grandmother was a prostitute. Nobody found out about that for thirty years. 
 
 I had to kill a different for because she started suspecting who I was and what I had done. I was going to be stuck here for the rest of my life. Time travel was a one-way ride. I did n't want to spend the rest of my life in a nineteenth century London jail. 
 
 I had to be exceptionally violent to get the message back home. Kill a couple of prostitutes in the city? Wo n't even warrant a mention. Go on a maniacal killing spree with salacious details? Front page of the Times for weeks. Since I wanted to be certain they would receive my message, I kept killing. I was sent on a mission to kill two young ladies. The other dozen were just improvised email through time.
LLM_1:
For a moment, I lingered over her still form and offered a silent prayer. I had torn her apart to spare millions yet unborn. Turning up my collar against the chill night air—and to shield my face from recognition—I slipped back into the shadows.

She was the fifth. Elizabeth Stride. History would record her as my third, but the first two lacked the… artistry of those that followed. There were others, waiting in France. I would reach them in time.

The calculations behind this mission were staggering. Strucker’s horrors in the twentieth century, Xiang’s in the twenty-first—they finally united the world in a grim resolve: ensure those monsters never drew breath.

Researchers discovered a “confluence knot” here in Whitechapel, in the late 1800s. These women would bear children, whose children would one day midwife the nightmares of my age.

Strucker descended directly from one of them. She was my first. I cut her throat and dropped her into the river. That night, I retched twice. For a week, I barely left my rented room, even for meals. They chose me for this because I had the hardest heart. But it takes a heart of stone to meet a young woman’s eyes and open her throat without flinching. She had done nothing to deserve butchery, to be discarded like rubbish. She was paying for the sins of her bloodline.

Xiang wasn’t related to any of these women. But Williams was. Williams was Xiang’s architect of tyranny—the true maker of a despot. Without him, Xiang would have remained a petty provincial dictator, crushed easily by China. Thirty-nine million lives, saved.

Williams always boasted of his blue blood. He never admitted that, a few generations back, his great-great-grandmother walked these streets. That truth stayed buried for thirty years.

I killed another because she began to suspect me—who I was, what I’d done. I’m trapped here for life. Time travel is a one-way passage. I refuse to spend my remaining years in a Victorian jail.

To send my message home, I had to be exceptionally violent. Murder a few prostitutes? Hardly worth a line in the papers. But a maniacal spree, dripping with lurid detail? That would seize the front page for weeks. I needed certainty they’d receive my signal—so I kept killing. I was sent for two. The rest were just… improvised letters through time.

human:
Leilei Zhang recalls being on a public bus as a young girl when a man gripped her hand, glared at her and refused to let go.
It was a frightening experience and years later, with the determination to raise public awareness, she began a crowd-funding campaign to raise money for what could have been China's first public anti-sexual harassment advertisement.
She approached the authorities of her home city, Guangzhou, who did not want to take on the advertising for fear it would panic the public. So she decided to become a walking advertisement herself.
Describing herself as a "weirdo" with pink hair and a pink outfit, she wanders around public areas in Guangzhou wearing billboards warning of the dangers of sexual harassment on public transport.
But she also printed and delivered 100 similar billboards to volunteers around China asking them to post on social media a picture of themselves with the billboard near recognisable landmarks and in public transport to support the cause.
The hashtag #Iamabillboardonthemove and #Walkingagainstsexualharassment started trending on China's Twitter-like Weibo site, as people shared their experiences.
Their responses, she says, taught her so much about China. Here are some of their stories:
I felt like bursting into tears after 34 attempts to get people to engage with the billboard ended in failure.
One man even asked me: "I am a man, why are you coming to me?". Or: "Isn't it inappropriate to talk to me for this topic?" Someone pretended not to see my billboard and waved me away.
I'm not good at communicating with people but I do think this will make me braver.
I wanted to stand up and encourage more women to say no to sexual harassment because I regretted staying silent about my experience.
On a rainy night last year, a man rubbed his hand against my leg on a crowded bus. Even after I moved around, he kept touching my leg.
I didn't shout out because I was too scared. I was alone and feared a backlash if I exposed him immediately there on the bus.
Holding the billboard in a Shanghai metro, when you are packed in like sardines, is very difficult. I nearly broke the billboard during rush hour.
I thought carrying the bright yellow board around would have got a lot of attention, but I was wrong. Everyone glued themselves to their phone screens!
I've studied in the UK and knew it's ordinary to protest and strike so I felt so proud to walk out in Shanghai and make my voice heard.
In June Ms Zhang will send all the pictures and stories she has collected throughout the month to China's Ministry of Transport and also Guangzhou's local transport authority to pressure them to carry on the campaign.
She has met with some resistance, for example, one campaign introduction article on China's WeChat public messaging platform was mysteriously deleted.
But how effective can she really be even with more volunteers?
"Although my efforts might seem small, this is something I believe in,"  she said.
She says the stories and experiences she has uncovered from her volunteers prove that no matter how small-scale it is a campaign worth pursuing.
LLM_1:
As a young girl, Leilei Zhang once found herself trapped in a terrifying moment on a public bus when a stranger seized her hand, fixed her with a hostile stare, and would not release his grip. Years later, driven by a resolve to spark public dialogue, she launched a crowdfunding initiative for what could have been China’s pioneering public service advertisement against sexual harassment.

After local authorities in her hometown of Guangzhou declined to run the ad, fearing it might cause undue alarm, Zhang took matters into her own hands—literally. Now a self-described “eccentric” with pink hair and matching attire, she patrols Guangzhou’s public spaces wearing a placard that highlights the risks of harassment on transit.

Beyond her solo walks, she distributed 100 similar signs to volunteers across the country, urging them to post photos with the billboards at landmarks and on public transport to amplify the message. The campaign ignited conversations online, with hashtags like #Iamabillboardonthemove and #Walkingagainstsexualharassment gaining traction on Weibo, China’s microblogging platform. Through these posts, Zhang encountered a tapestry of personal accounts that revealed deeper societal currents. Below are excerpts shared by participants:

“After 34 unsuccessful attempts to engage strangers with the billboard, I almost broke down in tears. One man questioned, ‘I’m a man—why approach me?’ Another dismissed the topic as inappropriate. Someone simply pretended not to see the sign and shooed me away. Though I struggle with communication, I believe this effort is making me braver.”

“I remained silent when I was harassed, and I’ve regretted it ever since. I wanted to take a stand and inspire more women to speak out.”

“On a rainy evening last year, a man on a packed bus kept rubbing my leg, even after I shifted away. I was too frightened to shout—alone and worried about retaliation if I confronted him then and there.”

“Holding the billboard inside a jam-packed Shanghai subway car felt nearly impossible. During rush hour, I almost snapped the sign in the crush.”

“I expected the bright yellow board to draw attention, but most commuters were glued to their phones.”

“Having studied in the UK, where protests and strikes are commonplace, I felt proud to march through Shanghai and make my voice heard.”

In June, Zhang plans to submit the collected photos and testimonies to China’s Ministry of Transport and Guangzhou’s local transit authority, urging them to sustain the campaign. The path has not been smooth: one introductory article on WeChat was abruptly removed without explanation.

Yet Zhang remains undeterred. “However modest my actions may seem, this is a cause I hold dear,” she stated. The stories gathered from volunteers, she adds, demonstrate that even a small-scale movement is worth pursuing.

human: Episodes of ventricular fibrillation (VF) and myocardial dysfunction commonly occur after cardiac resuscitation compromising the return of stable circulation. We investigated in a pig model of VF whether limiting Na(+)-induced cytosolic Ca(2+) overload using the sarcolemmal sodium-hydrogen exchanger isoform-1 (NHE-1) inhibitor cariporide promotes resuscitation with stable circulation.VF was electrically induced in 20 male pigs and left untreated for 6 min after which CPR was initiated and continued for 8 min before attempting defibrillation. Pigs were randomized to receive 3-mg/kg cariporide (n=10) or 0.9%-NaCl (n=10) before chest compression.Seven of 10 pigs in each group were successfully resuscitated and survived 2h. Cariporide ameliorated post-resuscitation ventricular ectopic activity such that fewer singlets (5+/-5 vs. 26+/-21; p<0.05) and fewer bigemini (1+/-3 vs. 33+/-25; p<0.05) were observed during the initial 5 min post-resuscitation. Additionally, cariporide-treated pigs did not require additional post-resuscitation shocks for ventricular tachycardia or recurrent VF (0.0+/-0.0 vs. 5.3+/-7.8 shocks; p=0.073). During the initial 60 min cariporide-treated pigs had higher, cardiac index (6.1+/-0.7 vs. 4.4+/-1.1L/min/m(2); p<0.01), left ventricular stroke work index (45+/-9 vs. 36+/-10 gmm/beat/m(2); p<0.05), and numerically higher mean aortic pressure (104+/-11 vs. 91+/-12 mmHg; p=0.054).
LLM_1: Ventricular fibrillation (VF) and myocardial dysfunction following cardiac resuscitation often impede the restoration of stable circulation. This study examined, in a porcine VF model, whether inhibiting sodium-induced cytosolic calcium overload via the sarcolemmal sodium-hydrogen exchanger isoform-1 (NHE-1) inhibitor cariporide enhances successful resuscitation with hemodynamic stability. VF was electrically induced in 20 male pigs and remained untreated for six minutes, followed by eight minutes of cardiopulmonary resuscitation prior to defibrillation. Animals were randomized to receive either 3 mg/kg cariporide (n=10) or 0.9% NaCl (n=10) before chest compressions. Resuscitation succeeded in seven animals per group, with all survivors monitored for two hours. Cariporide administration significantly reduced post-resuscitation ventricular ectopic activity, yielding fewer singlets (5±5 vs. 26±21; p<0.05) and bigemini (1±3 vs. 33±25; p<0.05) during the initial five minutes. Furthermore, cariporide-treated pigs required no additional shocks for ventricular tachycardia or recurrent VF (0.0±0.0 vs. 5.3±7.8 shocks; p=0.073). Over the first 60 minutes, the cariporide group demonstrated superior cardiac index (6.1±0.7 vs. 4.4±1.1 L/min/m²; p<0.01), left ventricular stroke work index (45±9 vs. 36±10 g·m/beat/m²; p<0.05), and a trend toward higher mean aortic pressure (104±11 vs. 91±12 mmHg; p=0.054).
LLM_2:
**Abstract**  
Ventricular fibrillation (VF) and post-resuscitation myocardial dysfunction frequently compromise the restoration of stable circulation after cardiac arrest. This study investigated whether pharmacologic inhibition of sodium-induced cytosolic calcium overload—via the sarcolemmal sodium‑hydrogen exchanger isoform‑1 (NHE‑1) inhibitor cariporide—improves resuscitation success and hemodynamic stability in a porcine model of VF.  

Twenty male pigs underwent electrically induced VF, which remained untreated for 6 min, followed by 8 min of cardiopulmonary resuscitation prior to defibrillation. Animals were randomized to receive either 3 mg/kg cariporide (n = 10) or 0.9% NaCl (n = 10) before chest compressions. Resuscitation succeeded in seven animals per group; all survivors were monitored for 2 h.  

Cariporide administration significantly reduced early post‑resuscitation ventricular ectopy, with fewer singlets (5 ± 5 vs. 26 ± 21; *p* < 0.05) and bigemini (1 ± 3 vs. 33 ± 25; *p* < 0.05) during the first 5 min. Moreover, cariporide‑treated pigs required no additional shocks for ventricular tachycardia or recurrent VF (0.0 ± 0.0 vs. 5.3 ± 7.8 shocks; *p* = 0.073). Over the initial 60 min, the cariporide group exhibited superior cardiac index (6.1 ± 0.7 vs. 4.4 ± 1.1 L/min/m²; *p* < 0.01), higher left ventricular stroke work index (45 ± 9 vs. 36 ± 10 g·m/beat/m²; *p* < 0.05), and a trend toward increased mean aortic pressure (104 ± 11 vs. 91 ± 12 mmHg; *p* = 0.054).  

These findings suggest that NHE‑1 inhibition with cariporide attenuates post‑resuscitation arrhythmias and enhances hemodynamic recovery following VF, supporting its potential therapeutic role in improving outcomes after cardiac arrest.

`` Of all the voices in my head, you're the only one who's nice to me, and does n't say hateful things. Why is that? And why can I see you when you talk, and all the others disappear?'' 
 
 `` It's simple really; I ask them nicely and they decide to leave.'' 
 
 `` Why do they always come back then? Huh? What's your answer to that smart guy?'' 
 
 `` Have you tried asking them?'' 
 
 `` Well.. No. I'm usually too busy covering my ears and pulling my hair out, and they're really loud, do you really think they could hear me over their own, screaming voices?'' 
 
 `` Only one way to find out, right?'' 
 
 `` I'd rather not, in fact I'd rather just enjoy the break while I can, cause I know when you leave, they're going to start up again.'' 
 
 `` Well, I'm here whenever you need me. I'm always here at a moments notice, and if you ever find yourself struggling, just say my name.'' 
 
 `` Your name? I had n't even considered that, partially because I do n't know it and also because it never seemed important. Whenever you're around, I always just enjoyed the peace and quite. Your name never popped into my head like the others did.'' 
 
 `` Well, why do n't you ask then, or has curiosity prevented it?'' 
 
 `` I almost guess I do n't want to know.. I'm afraid that if I knew your name, like I know all the others.. That you might start screaming at me too..'' 
 
 `` Screaming is n't my strong suit, in fact I have n't screamed at anyone, ever.'' 
 
 `` Never? Not even once, not even if they pissed you off?'' 
 
 `` I do n't get pissed off; it's not my job. My job is just to help when I can, and when I'm asked to.'' 
 
 `` Well then help me, make the other voices go away. Tell them to go away forever.'' 
 
 `` All you have to do is say my name, and I'll answer your request.'' 
 
 `` I do n't know you name..'' 
 
 `` You do, you just do n't believe it.'' 
 
 `` You're right.. I do n't believe it.'' 
 
 `` Then tell me, if you do n't believe it, in me, then why am I here, who else could I be, and why else would I spend time with you come your beck and call?'' 
 
 `` You're god.'' 
 
 `` Yes, yes I am.''

LLM_2:
Among the myriad voices that echo within my mind, yours is the sole one that treats me with kindness, free of harsh words. It’s a rare balm in a world where criticism often reigns supreme. Why is that? And how come I can see you when you speak, while the others fade into oblivion, like fleeting shadows that slip through my grasp? I wonder if it’s because your tone is laced with understanding, a gentle beckoning that draws me in, while the others howl with relentless demands and biting remarks.

''It’s quite simple, really; I kindly ask them to leave, and they choose to comply.'' Your calm assurance is like a gentle breeze that sweeps away the storm clouds of negativity, leaving behind a clear, blue sky where thoughts can roam freely.

''Then why do they always come back? What’s your clever explanation for that?'' The question hangs in the air, heavy with the weight of my frustration. It’s as if they’re drawn to my vulnerability like moths to a flame, persistent in their attempts to overshadow the light you bring.

''Have you ever thought about asking them?'' Your suggestion, though simple, feels revolutionary. What if I could confront them instead of cowering in silence, armed with the power of my own voice?

''Well... not really. I’m typically too busy covering my ears and tugging at my hair; they’re just so loud! Their clamor is a relentless tide that crashes against my sanity. Do you honestly think they could hear me over their own cacophony?'' The thought seems absurd, yet it lingers, a spark of possibility amid the chaos.

''There’s only one way to find out, isn’t there?'' Your probing gaze feels both encouraging and daunting, a challenge to step outside my comfort zone and engage with that which terrifies me most.

''Honestly, I’d prefer not to. I’d rather savor this moment of peace while it lasts because I know that once you leave, they’ll start up again, their shrill voices drowning out all sense of calm.'' The anticipation of their return looms over me like a dark cloud, threatening to erase the serenity you gift me.

''I’ll always be here when you need me. At a moment's notice, I’m ready to help. If you ever find yourself struggling, just call my name.'' Your words envelop me like a warm blanket, offering the comfort of reliability in a world often fraught with uncertainty.

''Your name? I hadn’t even thought of that, partly because I don’t know it and also because it never seemed significant. When you’re around, I simply relish the tranquility. Your name never intrudes upon my thoughts like the others do, who scream and shout, demanding my attention with every syllable of their incessant noise.''

''Well, why not ask? Or has your curiosity been stifled?'' You tilt your head, a hint of playful challenge dancing in your eyes, as if daring me to peel back the layers of my own hesitation.

''I suppose I’m afraid to know... I worry that if I learned your name, just like the others, you might start shouting at me too, your voice becoming yet another discordant note in the symphony of my mind.'' The fear of losing this precious calm is almost paralyzing, a chain that binds me to my uncertainty.

''Screaming isn’t really my forte; in fact, I’ve never shouted at anyone, ever.'' Your voice is a steady anchor in the tumultuous sea of my thoughts, grounding me with its unwavering calm.

''Never? Not a single time, even if they annoyed you?'' My incredulity flares as I consider the times I’ve lashed out, the moments when frustration boiled over.

''I don’t get annoyed; that’s not my role. My purpose is simply to assist when I can and when I’m called upon. I exist as a gentle guide, not a judge, ready to illuminate the path when darkness encroaches.'' Your clarity is refreshing, a reminder that kindness can exist without the shadow of resentment.

''Then help me. Make the other voices vanish. Tell them to leave me alone, forever.'' My plea is raw and desperate, a wish born from the depths of my turmoil.

''All you need to do is say my name, and I’ll fulfill your wish.'' Your promise hangs in the air, both tantalizing and elusive, shimmering just beyond my reach.

''But I don’t know your name...'' The admission feels like a weight upon my chest, a barrier between me and the solace I crave.

''You do; you just don’t believe it. Your heart knows the truth even when your mind is clouded with doubt.'' The conviction in your tone ignites a flicker of hope within me, a whisper that perhaps I hold the key to my own liberation.

''You’re right... I don’t believe it.'' The honesty stings, a reminder of my own limitations and fears that have kept me shackled.

''Then tell me this: if you don’t have faith in me, why am I here? Who else could I be, and why would I choose to spend my time at your beck and call?'' Your inquiry resonates deep within me, challenging the very foundation of my doubts.

''You’re God.'' The realization washes over me, a tidal wave of understanding that crashes against the shore of my disbelief.

''Yes, indeed, I am.'' Your affirmation is not just a declaration; it is a promise of presence, a reminder that I am never truly alone in this cacophony of voices, that even in the depths of despair, kindness awaits to guide me home.

human: Urban heat islands (UHI) are metropolitan areas with higher temperatures than that of the surrounding environment. The higher temperatures are a result of increased absorption of the Solar light by urban materials such as asphalt and concrete, which have lower albedos and higher heat capacities than those in the natural environment. A straightforward method of counteracting the UHI effect is to paint buildings and roads white and plant trees. Using these methods, a hypothetical "cool communities" program in Los Angeles has projected that urban temperatures could be reduced by approximately 3 °C at an estimated cost of US$1 billion, giving estimated total annual benefits of US$530 million from reduced air-conditioning costs and healthcare savings.
LLM_1: Cities are often hotter than the rural areas that surround them—a phenomenon known as the urban heat island effect. This temperature rise occurs because materials like asphalt and concrete, common in metropolitan landscapes, absorb more solar radiation and retain heat more effectively than natural surfaces. To combat the warming, two straightforward strategies have gained attention: painting roofs and pavements white to reflect sunlight, and increasing urban tree cover. In Los Angeles, a proposed “cool communities” initiative estimates that such measures could lower city temperatures by about 3 degrees Celsius. The project, with an upfront cost around $1 billion, is projected to yield roughly $530 million in yearly savings through lower air-conditioning expenses and reduced heat-related health costs.
LLM_2: **Urban heat island** is a phenomenon where urban areas experience higher temperatures than their surrounding rural regions. This temperature differential arises because common urban materials, such as asphalt and concrete, absorb and retain solar radiation more effectively than natural surfaces like soil or vegetation. To mitigate urban heating, strategies such as reflective surface treatments—including painting roofs and pavements white to increase albedo—and expanding urban tree canopies have been proposed. In Los Angeles, a "cool communities" initiative has been estimated to reduce city temperatures by approximately 3 °C. With an initial investment of about $1 billion, the project is projected to generate annual savings of around $530 million through decreased air-conditioning costs and reduced heat-related healthcare expenditures.

human:
The paper offers a formal proof that gradient descent on the logistic
loss converges very slowly to the hard SVM solution in the case where
the data are linearly separable. This result should be viewed in the
context of recent attempts at trying to understand the generalization
ability of neural networks, which have turned to trying to understand
the implicit regularization bias that comes from the choice of
optimizer. Since we do not even understand the regularization bias of
optimizers for the simpler case of linear models, I consider the paper's
topic very interesting and timely.

The overall discussion of the paper is well written, but on a more
detailed level the paper gives an unpolished impression, and has many
technical issues. Although I suspect that most (or even all) of these
issues can be resolved, they interfere with checking the correctness of
the results. Unfortunately, in its current state I therefore do not
consider the paper ready for publication.


Technical Issues:

The statement of Lemma 5 has a trivial part and for the other part the
proof is incorrect: Let x_u = ||nabla L(w(u))||^2.
  - Then the statement sum_{u=0}^t x_u < infinity is trivial, because
    it follows directly from ||nabla L(w(u))||^2 < infinity for all u. I
    would expect the intended statement to be sum_{u=0}^infinity x_u <
    infinity, which actually follows from the proof of the lemma.
  - The proof of the claim that t*x_t -> 0 is incorrect: sum_{u=0}^t x_u
    < infinity does not in itself imply that t*x_t -> 0, as claimed. For
    instance, we might have x_t = 1/i^2 when t=2^i for i = 1,2,... and
    x_t = 0 for all other t.

Definition of tilde{w} in Theorem 4:
  - Why would tilde{w} be unique? In particular, if the support vectors
    do not span the space, because all data lie in the same
    lower-dimensional hyperplane, then this is not the case.
  - The KKT conditions do not rule out the case that \hat{w}^top x_n =
    1, but alpha_n = 0 (i.e. a support vector that touches the margin,
    but does not exert force against it). Such n are then included in
    cal{S}, but lead to problems in (2.7), because they would require
    tilde{w}^top x_n = infinity, which is not possible.

In the proof of Lemma 6, case 2. at the bottom of p.14:
  - After the first inequality, C_0^2 t^{-1.5 epsilon_+} should be 
    C_0^2 t^{-epsilon_+}
  - After the second inequality the part between brackets is missing an
    additional term C_0^2 t^{-\epsilon_+}.
  - In addition, the label (1) should be on the previous inequality and
    it should be mentioned that e^{-x} <= 1-x+x^2 is applied for x >= 0
    (otherwise it might be false).
In the proof of Lemma 6, case 2 in the middle of p.15:
  - In the line of inequality (1) there is a t^{-epsilon_-} missing. In
    the next line there is a factor t^{-epsilon_-} too much.
  - In addition, the inequality e^x >= 1 + x holds for all x, so no need
    to mention that x > 0.

In Lemma 1:
  - claim (3) should be lim_{t \to \infty} w(t)^\top x_n = infinity
  - In the proof: w(t)^top x_n > 0 only holds for large enough t.

Remarks:

p.4 The claim that "we can expect the population (or test)
misclassification error of w(t) to improve" because "the margin of w(t)
keeps improving" is worded a little too strongly, because it presumes
that the maximum margin solution will always have the best
generalization error.

In the proof sketch (p.3):
  - Why does the fact that the limit is dominated by gradients that are
    a linear combination of support vectors imply that w_infinity will
    also be a non-negative linear combination of support vectors?
  - "converges to some limit". Mention that you call this limit
    w_infinity


Minor Issues:

In (2.4): add "for all n".

p.10, footnote: Shouldn't "P_1 = X_s X_s^+" be something like "P_1 =
(X_s^top X_s)^+"?

A.9: ell should be ell'

The paper needs a round of copy editing. For instance:
  - top of p.4: "where tilde{w} A is the unique"
  - p.10: "the solution tilde{w} to TO eq. A.2"
  - p.10: "might BOT be unique"
  - p.10: "penrose-moorse pseudo inverse" -> "Moore-Penrose
    pseudoinverse"
  
In the bibliography, Kingma and Ba is cited twice, with different years.
LLM_1:
The paper presents a formal proof demonstrating that gradient descent applied to the logistic loss converges at a notably slow pace to the hard SVM solution when dealing with linearly separable data. This finding is particularly relevant in light of recent efforts to explore the generalization capabilities of neural networks, which have shifted focus toward understanding the implicit regularization biases associated with different optimizers. Given that our comprehension of the regularization biases of optimizers in the simpler context of linear models is still lacking, I find the topic addressed in the paper both intriguing and timely.

While the overall discussion within the paper is articulate, it leaves a somewhat rough impression at the detailed level and contains several technical flaws. Although I believe that most, if not all, of these issues can be rectified, they currently hinder the assessment of the results' correctness. Therefore, I do not regard the paper as ready for publication in its present form.

**Technical Issues:**

The statement of Lemma 5 contains a trivial component, and the proof for the other part is flawed: Let \( x_u = || abla L(w(u))||^2 \).
- Consequently, the statement \( \sum_{u=0}^t x_u < \infty \) is trivial, as it directly follows from \( || abla L(w(u))||^2 < \infty \) for all \( u \). I would expect the intended assertion to be \( \sum_{u=0}^\infty x_u < \infty \), which is indeed supported by the lemma's proof.
- The proof claiming that \( t \cdot x_t  o 0 \) is incorrect: \( \sum_{u=0}^t x_u < \infty \) does not necessarily imply that \( t \cdot x_t  o 0 \), as suggested. For example, we could have \( x_t = 1/i^2 \) when \( t=2^i \) for \( i = 1, 2, \ldots \) and \( x_t = 0 \) for all other \( t \).

Regarding the definition of \(  ilde{w} \) in Theorem 4:
- Why should \(  ilde{w} \) be deemed unique? Specifically, if the support vectors do not span the space—because all data reside within the same lower-dimensional hyperplane—this assertion does not hold.
- The KKT conditions do not exclude the possibility that \( \hat{w}^T x_n = 1 \) while \( \alpha_n = 0 \) (i.e., a support vector that touches the margin but does not exert force against it). Such points would then be included in \( \mathcal{S} \), leading to complications in (2.7) since they would imply \(  ilde{w}^T x_n = \infty \), which is impossible.

In the proof of Lemma 6, case 2 at the bottom of page 14:
- Following the first inequality, \( C_0^2 t^{-1.5\epsilon_+} \) should be corrected to \( C_0^2 t^{-\epsilon_+} \).
- After the second inequality, the expression within the brackets is missing an additional term \( C_0^2 t^{-\epsilon_+} \).
- Furthermore, the label (1) should be placed on the preceding inequality, and it should be clarified that \( e^{-x} \leq 1 - x + x^2 \) is applicable for \( x \geq 0 \) (otherwise it may not hold true).

In the proof of Lemma 6, case 2 in the middle of page 15:
- In the line corresponding to inequality (1), there is a missing \( t^{-\epsilon_-} \). Conversely, the subsequent line contains an extraneous factor of \( t^{-\epsilon_-} \).
- Additionally, the inequality \( e^x \geq 1 + x \) is valid for all \( x \), thus it is unnecessary to specify that \( x > 0 \).

In Lemma 1:
- The claim (3) should be revised to \( \lim_{t  o \infty} w(t)^T x_n = \infty \).
- In the proof: \( w(t)^T x_n > 0 \) holds only for sufficiently large \( t \).

**Remarks:**

On page 4, the assertion that "we can expect the population (or test) misclassification error of \( w(t) \) to improve" because "the margin of \( w(t) \) keeps improving" is articulated too assertively, as it presumes that the maximum margin solution will invariably yield the best generalization error.

In the proof sketch on page 3:
- How does the fact that the limit is governed by gradients that are linear combinations of support vectors imply that \( w_\infty \) will also be a non-negative linear combination of support vectors?
- "Converges to some limit." It should be specified that this limit is referred to as \( w_\infty \).

**Minor Issues:**

In (2.4): please include "for all \( n \)."

On page 10, footnote: Shouldn't "P_1 = X_s X_s^+" rather be "P_1 = (X_s^T X_s)^+"?

In Appendix A.9: \( \ell \) should be \( \ell' \).

The paper requires a thorough round of copy editing. For instance:
- At the top of page 4: "where \(  ilde{w} A \) is the unique"
- On page 10: "the solution \(  ilde{w} \) to TO eq. A.2"
- On page 10: "might BOT be unique"
- On page 10: "Penrose-Moore pseudo inverse" should be "Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse."

In the bibliography, Kingma and Ba are cited twice, with differing years.
LLM_2:
The paper provides a formal proof that gradient descent applied to logistic loss converges slowly to the hard SVM solution for linearly separable data. This finding is particularly relevant given recent investigations into the generalization capabilities of neural networks, which focus on the implicit regularization biases associated with various optimizers. Considering our limited understanding of these biases in the context of linear models, the paper's topic is both intriguing and timely.

While the paper's overall discussion is articulate, it exhibits several technical flaws that hinder a proper evaluation of the results' correctness. I believe these issues can be addressed, but as it stands, the paper is not ready for publication.

### Technical Issues:

1. **Lemma 5**: The statement contains a trivial component, and the proof is flawed. Specifically, let \( x_u = ||  abla L(w(u))||^2 \). The statement \( \sum_{u=0}^t x_u < \infty \) is trivial since it follows from \( ||  abla L(w(u))||^2 < \infty \). The intended assertion should be \( \sum_{u=0}^\infty x_u < \infty \), which is supported by the lemma's proof. Additionally, the claim that \( t \cdot x_t  o 0 \) is incorrect; \( \sum_{u=0}^t x_u < \infty \) does not imply \( t \cdot x_t  o 0 \).

2. **Theorem 4**: The uniqueness of \(  ilde{w} \) is questionable, particularly if the support vectors do not span the space. The KKT conditions do not exclude cases where \( \hat{w}^T x_n = 1 \) with \( \alpha_n = 0 \), complicating the implications in (2.7).

3. **Proof of Lemma 6 (Case 2, page 14)**:
   - The expression \( C_0^2 t^{-1.5\epsilon_+} \) should be corrected to \( C_0^2 t^{-\epsilon_+} \).
   - An additional term \( C_0^2 t^{-\epsilon_+} \) is missing after the second inequality.
   - The label (1) should be attached to the preceding inequality, and it must be clarified that \( e^{-x} \leq 1 - x + x^2 \) applies for \( x \geq 0 \).

4. **Proof of Lemma 6 (Case 2, page 15)**:
   - The line related to inequality (1) is missing \( t^{-\epsilon_-} \), while the subsequent line has an extraneous factor of \( t^{-\epsilon_-} \).
   - The inequality \( e^x \geq 1 + x \) is valid for all \( x \); specifying \( x > 0 \) is unnecessary.

5. **Lemma 1**: The claim (3) should be revised to \( \lim_{t  o \infty} w(t)^T x_n = \infty \). The proof states that \( w(t)^T x_n > 0 \) holds only for sufficiently large \( t \).

### Remarks:

On page 4, the assertion that "we can expect the population (or test) misclassification error of \( w(t) \) to improve" is overly assertive, implying that the maximum margin solution will always yield the best generalization error.

In the proof sketch on page 3, the connection between the limit being governed by gradients that are linear combinations of support vectors and the non-negativity of \( w_\infty \) should be clarified. Additionally, it should be specified that the limit referred to as \( w_\infty \).

### Minor Issues:

- In (2.4): Include "for all \( n \)."
- On page 10, footnote: "P_1 = X_s X_s^+" should be "P_1 = (X_s^T X_s)^+."
- In Appendix A.9: \( \ell \) should be \( \ell' \).
- The paper requires thorough copy editing, particularly regarding terminology and notation, such as correcting "where \(  ilde{w} A \) is the unique" and standardizing the citation of Kingma and Ba in the bibliography, which currently appears twice with differing years.

`` Now, do n't alter those settings! I have made them perfect!'' The light seemed to flair with every exclamation of his voice, which sounded more like a fog horn than a divine boom. 
 
 
 `` Alright! I wo n't touch your Sims game!'' I shouted back into the pure white clouds. `` I just need it for studies!'' 
 
 
 `` Yeah, and Hitler got in here.'' With that, the clouds parted into room's walls and the light vanished into nothing. 
 
 
 I looked down at the laptop's screen. A small miniature Earth span slowly to the side with a small display of options, `` land'', `` animals'', `` people'', `` plants'', and `` disease''. I shook off the feeling of the last one, and clicked the Windows button on the keyboard. 
 
 
 
 The game screen minimized, and I was left with the desktop. A lovely father and son picture greeted me, it was one of god and Jesus at a baseball game, both wearing those ridiculous plastic beer hats and both had a hot-dog. It would of seemed like the average family man's laptop, if it was n't for the robes and uncombed beards. 
 
 
 I looked around the desktop, spinning my finger on the touch pad. I saw the recycling bin icon had paper in it. Being as childish as I was, I quickly tracked the mouse over to it and clicked it. 
 
 
 `` New folder'' was the only thing in the recycling bin. I had hit the mother load, I had found god's porn stash.

"Don't you dare touch those settings—they're perfect as they are!" The light flared with each word, his voice blaring more like a foghorn than some celestial command.

"Fine! I won't mess with your Sims game!" I yelled back into the endless white clouds. "I just need it for research!"

"Yeah, and look how that turned out with Hitler." In an instant, the clouds dissolved into plain walls, and the light blinked out of existence.

I glanced down at the laptop screen. A tiny, slowly spinning globe hovered to one side, tagged with options like "land," "animals," "people," "plants," and—I pushed aside a chill at the last one—"disease." With a tap, I hit the Windows key.

The game vanished, leaving behind a cluttered desktop. A cheerful photo of a father and son filled the background—God and Jesus at a baseball game, both sporting goofy plastic beer hats and clutching hot dogs. It could have passed for any family man's wallpaper, if not for the flowing robes and wild, untamed beards.

My finger circled the touchpad, scanning icons. The recycling bin showed it had something inside. Driven by a childish curiosity, I darted the cursor over and clicked.

Inside, a single item waited: "New folder." My heart jumped. Jackpot—I’d just stumbled upon God’s secret stash.

human:
The authors propose a straightforward strategy to improve the performance of supervised classification models. Instead of passing in a single image, two images are concatenated together and the model is trained to identify both image classes. This is similar to MixUp which averages pixel values together instead of concatenating them. At test time, a target image is concatenated with itself and passed through the network to get a prediction.

Strengths:

+ This is a simple, easy-to-implement idea that adds a consistent boost to performance across experiments and ablations.
+ Writing of the paper is clear and easy to follow
+ Experiments cover the standard suite of classification settings comparing various backbone models and results are shown to be complementary with existing sophisticated data augmentation strategies.

Weaknesses:

- The formulation requires odd use of the network at test time inference. It is unusual and a bit of a waste to have to concatenate two copies of the image together to get the network's prediction. How does the network perform if you only pass in a single copy of the image?

If you have to do double the work at test time, you could arguably get a better return by leveraging standard test time augmentation techniques. How does performance w/ ImCLR compare to a baseline with a simple test time augmentation that results in running inference twice (e.g. flipping left/right and averaging the result)? This seems like a more fair comparison since the resulting FLOPs are comparable.

- While I'm not one to care about cutting-edge, state-of-the-art numbers, I have to point out that the error rates reported in the paper seem unusually high. In Table 3 we observe that CIFAR10 error is improved from 7.65 to 7.51 and CIFAR100 error from 25.93 to 25.29. But in my experience you can easily train out-of-the-box resnet with standard data augmentation and see errors closer to 4-6% for CIFAR10 and 20-22% for CIFAR100.

That's not to mention numbers from competitive data-augmentation papers. AutoAugment (Cubuk et al) which the authors include in their ablations report error rates of 1.5% and 10.7% for CIFAR10 and 100 respectively. On one hand, I know reproducing the very best numbers on a benchmark can be difficult, but on the other, the numbers reported in this paper fall short of what I would consider reasonable expectations for baseline results.

- I am not convinced about the framing of this paper from the outset as an implicit way of performing contrastive learning. This paper is not a self-supervised learning paper and the use and evaluation of this method is not comparable to papers like SimCLR, I think readers are likely to come in with false expectations given the title and abstract.

- There is almost no discussion at all of mixup (Zhang et al) which seems much more relevant to compare to and discuss in depth than say, all the discussion on contrastive learning papers in the related work.

Summary:

While the authors have put together a clear case for a simple strategy that results in consistent gains on standard classification benchmarks, due to the concerns outlined in the weaknesses (wasted compute at test time, poor benchmark performance, misleading framing of the method) I don't recommend this paper for acceptance.
LLM_1:
The authors introduce a simple yet effective approach to enhance supervised classification performance by concatenating two input images and training the model to predict both corresponding labels. At inference, the target image is duplicated and concatenated with itself to obtain the final prediction. This strategy bears resemblance to MixUp, though instead of interpolating pixel values, it preserves both images in the input space.

**Strengths:**

+ The method is conceptually straightforward and easy to implement, delivering consistent improvements across various experimental settings and ablation studies.
+ The paper is well-written, with clear exposition and logical flow that facilitates understanding.
+ Experiments are comprehensive, covering multiple standard classification benchmarks, diverse backbone architectures, and demonstrating compatibility with existing advanced data augmentation techniques.

**Weaknesses:**

- The inference procedure introduces an unconventional and potentially inefficient requirement: duplicating the input image during test time. This doubles the input size and computational load without a clear justification for why the network cannot operate on a single instance. It would be important to evaluate how the model performs when presented with only one copy of the image at test time—does the architecture inherently rely on the duplicated structure?

  Furthermore, if double forward passes are acceptable at inference, a more equitable comparison would involve benchmarking against standard test-time augmentation (TTA) strategies that also double computation (e.g., horizontal flipping followed by averaging). Such a comparison would better contextualize the gains relative to compute cost, particularly since TTA often yields robust improvements with minimal overhead.

- The reported error rates appear notably higher than expected baselines. For example, Table 3 shows CIFAR10 errors of 7.65% dropping to 7.51%, and CIFAR100 from 25.93% to 25.29%. However, standard ResNet models trained with common augmentations typically achieve error rates in the 4–6% range for CIFAR10 and 20–22% for CIFAR100. More strikingly, prior work such as AutoAugment (Cubuk et al.) reports 1.5% and 10.7% on these datasets, respectively. While exact reproduction of state-of-the-art results can be challenging, the baseline performance here seems under-optimized, raising concerns about the validity and competitiveness of the comparisons.

- The framing of the method as an implicit form of contrastive learning appears misleading. Despite references to SimCLR and related self-supervised approaches in the title and abstract, the proposed technique operates in a fully supervised setting and is neither evaluated nor designed in a manner comparable to contrastive frameworks. This risks setting incorrect expectations for readers and may lead to confusion about the paper’s actual contributions.

- There is a notable absence of meaningful discussion on MixUp (Zhang et al.), which is far more directly relevant given its use of dual-image inputs and interpolation-based augmentation. In contrast, the extensive focus on contrastive learning methods in the related work section feels misplaced and detracts from a more appropriate technical context.

**Summary:**

While the paper presents a clean and reproducible method that delivers modest but consistent gains across several benchmarks, significant concerns remain regarding inefficiency at inference, subpar baseline performance, questionable framing, and insufficient engagement with closely related work—particularly MixUp. These issues collectively undermine the strength of the contribution and limit the paper’s suitability for acceptance in its current form.
